Authors with affiliations: Sugiyama, Y., Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Fujitsu Laboratories Ltd., Japan, Japan Society of Applied Physics, Inst. Electronics, Info. Commun. E., Japan; Nakata, Y., Fujitsu Laboratories Ltd., Japan, Tokyo Univ. of Agric. and Technology, Japan, Japan Society of Applied Physics, Japan; Futatsugi, T., University of Tokyo, Japan, Fujitsu Laboratories Ltd., Atsugi, Japan, Physical Society of Japan, Japan Society of Applied Physics, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes observations of spectral hole burning of InAs self-assembled quantum dots (QDs) embedded in a pin diode. At 5 K, a narrow spectral hole of photo-current corresponding to the reading light laser with a width of less than 1 nm was observed. At a writing light power of 8 mW, the spectral hole depth increased as the electric field was increased. The spectral hole was observed up to 40 K. The spectral hole width at 8 mW fitted well with the convolution integral of a Gaussian distribution for the reading light and a Lorentzian distribution for the absorption change taking into account a homogeneous broadening of InAs QDs of ≤ 80 μeV. The spectral hole lifetime at 8 mW was estimated to be in the order of 10 -6 s from a rate equation. Type II QD structures were proposed to prolong the hole lifetime. The optical absorption spectrum of a 15-stack InAs QD structure was also observed at 77 K and 300 K.
Index Keywords: Electric fields; Electron energy levels; Integral equations; Lasers; Light absorption; Photocurrents; Semiconducting indium compounds; Semiconductor device structures; Semiconductor diodes; Semiconductor storage; Gaussian distribution; Lorentzian distribution; Spectral hole burning; Semiconductor quantum dots

Authors: Zhao Feng, Frietman E.E.E., Geng Wanzheng
Title: Experimental study on the combinative action of zinc chloride and triethanolamine on improving photosensitivity in red-sensitized dichromated gelatin for optical storage
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Zhao, Feng, Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Frietman, E.E.E., Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Geng, Wanzheng, Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: An experimental study to ascertain the combinative action of zinc chloride and triethanolamine (TEA) on improving photosensitivity of red-sensitized dichromated gelatin (RSDCG) has been carried out. Firstly, the exposure properties of home-made RSDCG were studied experimentally. Then, zinc chloride, a kind of Louis' acid, was added into the RSDCG to observe its catalytic effect on photo-cross-linking of gelatin molecules in RSDCG. After that, TEA, as a kind of external electron donor in RSDCG photo-chemical reaction, was introduced into RSDCG to make its photosensitivity higher in this study. Finally, the combinative effect of zinc chloride and TEA on the photosensitivity in RSDCG holograms was studied. The results show: (1). zinc chloride and TEA have obvious combinative effect on improving the photosensitivity of RSDCG. (2). the curve of diffraction efficiency of RSDCG holographic transmission grating vs exposure energy is bell-shaped. (3). the maximum diffraction efficiency of the grating can reach as high as 83% corresponding to the exposure energy about 200 mJ/cm2.
Index Keywords: Amines; Catalysis; Crosslinking; Diffraction gratings; Holograms; Photochemical reactions; Photosensitivity; Zinc compounds; Dichromated gelatin; Triethanolamine; Zinc chloride; Optical data storage

Authors: Leon Carlos, Martin Sergio, Luque Joaquin, Vazquez Manuel
Title: Explore: expert system for water networks management
Source title: Proceedings of the Mediterranean Electrotechnical Conference - MELECON
Affiliations: Univ of Seville, Seville, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Leon, Carlos, Univ of Seville, Seville, Spain; Martin, Sergio, Univ of Seville, Seville, Spain; Luque, Joaquin, Univ of Seville, Seville, Spain; Vazquez, Manuel, Univ of Seville, Seville, Spain
Abstract: An expert system called EXPLORE has been developed to manage the Seville City water supply system. The main difficulties are the lack of information on management procedures, the complicated electrical tariff, the dynamical character of the water network and the dependency of the water demand that is a major uncontrollable factor. EXPLORE reduces the cost of operation derived from the pumps to the different water storage tanks; for this task EXPLORE employs the water demand forecast to obtain an optimal pump daily schedule. EXPLORE has several additional benefits as to collect the operator experience. EXPLORE also permits to refine the operation processes through the simulation of new strategies and to provide the training for novice operators. The system has been applied to the management of the Seville City water supply system. EXPLORE have been tested reaching a great improvement in electrical cost (a saving of the 25% concerning the current operation satisfying water demand).
Index Keywords: Costs; Energy management; Mathematical models; Optimization; Problem solving; Water supply systems; Water tanks; Electrical operation costs; Electrical tariff; EXPLORE; Water demand; Expert systems

Authors: Barnes P.J., McDermott W.M., Edgar R.J., Kellogg E.M.
Title: Towards a solid-state detector response function for AXAF calibration
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden St., Cambridge MA 02138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barnes, P.J., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden St., Cambridge MA 02138, United States; McDermott, W.M., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden St., Cambridge MA 02138, United States; Edgar, R.J., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden St., Cambridge MA 02138, United States; Kellogg, E.M., Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden St., Cambridge MA 02138, United States
Abstract: As part of the extensive ground testing of the Advanced X-ray Astrophysics Facility (AXAF), x-ray detectors of standard design (flow-proportional counters and solid-state devices) were used as secondary absolute calibrators. In order to realise the overall facility calibration goal, these detectors need to be calibrated in turn on a primary x-ray standard. This exercise consists of accurately determining the detectors' response to monochromatic x-rays of different energies. Our data were obtained on various beamlines at the BESSY synchrotron storage ring, which is a very accurately calibrated standard x-ray source. Here we report progress in understanding the response function of the solid-state devices (SSDs). The response is modelled using JMKmod in the XSPEC package, and includes effects of pileup, incomplete charge collection, fluorescent escape, and other secondary processes. Knowledge of the SSD response function will permit precise removal of SSD detector effects from AXAF calibration data, and therefore allow accurate calibration of the AXAF system's effective area and other performance parameters.
Author Keywords: AXAF; Detector modelling; Detector response function; Solid state detectors

Authors: Futatsugi T., Nakajima A., Nakao H.

Abstract: A single-electron memory having a ultra-small floating gate on a narrow channel is studied theoretically and experimentally. This device is fabricated based on Si by using self-aligned process, and exhibits quantized threshold voltage shifts and hysteresis curves in the electrical characteristics at room temperature. These are basic operation of the single-electron memory. A novel method to form small metal dots is also developed. Sn nanocrystals are formed in thin, thermally grown SiO 2 layers by using low energy ion implantation followed by thermal annealing. Current-voltage characteristics of a diode in which Sn dots are embedded show a clear Coulomb gap and Coulomb staircases. These techniques are promising for making single-electron memories to be practical.

Authors: Dashevsky Z., Kaftori D., Rabinovich D.
Title: High efficiency thermoelectric unit within an autonomous solar energy converter
Source title: International Conference on Thermoelectrics, ICT, Proceedings
Affiliations: Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Dashevsky, Z., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel; Kaftori, D., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel; Rabinovich, D., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel
Abstract: A study is concerned with development of an autonomous power generation unit in the 5 to 10 kW range. Such an unit is intended to operate at isolated sites under remote control and to power various systems such as local radio transmitters, environmental measurement stations, or mobile telephone stations with 100% reliability. Our paper focuses on the conceptual design and the development of a high efficiency Direct Energy Converter of solar energy based on thermoelectric power generation. The converter consists of solar radiation concentrating optics, a thermal storage and a power thermoelectric unit. The thermoelectric unit is based on a new design and a novel multicrystal legs that are expected to enable a wider temperature difference with an efficiency of 10% (thermal to electric). This stage of work consists of crystal growth techniques with high crystalline perfection of thermoelectric materials and the development of two stage composite legs. The waste heat (.50 kW) from thermoelectric unit is used for space heating or the absorption refrigeration.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Solar energy; Solar energy converters; Thermoelectric energy conversion

Authors: Tsuyoshi A., Matsuura K., Okamoto H., Torigoe K., Yamamoto M., Tsutsumida K.
Title: Effective thermoelectric generation by use of heat stored in a thermal accumulator
Source title: International Conference on Thermoelectrics, ICT, Proceedings
Affiliations: Kobe City Coll of Technology, Kobe, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tsuyoshi, A., Kobe City Coll of Technology, Kobe, Japan; Matsuura, K., Kobe City Coll of Technology, Kobe, Japan; Okamoto, H., Kobe City Coll of Technology, Kobe, Japan; Torigoe, K., Kobe City Coll of Technology, Kobe, Japan; Yamamoto, M., Kobe City Coll of Technology, Kobe, Japan; Tsutsumida, K., Kobe City Coll of Technology, Kobe, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the present work about the thermoelectric generation by use of the limited mass of heat which is recovered from unused energy and stored in a thermal accumulator. When a thermoelectric generator is operated by using heat stored in a thermal accumulator, the temperature of heat source drops and causes decrease of generated power and conversion efficiency. In this case to obtain maximum electricity generated from the limited mass of heat the thermoelectric generator should be controlled as the conversion efficiency could be maximum by monitoring the temperature of the heat medium and the net power which is subtracted the pumping power required for circulation from the gross power. But it is difficult to measure conversion efficiency in transient condition. Thus in this paper a maximum net power tracking control of a thermoelectric generator is proposed and experimentally evaluated.
Index Keywords: Heat storage; Power control; Thermoelectric equipment; Thermoelectricity; Thermal accumulators; Thermoelectric generators; Thermoelectric energy conversion

Authors: Leifer J., Mickalonis J.I.
Title: Prediction of pitting corrosion in aqueous environments via Artificial Neural Network analysis
Source title: Intelligent Engineering Systems Through Artificial Neural Networks
Affiliations: University of South Carolina - Aiken, Dept. of Math. Sci. and Engineering, Aiken, SC 29801, United States; Westinghouse Savannah River Company, Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, SC 29808, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leifer, J., University of South Carolina - Aiken, Dept. of Math. Sci. and Engineering, Aiken, SC 29801, United States; Mickalonis, J.I., Westinghouse Savannah River Company, Savannah River Technology Center, Aiken, SC 29808, United States
Abstract: One mission of the Department of Energy's Savannah River Site (SRS) is to store spent nuclear fuel (SNF) and other waste products while permanent storage facilities for such materials are prepared. This extended storage increases the probability of pitting corrosion for both aluminum-based SNF stored in natural (fresh) waters, and in carbon steel waste tanks containing aqueous radioactive waste. The Back Propagation of Error method was used to train and test an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) model using archival pitting data. For aluminum, a database from the British Non-Ferrous Metals Research Association (BNFMRA) was used because it contained the relevant chemical species for pitting. A trained ANN, consisting of two hidden layers of six and four elements each, provided a good estimate of pit depth as a function of water chemistry after 150000 training cycles. For carbon steel, a set of "noisy" waste chemistry versus binary pitting state data generated at SRS was used to train and evaluate a feed-forward ANN model. The model contained two hidden layers of five and three elements each, and after 100000 training cycles, successfully predicted the correct pitting state for the carbon-steel tanks 69% of the time.
Index Keywords: Backpropagation; Carbon steel; Errors; Feedforward neural networks; Learning systems; Pitting; Spent fuels; Tanks (containers); Archival pitting data; Carbon steel waste tank; Neural networks

Abstract: During the summer of 1995, National Fuel, through a Department of Energy (DOE) sponsored project for storage deliverability enhancement, began a stimulation project on three wells in Galbraith Storage Field. The three wells were subjected to liquid carbon fracture stimulations. Preliminary well test analysis indicated that permeability in the field was greater than anticipated, and deliverability was being adversely affected by a large skin. Eighteen-month follow-up well testing showed good maintenance of deliverability at the two propped wells and an increase in the deliverability at the unpropped well. In July 1998, flow testing was conducted to evaluate third-year performance.
Index Keywords: Gas storage deliverability; Liquid carbon dioxide fracturing; Boreholes; Carbon dioxide; Gas fuel storage; Natural gas wells; Project management; Well stimulation; Hydraulic fracturing

Authors: Sathe Pushkaraj J., Parker Robert G.
Title: Free vibration and stability of a rotating disk-spindle system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Information Storage and Processing Division, ISPS
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Columbus, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sathe, Pushkaraj J., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, United States; Parker, Robert G., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, United States
Abstract: This work examines the free vibration and stability of a rotating flexible disk-spindle system. The extended operator formulation (Parker, 1997) is exploited to discretize the system using Galerkin's method. The coupled vibration modes of the system consist of disk modes, in which the disk dominates the system deformation, and spindle modes, in which the spindle dominates the system deformation. Both the natural frequencies and vibration modes are strongly affected by disk flexibility. If the membrane stresses associated with disk rotation are neglected then the system exhibits flutter instabilities, but these instabilities are not present when membrane stresses are included. Natural frequency veering between disk and spindle frequencies is prominent at low speeds and substantially affects the spectrum and stability. No veering is observed at high speeds where rotational stress stiffening diminishes disk-spindle coupling and causes the natural frequencies to converge to those of a rotating spindle carrying a rigid disk. Changes to the vibration modes are examined in terms of a strain energy ratio measuring the contribution of the disk strain energy to the total modal strain energy.
Index Keywords: Galerkin methods; Natural frequencies; Rotation; Stability; Strain measurement; Stresses; Vibrations (mechanical); Rotating disk spindle system; Strain energy ratio; Magnetic disk storage

Abstract: The effect of the time of preliminary storage at room temperature on the kinetics of HMDI trimerization at the fixed HMDI/ER ratio (85/25), and different concentrations of the catalyst, TEA, and the evolution of glass transition parameters of the end products in function of the curing reaction regime, were studied by calorimetry. It was established that both the activation energy Eα and the pre-exponential factor ln A increased, the longer the storage time, and both tended to decrease with the conversion α1 The time for the onset of gelation tgel decreased, the higher the catalyst concentration and/or the longer the preliminary storage time the former proved to be a major factor controlling tgel. The glass transition temperatures Tg for post-cured samples of series HT "internally diluted" with stiff oxazolidone heterocycles were systematically higher than those for samples of series LT cured at 393 K whatever the catalyst concentration and/or the storage time.

Abstract: The capacitive energy store of E7-25 type is intended for study of electrophysic processes with superheavy pulse currents and for energy supply of electrothermal and railgun launchers. Its designed energy is specified and the voltage is 25 kV. The store is tested with pulse current up to 10 MA and current integral up to 5·109 A2·s. Peculiarity of the store is its ability to form current pulse by the non-simultaneous triggering of its capacitors modules discharge.

Authors: Adibi Ali, Buse Karsten, Psaltis Demetri
Title: Hologram multiplexing using two-step recording
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adibi, Ali, California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States; Buse, Karsten, California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States; Psaltis, Demetri, California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: We present a comparison of different two-step holographic recording schemes based on their multiplexing performance using a unified framework. The difference between the different schemes is mainly due to the energy levels and sources of the traps. The influence of effective trap density and recording and sensitizing intensities are addressed. It is shown that for low light intensity operation, the performance of the doubly-doped crystals is superior due to the lack of dark depopulation of the shallow traps. Usage of such crystals also results in the suppression of the intensity threshold that exists for two-step recording in singly-doped crystals. The promising potentials for improvements in the two-step holographic recording in doubly-doped materials is also addressed.
Index Keywords: Benchmarking; Electron traps; Holograms; Multiplexing; Photorefractive materials; Semiconductor doping; Single crystals; Hologram multiplexing; Holographic storage system; Optical data storage

Abstract: Ultracapacitors, also known as super or double-layer capacitors, represent a new generation of electrochemical components for energy storage. In terms of energy density and speed of access to the energy stored, they occupy a position between large aluminum electrolytic capacitors and smaller rechargeable batteries.
Index Keywords: Double layer capacitors; Ultracapacitors; Capacitor storage; Electrolytic capacitors

Abstract: We present the concept of utilizing micro-electromechanical (MEM) energy storage for power conversion. A capacitor and inductor-free step-up converter based on mechanical resonance and silicon strain energy is introduced. In this circuit, a single MEM device is used to generate and supply high voltages, suitable for driving other MEM devices. A test converter using vertical polysilicon based resonators as energy storage elements is fabricated and tested, demonstrating the basic step-up function.

Abstract: A theory of bunch lengthening and energy spread increasing in electron storage rings is established by introducing the concept of collective random excitations. Analytical formulae are established to calculate the equilibrium bunch length and energy spread in the whole current range. Some experimental results are compared with those predicted by the theory and the results compare quite well. © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Abstract: One of the major concerns of gas suppliers and gas users is the safety of cylinders containing technical gases that are commonly used in industry as well as households. To reduce the risk of explosions, many suppliers do not fill the gas cylinders to their maximum capacity. It is therefore important for gas authorities, gas suppliers, and gas users to coordinate with one another to determine the best way to transport, store, and handle gas cylinders and to develop safety standards for gas cylinders.

Abstract: We report visible-laser ablation of a urethane-urea copolymer containing an azo dye. The ablated depth on the copolymer film was proportional to incident laser energy. The linearity of a depth/energy conversion on a nanometer scale was ensured at very low beam energy (∼ 2 J/cm2). Holographic grating formation was demonstrated as an example of application of this property. A sinusoidal grating with 40-nm amplitude was easily fabricated on the surface of the polymer film by introducing two coherent laser beams. The main mechanism of grating formation in the copolymer was not mass transport of copolymer chains due to pressure gradients but evaporation of the copolymer. Mass reduction associated with polymer evaporation was observed by means of the Quartz Crystal Microbalance (QCM) method. © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Nagpal Swati, Pathak Pankaj, Mona, Poonam, Bhatnagar P.K.
Title: Estimation of incubation time for Sb2Te3 used in optical memories
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ of Delhi South Campus, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Nagpal, Swati, Univ of Delhi South Campus, New Delhi, India; Pathak, Pankaj, Univ of Delhi South Campus, New Delhi, India; Mona, Univ of Delhi South Campus, New Delhi, India; Poonam, Univ of Delhi South Campus, New Delhi, India; Bhatnagar, P.K., Univ of Delhi South Campus, New Delhi, India
Abstract: Incubation time plays a very crucial role in deciding the erasure time in chalcogenide based phase change optical memory system. In the present work analytical results have been presented and exact value of incubation time have been estimated, so as to have an idea of whether the erasure time will be slow or fast. Experimental results of XRD on Sb2Te3 have been used for the theoretical estimation of incubation time (using Scherrer equation). It is also shown that interfacial strain energy (σ), the activation energy required for crystallization (Ea) and the change in Gibb's free energy (Δ Gc) are very important parameters to control the incubation time (τ). The incubation time calculated by the analytical expressions are explained by the grain boundary nucleation process only and not by grain comer or grain edge nucleation process.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Computational methods; Crystallization; Estimation; Gibbs free energy; Grain boundaries; Nucleation; Optical data storage; Strain; X ray diffraction analysis; Incubation time estimation; Semiconducting antimony compounds

Authors: Mu Fenghao, Svensson Christer
Title: Self-synchronized vector transfer for high speed parallel systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Internatoinal Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems - ICPADS
Affiliations: Linkoping Univ, Linkoping, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Mu, Fenghao, Linkoping Univ, Linkoping, Sweden; Svensson, Christer, Linkoping Univ, Linkoping, Sweden
Abstract: Communications between processing elements (PEs) in high speed parallel systems become a bottleneck as the function and speed of the PEs improve continuously. Clocked I/O ports in PEs may malfunction if data read failure occurs due to clock skew. To reduce the clock skew, global clock distribution utilized, however, it seems to be more difficult to use this for high speed parallel systems in the future. This paper addresses a self-tested self-synchronization (STSS) method for vector transfer between PEs. A test signal is added to remove the data read failure. This method has these features: 1) high data throughput; 2) low power consumption; 3) no constraints on clock skew and system scale; 4) flexibility in design; 5) less latency. A failure zone concept is used to characterize the behavior of storage elements. Using a jitter injected test signal, robust vector transfer between PEs with arbitrary clock phases is achieved without global synchronization.
Index Keywords: Congestion control (communication); Data communication systems; Energy utilization; Fault tolerant computer systems; Response time (computer systems); Robustness (control systems); Storage allocation (computer); Synchronization; Telecommunication traffic; Vectors; High speed parallel systems; Self-synchronized vector transfers; Parallel processing systems

Authors: Gilbert J.M., Abu Hassan A.H.
Title: Design and control of a multi-mode drive system
Source title: International Workshop on Advanced Motion Control, AMC
Affiliations: Univ of Hull, Hull, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gilbert, J.M., Univ of Hull, Hull, United Kingdom; Abu Hassan, A.H., Univ of Hull, Hull, United Kingdom
Abstract: A novel structure of drive system is presented which allows operation in a number of modes, which may be combined in various ways to give optimum performance for a given motion. The drive mode is controlled by a number of clutches and brakes and the drive also includes a spring which can be used to store energy under the control of the clutches. In one operating mode this spring is used to repeatedly transfer packets of energy from the input to the load in such a way that a variable speed ratio is achieved. In a second mode the spring is used to store energy extracted from the load at the end of one operation to be used at the beginning of a subsequent motion. Other modes allow precise position control and load braking. The paper describes the operating modes and control strategies and presents results for a prototype device.
Index Keywords: Electric brakes; Electric clutches; Energy storage; Multi-mode drive systems; Electric drives

Authors: Lang Tomas, Musoll Enric, Cortadella Jordi
Title: Extension of the working-zone-encoding method to reduce the energy on the microprocessor data bus
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Univ of California at Irvine, Irvine, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lang, Tomas, Univ of California at Irvine, Irvine, United States; Musoll, Enric, Univ of California at Irvine, Irvine, United States; Cortadella, Jordi, Univ of California at Irvine, Irvine, United States
Abstract: The energy at the I/O pins is a significant part of the overall consumption of a chip. To reduce this energy, this work extends to the data bus the Working Zone Encoding method, originally applied to encoding an external address bus. This method is based on the conjecture that programs favor a few working zones of their address space at each instant and that addresses to consecutive accesses for each zone frequently differ by a small amount. When the difference is small, instead of sending the whole address, the method sends an off-set with respect to the previous address to that zone, together with an identifier for the zone. In this paper the same idea is extended to the data bus. The approach has been applied to several SPEC95 streams of references to memory along with the corresponding data values in a system with multiplexed address and multiplexed instruction/data buses. Moreover, the effect of instruction and data caches is evaluated. Comparisons are given with previous methods for bus encoding, showing significant improvement in all cases except for the multiplexed address bus with instruction cache, where the best scheme depends on the overhead of the implementation.
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Codes (symbols); Data processing; Data transfer; Encoding (symbols); Input output programs; Address bus; Data bus; Working zone encoding method; Microprocessor chips

Authors: Dvornikov A.S., Cokgor I., Rentzepis P.M.
Title: Science and engineering of two photon 3D storage devices
Source title: IEEE Nonlinear Optics: Materials, Fundamentals and Applications - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of California, Irvine, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dvornikov, A.S., Univ of California, Irvine, United States; Cokgor, I., Univ of California, Irvine, United States; Rentzepis, P.M., Univ of California, Irvine, United States
Abstract: A high-density fast read-out 3D optical storage memory is developed which relies on the nonlinear absorption of two photons that causes changes in the structure and spectra of the excited molecule. The two states of the binary code, 0 and 1 are formed by the photo-chemical changes which lead to two distinct structures of the molecular species used as the storage medium. The stored information is read by illuminating the written bits with either one photon of the energy necessary to induce fluorescence or by simply intersecting two optical beams at that point. This optical storage memory has the capability of dynamic parallel-access needed to accommodate the demands of today's technologies.
Index Keywords: Binary codes; Data transfer; Electric excitation; Light absorption; Optical data storage; Photons; Two photon three-dimensional storage devices; Nonlinear optics

Authors: Stroud Jr. C.R.
Title: Information storage and retrieval from a single atom
Source title: IEEE Nonlinear Optics: Materials, Fundamentals and Applications - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of Rochester, Rochester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stroud Jr., C.R., Univ of Rochester, Rochester, United States
Abstract: When the volume of the atom becomes extremely large at high Rydberg levels, there is a corresponding increase in the state space of the atom. If measurements are made on an entire ensemble of atoms similarly prepared, then the information storage capacity is much larger. While the information is stored in the atom, unitary transformations can be carried out on the state of the atom allowing the possibility of quantum computing within this single atom. The potentiality of this scheme and its strengths and weaknesses in comparisons with other schemes for quantum computing are discussed.
Index Keywords: Atomic physics; Electron energy levels; Quantum theory; Shot noise; Rydberg levels; Nonlinear optics

Authors: Harata Iko, Takagi Sakae, Wakabayashi Isao, Sakai Motohiro, Tetuka Hirofusa, Toshou Tuyoshi
Title: Development of the storage tank water heater by thermoelectric technology
Source title: International Conference on Thermoelectrics, ICT, Proceedings
Affiliations: Tohoku Electric Power Co, Inc, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Harata, Iko, Tohoku Electric Power Co, Inc, Sendai, Japan; Takagi, Sakae, Tohoku Electric Power Co, Inc, Sendai, Japan; Wakabayashi, Isao, Tohoku Electric Power Co, Inc, Sendai, Japan; Sakai, Motohiro, Tohoku Electric Power Co, Inc, Sendai, Japan; Tetuka, Hirofusa, Tohoku Electric Power Co, Inc, Sendai, Japan; Toshou, Tuyoshi, Tohoku Electric Power Co, Inc, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: The reduction in energy consumed by the storage tank water heater through conventional resistance heating had a limit. Therefore, we used thermoelectric technology. The thermoelectric technology which changes electric energy into the heat energy is commonly known to be used as the heat pump. In this thermoelectric technology, we used a heat pump which utilizes the latent heat of the atmosphere. The other characteristic was to collect the heat which occurs from the power supply equipment of the thermoelectric technology device in effect a CHP (Combined Heat and Power) device. In this thermoelectric technology, an improvement of the energy efficiency can be expected. Initially we examined for a basis a bench scale model. As for the examination condition, the capacity of the tank was 3.7 liters, the temperature of hot water was 85 °C, the environment temperature was 23 °C and the efficiency of the power supply was 80%. On inspection of the results the new thermoelectric technology performed with a greater efficiency than the resistance heated storage tank heater. That is with the thermoelectric technology storage tank water heaters about a 13% reduction in energy consumption was achieved. In 1998, we will further develop the thermoelectric technology storage tank water heater on a full scale rig.
Index Keywords: Energy efficiency; Heat pump systems; Water heaters; Combined heat and power (CHP) devices; Storage tank water heaters; Thermoelectric energy conversion

Authors: Nikitin E., Zubov L.M.
Title: Conservation laws and conjugate solutions in the elasticity of simple materials and materials with couple stress
Affiliations: Program in Mechanics, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08855-0909, United States; Dept. of Mechanics and Mathematics, Rostov State University, Rostov-on-Don 344711, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Nikitin, E., Program in Mechanics, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08855-0909, United States; Zubov, L.M., Dept. of Mechanics and Mathematics, Rostov State University, Rostov-on-Don 344711, Russian Federation
Abstract: The stored energy functional of a homogeneous isotropic elastic body is invariant with respect to translation and rotation of a reference configuration. One can use Noether's Theorem to derive the conservation laws corresponding to these invariant transformations. These conservation laws provide an alternative way of formulating the system of equations governing equilibrium of a homogeneous isotropic body. The resulting system is mathematically identical to the system of equilibrium equations and constitutive relations, generally, of another material. This implies that each solution of the system of equilibrium equations gives rise to another solution, which describes the reciprocal deformation and solves the system of equilibrium equations of another material. In this paper we derive conservation laws and prove the theorem on conjugate solutions for two models of elastic homogeneous isotropic bodies - the model of a simple material and the model of a material with couple stress (Cosserat continuum).
Author Keywords: Conservation laws; Cosserat continuum; Noether's Theorem
Index Keywords: Continuum mechanics; Degrees of freedom (mechanics); Differential equations; Elasticity; Integral equations; Mathematical models; Mathematical transformations; Rotation; Stresses; Tensors; Theorem proving; Energy conservation; Energy storage; Stress analysis; Conservation laws; Cosserat continuum; Elastic materials; Noether's theorem; Conjugate solution; Conservation law; Couple stress; Noether theorem; Materials science; Elasticity

Authors: Musoll E., Lang T., Cortadella J.
Title: Working-zone encoding for reducing the energy in microprocessor address buses
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
Affiliations: Cyrix (National Semiconductor Corp.), Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697, United States; Department of Software, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, Barcelona 08071, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Musoll, E., Cyrix (National Semiconductor Corp.), Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Lang, T., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697, United States; Cortadella, J., Department of Software, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, Barcelona 08071, Spain
Abstract: The energy consumption due to input-output pins is a substantial part of the overall chip consumption. To reduce this energy, this work presents the working-zone encoding (WZE) method for encoding an external address bus, based on the conjecture that programs favor a few working zones of their address space at each instant. In such cases, the method identifies these zones and sends through the bus only the offset of this reference with respect to the previous reference to that zone, along with an identifier of the current working zone. This is combined with a one-hot encoding for the offset. Several improvements to this basic strategy are also described. The approach has been applied to several address streams, broken down into instruction-only, data-only, and instruction-data traces, to evaluate the effect on separate and shared address buses. Moreover, the effect of instruction and data caches is evaluated. For the case without caches, the proposed scheme is specially beneficial for data-address and shared buses, which are the cases where other codings are less effective. On the other hand, for the case with caches the best scheme for the instruction-only and data-only traces is the WZE, whereas for the instruction-data traces it is either the WZE or the bus-invert with four groups (depending on the energy overhead of these techniques). © 1998 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Address bus; Encoding for low power; Input-output energy; Low-power; Microprocessor
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Energy utilization; Signal encoding; Working-zone encoding; Microprocessor chips

Authors: Krishna Vamsi, Ranganathan N., Vijaykrishnan N.
Title: Energy efficient scheduling scheme for signal processing applications
Source title: Conference Record of the Asilomar Conference on Signals, Systems and Computers
Affiliations: Univ of South Florida, Tampa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krishna, Vamsi, Univ of South Florida, Tampa, United States; Ranganathan, N., Univ of South Florida, Tampa, United States; Vijaykrishnan, N., Univ of South Florida, Tampa, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we propose a time constrained energy efficient scheduling technique for signal processing applications. Specifically, we propose a scheduling algorithm, (DFMVS), which utilizes the concept of Dynamic Frequency Clocking and Multiple Voltage Scaling. In the dynamic frequency scheme, all units are driven by a single clock line which changes at run time depending on the functional unit active at that time. This feature of dynamic frequency clocking gives enough slack for multiples voltages to be used for energy minimization. DFMVS has been applied to some DSP benchmarks and the results show an average reduction of 31.6% in energy dissipated as compared to using a uni-frequency clocking scheme with a single supply voltage.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Digital signal processing; Dynamic frequency clocking and multiple voltage scaling (DFCMVS); Storage allocation (computer)

Authors: Garren A.A., Green M.A.
Title: Alternative lattice design for a compact light source ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garren, A.A., Univ of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, United States; Green, M.A., Univ of California, Los Angeles, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: A 26 meter circumference 1.5 GeV electron storage ring, designed to deliver x-rays with a critical energy of 10.4 keV, and has been proposed for the UCLA campus. This ring has twelve 6.9 T superconducting dipoles grouped in pairs. Each pair bends the beam sixty degrees. The quadropoles and sextupoles are conventional. The alternative ring design presented in this report would have twelve separate 6.9 T superconducting dipoles that bend the beam thirty degrees each. Although this ring would have a larger circumference (about 36 meters) and more focusing elements, it would have a smaller emittance and consequently it would be a brighter source of x rays. As with the smaller ring, the focusing elements would be conventional. The x-ray power from the alternative ring delivered to the users is expected to be much higher than from the smaller ring.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electron ring accelerators; Light sources; Magnetic lenses; Superconducting magnets; X rays; Superconducting dipoles; Storage rings

Authors: Hettel R., Boyce R., Brennan S., Corbett J., Cornacchia M., Davies-White W., Garren A., Hofmann A., Limborg C., Nosochkov Y., Nuhn H.-D., Rabedeau T., Safranek J., Wiedemann H.
Title: SPEAR III - a brighter source at SSRL
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hettel, R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Boyce, R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Brennan, S., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Corbett, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Cornacchia, M., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Davies-White, W., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Garren, A., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Hofmann, A., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Limborg, C., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Nosochkov, Y., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Nuhn, H.-D., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Rabedeau, T., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Safranek, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Wiedemann, H., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: By replacing the magnets and vacuum chamber for the 3 GeV SPEAR II storage ring, the natural emittance of the machine can be reduced from 130 to 18 nm-rad and the stored current can be raised from 100 to 200 mA with a 50 h lifetime. This configuration increases focused photon flux for insertion device beamlines by an order of magnitude and the photon brightness for future undulators would exceed 1018 at 5 keV. Due to a higher critical energy, the photon flux in the 20 keV range for bending magnet beamlines increases by more than two orders of magnitude. We present preliminary SPEAR III design study results and plans to implement the facility upgrade with minimal downtime for SSRL users.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Particle beam dynamics; Photons; Insertion devices; Storage rings

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron LNLS, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Farias, R.H.A., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron LNLS, Campinas, Brazil; Jahnel, L.C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron LNLS, Campinas, Brazil; Lin, Liu, Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron LNLS, Campinas, Brazil; Rodrigues, A.R.D., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron LNLS, Campinas, Brazil; Tavares, P.F., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron LNLS, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: The 1.37 GeV LNLS UVX electron storage ring has a 120 MeV injector LINAC. Once stored, the electron beam must be ramped up to the nominal operation energy. In order to minimize current loss, orbit and tune corrections have been implemented along the energy ramp. In this report, we present a description of the energy ramping process, performance, orbit and tune corrections.
Index Keywords: Energy dissipation; Particle beam injection; Synchrotrons; Energy ramping; Storage rings

Authors: Kurita Nadine R., Kulikov Artem, Nordby Martin, Corlett John
Title: Final design and manufacturing of the PEP-II High Energy Ring Arc bellows module
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States

Abstract: An update on the Arc bellows module for the PEP-II High Energy Ring is presented. Final design, manufacturing issues, material and coating selection, and tribological and RF testing are discussed. Performance and operational requirements are also reviewed. The RF shield design has been proven during assembly to allow for large manufacturing tolerances without reducing the mechanical spring force below required values. In addition, the RF shield maintains electrical contact even with large misalignments across the module.

Authors: Keller R.
Title: Tune-split effects at the ALS storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keller, R., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: This paper is concerned with operational characteristics of the Advanced Light Source (ALS) storage ring, a synchrotron light source of the third generation that is capable of operating between 1.0 and 1.9 GeV beam energy. Even though the magnetic properties of its lattice magnets appeared to be very well understood an anomaly was observed with the measured betatron tunes when the working point of any of the three quadrupole families or the bend magnets was switched from the upper to the lower hysteresis branch. In no case was it then possible to recover the standard horizontal and vertical tune values simultaneously at any given excitation current; either one was considerably off normal when the other one was set to the proper value. The nature of this so-called `tune-split effect' was investigated, and the solution to the problem is presented here, together with an outlook on consequences for operational scenarios resulting from this effect.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Elementary particle sources; Light sources; Magnetic field effects; Magnetic hysteresis; Magnetic properties; Particle beams; Synchrotrons; Advanced light source (ALS) storage rings; Tune split effects; Storage rings

Authors: Grobner O.
Title: LHC vacuum system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Grobner, O., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, involves two proton storage rings with colliding beams of 7 TeV. The machine will be housed in the existing LEP tunnel and requires 16 m long superconducting bending magnets. The vacuum chamber will be the inner wall of the cryostat and hence at the temperature of the magnet cold bore, i.e. at 1.9 K and therefore a very good cryopump. To reduce the cryogenic power consumption, the heat load from synchrotron radiation and from the image currents in the vacuum chamber will be absorbed on a `beam screen', which operates between 5 and 20 K, inserted in the magnet cold bore. The design pressure necessary for operation must provide a lifetime of several days and a further stringent requirement comes from the power deposition in the superconducting magnet coils due to protons scattered on the residual gas which could lead to a magnet quench. Cryopumping of gas on the cold surfaces provides the necessary low gas densities but it must be ensured that the vapour pressure of cryosorbed molecules, of which H2 and He would be the most critical species, remains within acceptable limits. In the room temperature sections of the LHC, specifically in the experiments, the vacuum must be stable against ion induced desorption and ISR-type `pressure bumps'.
Index Keywords: Cryostats; Energy utilization; Helium; Hydrogen; Protons; Storage rings; Superconducting magnets; Synchrotron radiation; Thermal load; Vacuum pumps; Vacuum technology; Vapor pressure; Cryopumps; Large hadron collider (LHC); Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Belochitskii P., Carli C., Eriksson T., Giannini R., Maury S., Mohl D., Pedersen F.
Title: Beam optics issues for the antiproton decelerator
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Belochitskii, P., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Carli, C., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Eriksson, T., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Giannini, R., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Maury, S., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Mohl, D., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation; Pedersen, F., JINR, Dubna, Russian Federation
Abstract: The deceleration of the beam down to 0.1 GeV/c in the ring previously used as Antiproton Collector (AC) at 3.5 GeV/c, requires a number of modifications to the lattice. The insertion of the electron cooling, needed to cool the antiproton beam at low energy, implies the re-arrangement of quadrupoles. The optical functions then need to be readjusted in order to keep the large acceptance and to cope with the electron and stochastic cooling environment. Calculations of the linear optics and of the acceptance are reported. Tests of beam deceleration in the AC show the need for closed-orbit correction at low momentum in addition to the static correction by the movement of the quadrupoles available in the present configuration. The deceleration tests will be discussed and a correction system, which includes trim supplies on the main bending magnets, will be described.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Functions; Particle beam dynamics; Particle optics; Antiproton decelerators; Electron cooling; Particle beam cooling; Particle beam deceleration; Storage rings

Authors: Blum E.B., Lynch D.R., Mortazavi P., Singh O.V., Thomlinson W., Woodle M.H., Broadbent A.J., Coates M.C., Milward S.R., Moor E.J.F., Smith K.D.
Title: Superconducting wiggler magnet for the NSLS X-ray ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blum, E.B., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Lynch, D.R., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Mortazavi, P., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Singh, O.V., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Thomlinson, W., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Woodle, M.H., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Broadbent, A.J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Coates, M.C., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Milward, S.R., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Moor, E.J.F., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Smith, K.D., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: The superconducting 5 pole, 5 Tesla wiggler which has been operating in the X-17 straight section of the x-ray storage ring at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS) since 1989 will soon be replaced by a new wiggler being built by Oxford Instruments with lower operating costs, higher reliability, and greater performance. The new wiggler has three modes of operation: the full wiggler with 11 poles producing 3.0 T, the partial wiggler with 5 poles at 4.7 T, and the wavelength shifter with a single pole producing 5.5 T. The full wiggler, optimized for the digital subtraction radiography program, will produce the same x-ray flux at the 33 KeV iodine K-edge as the existing wiggler operating at 4.7 T but will reduce the higher energy harmonics delivered to the target. The partial wiggler will deliver the same flux for solid state physics experiments as the existing wiggler, and the wavelength shifter will provide an elliptically polarized x-ray beam that is not now available.

Authors: Hiraiwa A., Ogasawara M., Natsuaki N., Itoh Y., Iwai H.
Title: Local-field-enhancement model of DRAM retention failure
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting

Abstract: We have developed the local-field-enhancement model of the tail component of DRAM (dynamic random access memory) retention-time distribution. The model is in excellent agreement with experiments and proposes to control not the number but the energy-level distribution of traps and to reduce the space-charge-region-field variation together with the field itself to increase the retention time.

Authors: Hofmann Heath, Sanders Seth R.
Title: Optimal efficiency controller for synchronous reluctance flywheel drive
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hofmann, Heath, Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Sanders, Seth R., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: This paper presents an approach to achieve optimal efficiency over a range of power and rotational speed for a synchronous reluctance motor/alternator drive, to be used in a flywheel energy storage system. Synchronous reluctance machines have distinct advantages over permanent magnet machines in flywheel applications with respect to cost and reliability. A stator-flux-oriented torque control scheme is used to control the motor/alternator. For a given speed and torque, power losses in the machine are a function of only the stator flux magnitude. The optimal flux value can then be found using a one-dimensional optimization algorithm, such as the Method of Sequential Quadratic Interpolations. Optimal flux values for the machine are determined using an experimental setup that accurately determines losses in the motor/drive system. This work is part of a broader project at the University of California at Berkeley to develop flywheel energy storage systems. In particular, high-speed synchronous reluctance machines have been designed and built for flywheel applications. Experimental results obtained from the test setup show the validity of the controller and the optimization algorithm.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Flywheels; Optimal control systems; Optimization; Permanent magnets; Reluctance motors; Stators; Synchronous generators; Torque control; Optimal efficiency; Electric drives

Title: Experimental investigation of the dielectric strength of the H011 and E111 oscillation modes in a cylindrical resonator using compressed gas

Authors with affiliations: Avgustinovich, V.A., Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, Tomsk Polytechnical University, 634050 Tomsk, Russian Federation; Artemenko, S.N., Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, Tomsk Polytechnical University, 634050 Tomsk, Russian Federation; Chumerin, P.Yu., Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, Tomsk Polytechnical University, 634050 Tomsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: It is shown experimentally that in order to increase the stored energy in storage resonators using compressed gas, it is preferable to have oscillation modes in which the electrical components of the fields do not interact with the inner surfaces of the resonator. © 1998 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Polyak Lisa M., Alden Sue A., Riffe Thomas B.
Title: Military services convert from JP-4 to JP-8: a pollution prevention story
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Affiliations: Ambient Air Quality Management, Program, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States
Authors with affiliations: Polyak, Lisa M., Ambient Air Quality Management, Program, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States; Alden, Sue A., Ambient Air Quality Management, Program, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States; Riffe, Thomas B., Ambient Air Quality Management, Program, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States
Abstract: An attempt is made to model and quantify the change in volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions associated with the conversion from JP-4 to JP-8 at 1,880 fuel storage tanks throughout the United States. Annual field throughputs for FY92 through FY97 are examined in four composite models which reflect the JP-4 and JP-8 fuel tank inventory for the Army, Navy, Air Force and Defense Logistics Agency (DLA). Volatile organic compound emissions are calculated using the TANKS3 program.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Aircraft fuels; Computer simulation; Energy conversion; Gas emissions; Logistics; Volatile organic compounds; Military services; Pollution prevention benefits; Air pollution control

Authors: Chiradeja Pathomthat, Ramakumar Rama
Title: Review of distributed generation and storage
Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chiradeja, Pathomthat, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States; Ramakumar, Rama, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States
Abstract: The impending deregulated environment facing the electric utilities in the twenty first century is both a challenge and an opportunity for a variety of technologies and operating scenarios. The need to provide acceptable power quality and reliability will create a very favorable climate for the entry of distributed resources and innovative operating practices. Distributed resources (DR) is a term that encompasses both distributed generation (DG) and distributed energy storage (DS). A distributed utility (DU) will use both distributed resources and load management to achieve its goals. With a multitude of technologies available for both DG and DS, several issues need consideration to match technologies and needs. This paper presents a brief review of some of the major technologies proposed for DG and DS and discusses their suitability, barriers to their introduction, and potential problem areas in the technical, economic, institutional, environmental, and policy aspects.
Index Keywords: Deregulation; Electric energy storage; Electric load management; Electric power generation; Energy policy; Environmental impact; Environmental protection; Industrial economics; Resource allocation; Distributed power generation; Distributed power storage; Electric utilities

Authors: Bosser J., Broere J., Carli C., Chanel M., Hill C., Ley R., Lombardi A., Maccaferri R., Maury S., Mohl D., Molinari G., Mulder H., Tanke E., Tranquille G., Vretenar M.
Title: Recent lead ion storage tests on LEAR
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Bosser, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Broere, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Carli, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Chanel, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Hill, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Ley, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lombardi, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Maccaferri, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Maury, S., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mohl, D., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Molinari, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mulder, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Tanke, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Tranquille, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Vretenar, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: With the completion of the antiproton physics program, the Low Energy Antiproton Ring (LEAR) can be used as an accumulator ring for heavy ions in the large hadron collider injector chain. The proposed scheme for the injection of lead ions is presented, where an intensity gain of 125 is obtained by accumulating lead ions with electron cooling in the LEAR. With the linac cycling at 10 Hz and cooling times faster than 100 ms, 20 pulses can be accumulated in 2 s before transfer to the PS, the next machine in the chain.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Heavy ions; Linear accelerators; Particle beam injection; Low energy antiproton rings (LEAR); Storage rings

Authors: Luo Gwo-Huei, Lin Glory, Kuo C.C., Chiang John, Hsu Y.J., Lee D.H., Sah R.C., Hsu Ian C.
Title: Analyzing the relationship between the beam life time and average gas pressure
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Luo, Gwo-Huei, Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lin, Glory, Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Kuo, C.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chiang, John, Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hsu, Y.J., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lee, D.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Sah, R.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hsu, Ian C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: For a low-energy third-generation synchrotron storage ring like Taiwan Light Source (TLS), the beam life time is a critical issue to determine the future expansion and design criterion of the insertion devices. The beam life time also affects the routine operation of the beam energy, from 1.3 GeV to 1.5 GeV has been successfully operated, which could increase the beam life time. There were various ways and experiments that have been carried out at TLS to investigate dominating factors of the beam lifetime. The dominating factor of beam life time was intra-beam scattering at 1.3 GeV. From various operation experiences of 1.5 GeV, the dominating factor of overall beam life time is changing. A simple algorithm is setup to interpret the relation between residual gas pressure and beam lifetime using archived data during 1.5 GeV normal operation.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Light sources; Particle beams; Synchrotron radiation; Insertion devices; Intrabeam scattering; Storage rings

Authors: Choi J., Lee T., Kwon M., Huang J.Y., Nam S.H., Yoon M., Cho M.H., Ko I.S., Namkung W.
Title: Operational status of Pohang light source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Choi, J., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Lee, T., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Kwon, M., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Huang, J.Y., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Nam, S.H., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Yoon, M., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Cho, M.H., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Ko, I.S., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Namkung, W., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea
Abstract: The PLS, a 2-GeV dedicated electron synchrotron light source, has been in normal operation mode for users since September 1995. It consists of 2-GeV electron linear accelerator, which works as a full energy injector, and a storage ring. The linac is 150-m long and has 42 accelerating sections. The storage ring has a 12-cell TBA type lattice with 4 rf cavities. The construction of PLS was started in 1988, and the installation was completed in August 1994. From then until December 24, 1994, which we call the first commissioning phase, we succeeded in stacking the 2-GeV electrons up to 300-mA in the storage ring. After baking out the vacuum chamber, the second commissioning was performed from April to July 1995. In 1996, the user beam time reaches about 2,800 hours among 4,800 hours of the accelerator operation time. We present the current operational status of PLS in this paper.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Light sources; Linear accelerators; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Vacuum technology; Vacuum chamber; Particle optics

Authors: Arduini G., Bruning O., Cavallari G., Gayet P., Geschonke G., Habel E., Hofmann A., Jimenez M., Meincke O., Morpurgo G., Roy G., Schmickler H., Uythoven J., Wagner A., Zotter B.
Title: Parasitic energy loss in the LEP superconducting cavities
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Arduini, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Bruning, O., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Cavallari, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Gayet, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Geschonke, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Habel, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Hofmann, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Jimenez, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Meincke, O., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Morpurgo, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Roy, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Schmickler, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Uythoven, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Wagner, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Zotter, B., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The energy loss of bunches in the LEP superconducting (SC) cavities has been determined by measuring the closed orbit as a function of current with the beam position monitors located at finite dispersion. This method has already been used in earlier experiments to determine the distribution of the longitudinal impedance of different parts of LEP. In the present experiment the energy loss in two straight sections, containing only SC cavities, was compared with that in sections having both copper cavities and SC cavities. The results confirm the impedance calculations for the two types of cavities. The accuracy of the measurements was considerably improved by determining simultaneously the orbits of bunches with different currents. At the same time with these beam-based impedance measurements, the power dissipation was observed directly by local temperature monitors in different elements: the inter-cavity bellows inside the cryostat, the warm intermodule bellows, and Ferrite absorbers which were installed in two places to reduce the energy leaking out of cavities. These observations were correlated with the change of cryogenics power consumption, and showed an unexpected dependence of energy loss on beam energy.
Index Keywords: Cryostats; Electric impedance measurement; Electric losses; Ferrite devices; Superconducting devices; Superconducting cavities; Storage rings

Authors: Lau W.K., Chang L.H., Chang S.S., Ho C.H., Lin M.C., Lin S.J., Luo G.H., Yang T.T., Yeh M.S., Wang Ch., Kuo C.C.
Title: Upgrade issues of the TLS storage ring rf system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lau, W.K., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chang, L.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chang, S.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Ho, C.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lin, M.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lin, S.J., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Luo, G.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Yang, T.T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Yeh, M.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Wang, Ch., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Kuo, C.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: To achieve the goals in the TLS storage ring performance upgrade plan, the necessity of adding the third rf station to the storage ring for radiation loss compensation at 1.5 GeV/350 mA operation and lifetime improvement are analyzed. We estimated the rf power required to compensate the radiation losses by bending magnets and various insertion devices. Effects of the proposed passive Landau cavity on power consumption is also studied.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Energy dissipation; Synchrotron radiation; Landau cavity; Radiofrequency system; Storage rings

Authors: Kwon M., Park H.J., Yu I.H., Huang J.Y., Ko I.S.
Title: Operational characteristics of RF system affecting PLS beam stability
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kwon, M., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Park, H.J., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Yu, I.H., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Huang, J.Y., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea; Ko, I.S., POSTECH, Pohang, South Korea
Abstract: The fourth RF station was installed to the Pohang Light Source (PLS), whereas its station consists of a 60 kW klystron amplifier and a nose cone type cavity connected by a coaxial transmission line. Total 240 kW RF power is available for storing electrons up to 400-mA at 2-GeV and 200-mA at 2.5-GeV of beam energy. During the normal operation, some dangerous higher order modes (HOMs) induced by cavities have been identified. Making an effort to suppress instabilities caused by HOMs has been started by enhancing the capability of cavity cooling temperature control and adding the transverse and longitudinal feedback systems. Besides these efforts, characterizations of the beam loss transient due to RF have been underway. A modulation experiment of the accelerating voltage is also planned using the fourth cavity. We present performance test results with newly installed low level system.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Feedback amplifiers; Klystrons; Particle beam dynamics; Particle beam stability; Storage rings

Authors: Kageyama T., Akai K., Akasaka N., Ezura E., Mizuno H., Naito F., Nakanishi H., Sakai H., Takeuchi Y., Yamazaki Y., Kobayashi T.
Title: Development of high-power ARES cavities
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kageyama, T., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Akai, K., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Akasaka, N., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Ezura, E., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Mizuno, H., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Naito, F., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Nakanishi, H., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Sakai, H., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Takeuchi, Y., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Yamazaki, Y., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Kobayashi, T., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The ARES (Accelerator Resonantly coupled with Energy Storage) structure is a three-cavity system operated in the π/2 mode, where a HOM-damped accelerating cavity is coupled with an energy storage cavity via a coupling cavity equipped with a coaxial antenna damper to reduce the impedances of the parasitic 0 and π modes. Two high-power prototypes with different HOM-damping schemes have been developed, where one is with a quadrupole counter-mixing (QCM) choke structure and the other with grooved beam pipe one. Both prototypes have been tested with an electron beam of about 500 mA in the TRISTAN accumulation ring (AR). This paper reports their RF structures together with some results of the high-power and high-current beam tests.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Cavity resonators; Damping; Electric impedance; Electron beams; Particle beam dynamics; Accelerator cavities; Accumulation rings; Quadrupole counter mixing (QCM); Storage rings

Authors: Laclare J.-L., Level M.-P., Bosland P., Brunelle P., Chaput R., Chel S., Corlier M., Flynn G., Juillard M., Hanus X., Herbeaux C., Loulergue A., Marlats J.-L., Mosnier A., Nadji A.
Title: Status of the SOLEIL project
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France
Authors with affiliations: Laclare, J.-L., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Level, M.-P., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Bosland, P., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Brunelle, P., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Chaput, R., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Chel, S., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Corlier, M., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Flynn, G., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Juillard, M., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Hanus, X., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Herbeaux, C., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Loulergue, A., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Marlats, J.-L., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Mosnier, A., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France; Nadji, A., Projet SOLEIL, Gif sur Yvette, France
Abstract: With the goal to be prepared for a start of construction in January 99, the SOLEIL project was recently reviewed. The main characteristics have been confirmed while some options have been revised. The preinjector is now a 100 MeV electron linac installed together with the Booster inside the storage ring. The storage ring energy is increased to 2.5 GeV in order to meet the new user's requirements on the brilliance (B>1018) around 10 keV. Optics were reoptimized with an emphasis on the energy acceptance so as to obtain large Touschek lifetime. New designs of vacuum chamber and magnetic elements are in progress and a new type of superconducting cavity with heavily damped HOM's at 353 MHz is being prototyped.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Electron energy levels; Particle injectors; Storage rings; Superconducting devices; Vacuum technology; Touschek lifetime; Linear accelerators

Authors: Rubin D., Dugan G., Mikhailichenko A., Rogers J.
Title: Dual aperture high luminosity collider at Cornell
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rubin, D., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Dugan, G., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Mikhailichenko, A., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Rogers, J., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: We describe a very high luminosity electron-positron collider that operates in the Υ4s energy range. Trajectories intersect with a small horizontal crossing angle so that closely spaced bunches collide only at the interaction point. An electrostatic deflector steers the counter-rotating beams into side-by-side vacuum chambers that share a common dipole guide field. The beams also share superconducting RF accelerating cavities. Independent focusing and chromaticity correction is provided by dual aperture superconducting quadrupoles and sextupoles. The machine is installed above the synchrotron injector in the CESR tunnel. The existing storage ring can remain for service as an accumulator or dedicated synchrotron light source. With 3A/beam in 180 bunches, βv* = 7 mm, beam-beam tune shift parameter ξ = 0.06 and beam energy of 5.3 GeV, we anticipate luminosity of 3×1034 cm-2 s-1.
Index Keywords: Electrostatic accelerators; Focusing; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Dual aperture high luminosity colliders; Electrostatic particle deflectors; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Yang B.X., Lumpkin A.H., Borland M., Harkay K., Nassiri A.
Title: Characterization of beam dynamics in the APS injector rings using time-resolved imaging techniques
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yang, B.X., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Lumpkin, A.H., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Borland, M., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Harkay, K., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Nassiri, A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: Images taken with streak cameras and gated intensified cameras with both time (longitudinal) and spatial (transverse) resolution reveal a wealth of information about circular accelerators. We illustrate a novel technique by a sequence of dual-sweep streak camera images taken at a high dispersion location in the booster synchrotron, where the horizontal coordinate is strongly correlated with the particle energy and the `top-view' of the beam gives a good approximation to the particle density distribution in the longitudinal phase space. A sequence of top-view images taken right after injection clearly shows the beam dynamics in the phase space. We report another example from the positron accumulator ring for the characterization of its beam compression bunching with the 12th harmonic rf.
Index Keywords: Imaging techniques; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Streak cameras; Synchrotron radiation; Advanced Photon Source (APS); Positron accumulator ring; Time-resolved imaging techniques; Particle beam dynamics

Authors: Jacobs K., Bradley S., Carter A., McAllister B., Sibley C., Wang F.
Title: Real time dispersion measurements at the MIT Bates Linac
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jacobs, K., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Bradley, S., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Carter, A., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; McAllister, B., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Sibley, C., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Wang, F., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States
Abstract: The MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Center comprises a 1 GeV electron linac/recirculator system, beam lines to two main experimental halls, and a pulse stretcher/storage ring. Proper tuning of the beam requires the transverse dispersion to be zero, or some specified non-zero value, at all locations along the beam lines. Dispersion measurements are made by correlating beam positions measured by BPMs, with energy measurements made using a BPM in a region of known non-zero dispersion. Data are acquired continuously from the BPMs and displayed on a graphical user interface in real time. This allows the accelerator operators to set dispersion quadrupoles and sextupoles so that the first and second order position and angle dispersions have their correct values at all points along the beam line. Details of the system design and operation are presented.
Index Keywords: Beam position monitors (BPM); Electric power measurement; Graphical user interfaces; Particle beams; Position measurement; Storage rings; Tuning; Linear accelerators

Authors: Bizek Hana M.
Title: Extended Touschek lifetime
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bizek, Hana M., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: Scattering of particles within the bunch is called Touschek scattering particles. If large enough, such an energy transfer may eject the particle out of the bunch. If a particle is scattered in the dispersive region, it will induce a horizontal betatron oscillation which will be coupled into vertical motion when it passes through skew components. The amount of coupling is expressed in terms of the coupling coefficient, χ. If the coupling coefficient is large enough, the resulting vertical oscillations may exceed the normally small vertical admittance of the ring. Thus the particles may be lost even though the energy loss is within the momentum acceptance. The lifetime associated with this loss mechanism is called the extended Touschek lifetime. In the usual Touschek lifetime calculation, the lifetime increases as the coupling increases. Including the effect of the vertical oscillation results in a decrease of Touschek lifetime beyond some coupling value.
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Energy dissipation; Energy transfer; Mathematical models; Oscillations; Storage rings; Coupling coefficient; Touschek lifetime; Touschek scattering; Particle beam dynamics
