Authors: Kirbie H., Hickman B., Lee B., Ollis C., Brooksby C., Saethre R.
Title: All solid state pulse power source for high PRF induction accelerators
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Univ of California, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirbie, H., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Hickman, B., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Lee, B., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Ollis, C., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Brooksby, C., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Saethre, R., Univ of California, Livermore, United States
Abstract: Researchers at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) are developing a flexible, all solid-state pulsed power source that will enable an induction accelerator to produce multikiloampere electron beams at a maximum pulse repetition frequency (prf) of 2 MHz. The prototype source consists of three, 15-kV, 4.8-kA solid-state modulators stacked in an induction adder configuration. Each modulator contains over 1300 field-effect transistors (FETs) that quickly connect and disconnect four banks of energy storage capacitors to a magnetic induction core. The FETs are commanded on and off by an optical signal that determines the duration of the accelerating pulse. Further electronic circuitry is provided that resets the magnetic cores in each modulator immediately after the accelerating pulse. The system produces bursts of five or more pulses with an adjustable pulse width that ranges from 200 ns to 2 μs. The pulse duty factor within a burst can be as high as 25% while still allowing time for the induction core to reset. The solid-state modulator described above is called ARM-II and is named for the Advanced Radiographic Machine (ARM) - a powerful radiographic accelerator that will be the principal diagnostic device for the future Advanced Hydrotest Facility (AHF).
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electron beams; Energy storage; Field effect transistors; Modulators; Advanced radiographic machines (ARM); Pulse repetition frequency induction accelerators; Particle accelerators

Authors: Koontz R., Akemoto M., Gold S., Krasnykh A., Wilson Z.
Title: NLC klystron pulse modulator R&D at SLAC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koontz, R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Akemoto, M., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Gold, S., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Krasnykh, A., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Wilson, Z., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The basic elements of a klystron pulse modulator are: a charging supply, a PFN with energy storage capacitors, a thyratron switch tube, and a pulse transformer. The design group mentioned above is working on the system requirements of an NLC modulator, is carrying out tests on components, and building a prototype NLC modulator of conventional, but optimized design. A PFN using Russian K15-10 type high energy density glass capacitors has been constructed and tested into a conventional pulse transformer and klystron load. Rise time is less than 400 nsec. Developmental work with thyratron manufacturers is being started. Similarly, R&D pulse transformers developed in cooperation with industry are being tested.
Index Keywords: Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric transformers; Klystrons; Linear accelerators; Modulators; Thyratrons; Klystron pulse modulators; Colliding beam accelerators

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Universite de Paris-Sud, Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Gao, J., Universite de Paris-Sud, Orsay, France
Abstract: A theory of bunch lengthening and energy spread increasing in electron storage rings is established by introducing the concept of collective random excitations. Analytical formulae are established to calculate the equilibrium bunch length and the energy spread in the whole current range. Some experimental results are compared with those predicted by the theory and the comparison results are quite well.

Authors: Wisnivesky D., Pardine C.
Title: Operation of the LNLS storage ring RF system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Wisnivesky, D., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Pardine, C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: The LNLS storage ring RF system operates at 476 MHz and delivers up to 60 kW CW into a single RF cavity. Injection and accumulation in the storage ring are done at low energy after which the beam energy is ramped up to 1.37 GeV. Correspondingly the RF power changes from a very low initial value up to a high power determined by the amount of stored current. Several temperature and mechanical tuning control systems operate during ramping and steady state to keep the cavity tuned and away from instabilities. In this paper we discuss the results and experience obtained after more than one year of operation of the system.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Linear accelerators; Particle beam injection; Tuning; Radiofrequency (RF) cavity; Storage rings

Authors: Gold S.L., Eichner J.P., Koontz R.F., Krasnykh A.
Title: Developments in the NLC modulator R&D program at SLAC
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gold, S.L., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Eichner, J.P., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Koontz, R.F., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Krasnykh, A., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The NLC (Next Linear Collider) development effort continues to move forward from its initial Zero Design Report (ZDR). A major component of the NLC is the High Power RF Source, which is designed around the technology of the klystron. The NLC is conceptualized around 75 MW, PPM (periodic permanent magnet) focussed, klystrons and will use approximately 3300 klystrons in each of the two main Linacs. Simple analysis has shown that operating two klystrons per modulator has both economic and configuration advantages. The physical design of the modulators is an integral part of the design of the tunnels, etc. Klystron spacing is dictated by the pulse compression regime. This paper will present the to-date results of the investigation efforts in energy storage, pulse transformers and efficiency. Future plans, including new technologies to pursue will be discussed. SLAC is also continuously looking for new and novel approaches to either the modulator components or the overall modulator approach. SLAC and the DOE are attempting to use the SBIR program to help with industry development of the needed components and new ideas.
Index Keywords: Electric transformers; Energy storage; Klystrons; Permanent magnets; Periodic permanent magnets (PPM); Pulse transformers; Modulators

Authors: de Lamare J., Donaldson A., Kulikov A., Lipari L.
Title: PEP-II abort kicker system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: de Lamare, J., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Donaldson, A., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Kulikov, A., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Lipari, L., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The PEP-II project has two storage rings. The HER (High Energy Ring) has up to 1.48 A of electron beam at 9 GeV, and the LER (Low Energy Ring) has up to 2.14 A of positron beam at 3.1 GeV. To protect the HER and LER beam lines in the event of a ring component failure, each ring has an abort kicker system which directs the beam into a dump when a failure is detected. Due to the high current of the beams, the beam kick is tapered from 100% to 80% in 7.33μS (the beam transit time around the ring). This taper distributes the energy evenly across the window which separates the ring from the beam dump such that the window is not damaged. The abort kicker trigger is synchronized with the ion clearing gap of the beam allowing for the kicker field to rise from 0-80% in 370 nS. This report discusses the design of the system controls, interlocks, power supplies, and modulator.
Index Keywords: Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electron beams; Electron gas; Modulators; Positrons; Synchronization; Abort kicker systems; High energy rings (HER); Low energy rings (LER); Storage rings

Authors: Anderson E.B., Rogers J.
Title: Trapped modes in CESR sliding joints
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, E.B., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States; Rogers, J., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: Trapped modes in the sliding joints in CESR were investigated as a possible source of instabilities. To detect these modes, experiments were performed where pairs of bunches of positrons were run through at various spacings. It was hoped that constructive and destructive interference of wake fields would produce varying amounts of heating. Data taking was time consuming, and insufficient numbers of data points could be taken to fit to the wake fields. To help solve this, the frequency of the mode was measured on the bench. A single trapped mode and its profile were observed. The trapped mode has a frequency of 3.59 GHz, just below the TM cutoff of the beampipe. Measurements of the mode were used to predict a shunt impedance of 4.9 ohms. The corresponding loss factor is slightly higher than the total loss factor found in previous time domain measurements. The program ZAP was used to predict an instability threshold of about 2.1 A.
Index Keywords: Electric impedance; Energy dissipation; Particle beam dynamics; Positrons; Wave interference; Shunt impedance; Trapped modes; Storage rings

Authors: McDowall Jim, Broussely Michel
Title: Battery developments for the outside plant environment - an overview
Affiliations: SAFT Advanced and Industrial Battery, Group
Authors with affiliations: McDowall, Jim, SAFT Advanced and Industrial Battery, Group; Broussely, Michel, SAFT Advanced and Industrial Battery, Group
Abstract: Valve-regulated lead-acid (VRLA) became the battery of choice as the telephone infrastracture evolved, pushing switching equipment further out into the distribution network. VRLA batteries are cost-effective in mild environments, but present problems in hot climates, particularly in outside plant applications. The benefits and potential drawbacks of VRLA battery alternatives such as nickel-cadmium pocket plate, nickel-cadmium sintered/PBE, nickel-metal hydride, lithium-ion and lithium-polymer batteries are discussed.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric energy storage; Electric vehicles; Flywheels; Fuel cells; Lithium batteries; Nickel cadmium batteries; Superconducting magnets; Valve-regulated lead-acid (VRLA) batteries; Secondary batteries

Authors: Bocchetta C.J., Fabris A., Iazzourene F., Karantzoulis E., Svandrlik M., Tosi L., Walker R.P., Wrulich A.
Title: Beam density manipulations in the ELETTRA storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bocchetta, C.J., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Fabris, A., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Iazzourene, F., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Karantzoulis, E., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Svandrlik, M., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Tosi, L., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Walker, R.P., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Wrulich, A., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy
Abstract: Low energy third generation light sources, such as ELETTRA, are lifetime limited by Touschek scattering. In principle an improvement of the lifetime can be obtained by increasing the emittance coupling or by increasing the longitudinal bunch dimensions, however, both methods have an adverse effect on the light quality. The trade off between lifetime and light quality in ELETTRA is discussed and spectral measurements for various scenarios are presented.
Index Keywords: Light sources; Particle beams; Touschek scattering; Storage rings

Authors: Borden M.J., Plum M.A., Sugai I.
Title: Carbon stripper foils used in the Los Alamos PSR
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Borden, M.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Plum, M.A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Sugai, I., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Carbon stripper foils produced by the modified controlled ACDC arc discharge method (mCADAD) at the Institute for Nuclear Study have been tested and used for high current 800-MeV beam production in the Proton Storage Ring (PSR) since 1993. Two foils approximately 110 μg/cm2 each are sandwiched together to produce an equivalent 220 μg/cm2 foil. The foil sandwich is supported by 4-5 μm diameter carbon fibers attached to an aluminum frame. These foils have survived as long as five months during PSR normal beam production of near 70 μA average current on target. Typical life-times of other foils vary from seven to fourteen days with lower on-target average current. Beam loss data also indicate that these foils have slower shrinkage rates than standard foils. Equipment has been assembled and used to produce foils by the mCADAD method at Los Alamos. These foils will be tested during 1997 operation.
Index Keywords: Electric arcs; Energy dissipation; Life cycle; Particle beam dynamics; Protons; Service life; Targets; Carbon stripper foils; Modified controlled arc discharged method; Storage rings

Authors: Svandrlik M., Fabris A., Pasotti C.
Title: Improvements in curing Coupled Bunch Instabilities at ELETTRA by mode shifting after the installation of the adjustable Higher Order Mode Frequency Shifter (HOMFS)
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Svandrlik, M., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Fabris, A., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy; Pasotti, C., Sincrotrone Trieste, Trieste, Italy
Abstract: Mode shifting is the technique used at the third generation synchrotron light source ELETTRA to cure Coupled Bunch Instabilities (CBI). Temperature tuning of the RF cavities, based on an analytical prediction algorithm, allows longitudinal stable operating conditions to be obtained. However, once longitudinal stability has been achieved transverse instabilities can be observed, particularly during the energy ramp from 1.0 to 2.0 GeV. There has therefore been the need to extend the flexibility of the mode shifting technique. This has been achieved by the installation of adjustable HOMFS on the storage ring RF cavities. The HOMFS is effective on those longitudinal and transverse cavity Higher Order Modes which are unstable over a wide temperature range, by shifting them out of the operating temperature interval of the cavity. The installation of the HOMFS has improved the reliability and reproducibility of machine operation, also in view of the beam current upgrade.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Curing; Particle beam dynamics; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Tuning; Coupled bunch instabilities (CBI); Higher order mode frequency shifters (HOMFS); Synchrotrons

Authors: Zheng Jianli, Chen Songcan
Title: High-order BAM-its modifications and performance analyses
Source title: Journal of Dong Hua University (English Edition)
Affiliations: China Textile Univ, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, Jianli, China Textile Univ, Shanghai, China; Chen, Songcan, China Textile Univ, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Based on Tai's high-order bidirectional associative memory (HOBAM) and Simposon's intraconnected BAM (IBAM), two improved models are presented and discussed. The improved models not only retain the advantages of both HOBAM and IBAM but overcome the shortcomings of Kosko's BAM also. Their recall stabilities in synchronous and asynchronous update modes have been proven by defining corresponding energy functions which decrease as the recall process proceeds. Finally with signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) approach, it is shown that their storage capacities and error correction capabilities are better than that of the HOBAM.
Index Keywords: Error correction; Learning systems; Mathematical models; Signal to noise ratio; Stability; Bidirectional associative memory; Storage capacity; Neural networks

Authors: Nance Thomas A., Fogle Robert F.
Title: Mobile, teleoperated, tool platform for use in waste tank remediation efforts
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nance, Thomas A., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States; Fogle, Robert F., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Abstract: A low-cost crawler is being developed to carry a range of tools to dissolve or breakup the residual heel and clinkers left in the storage tanks at the Department of Energy's Savannah River Site. The crawler will move the waste so that it can be easily pumped out of the waste tanks. The remotely-operated tool platform being developed will carry a water cannon and other water conveyance devices and will be able to access the tanks through available small access ports. The cleaning challenge, possible solutions and their evaluation and selection, design, development, and mockup testing results of a low-cost, mobile, teleoperated, tool platform for breaking up large waste deposits remaining in underground waste storage tanks are discussed.
Index Keywords: Cleaning; Cost effectiveness; Process control; Radioactive waste storage; Remediation; Remote control; Tanks (containers); Crawlers; Radioactive waste remediation; Teleoperation; Mobile robots

Authors: Mizel V.J.
Title: On the ubiquity of fracture in nonlinear elasticity
Affiliations: Department of Mathematical Sciences, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mizel, V.J., Department of Mathematical Sciences, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Abstract: This paper points out a subtle and little known consequence of assuming rank-one convexity for an isotropic hyperelastic material [e.g., of assuming a common ordering of principal stretches and principal stresses and hence the Baker-Ericksen inequalities]. What is shown is that rank-one convexity necessarily privilages those affine deformations which are dilatations:-the stored-energy associated with a dilatation is smaller than the stored energy associated with any other affine deformation possessing the same determinant. Also pointed out are fracture related consequences of this property that arise when the stored-energy function assigns to the dilatation of determinant δ>0 a value A(δ) which is not an everywhere convex function of δ∈(0, ∞).
Index Keywords: Deformation; Energy storage; Fracture mechanics; Functions; Polyconvexity; Rank one convexity; Elasticity

Authors: Farias R.H.A., Jahnel L.C., Lin Liu, Tavares P.F.
Title: Optical beam diagnostics for the LNLS synchrotron light source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Farias, R.H.A., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Jahnel, L.C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Lin, Liu, Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Tavares, P.F., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: An optical characterization bench for the electron beam in the LNLS storage ring using visible synchrotron radiation is described. Preliminary measurements at injection energy (120 MeV) and at operation energy (1.37 GeV) are presented. The system includes a high frame rate (up to 400 Hz) CCD camera and a fast photodiode (7 ps FWHM) for longitudinal measurements.
Index Keywords: Charge coupled devices; Electron beams; Electron energy levels; Particle beam injection; Photodiodes; Synchrotron radiation; Optical beam diagnostics; Storage rings

Authors: Takaki Hiroyuki, Koseki Tadashi, Nakamura Norio, Kamiya Yukihide, Kobayashi Yukinori, Nagatsuka Toshiya
Title: Lattice for the future project of VUV and soft X-ray high-brilliant light source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takaki, Hiroyuki, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Koseki, Tadashi, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nakamura, Norio, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kamiya, Yukihide, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kobayashi, Yukinori, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Nagatsuka, Toshiya, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Presented in this paper is a lattice for a third-generation VUV and soft X-ray light source, which is a future project of the University of Tokyo and is being designed in close collaboration with the Photon Factory of KEK. The storage ring has an energy of 2 GeV, a circumference of about 400 m, an emittance of about 5 nm·rad, four 14.3 m `long' straight sections and twelve 7.0 m `semi-long' straight sections for insertion devices. Three different optics were studied in the same lattice configuration. It was proved that this lattice configuration has large flexibility and the basic optics has a sufficiently large dynamic aperture.
Index Keywords: Light sources; Particle beam dynamics; Particle optics; Ultraviolet radiation; X rays; X ray sources; Storage rings

Authors: Coulson D.R.
Title: EMC techniques for microprocessor software
Affiliations: DIRAC Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Coulson, D.R., DIRAC Ltd
Abstract: Design engineers have found that embedding microcontrollers into products provides extra features and functionality but also introduces a new set of EMC problems. Microcontroller-based equipment is particularly vulnerable to electrical transients such as electrostatic discharge (ESD), electrical fast transient bursts (EFT), high energy surges and supply dips, interruptions and variations. Hardware countermeasures should always be the first line of defence, to achieve any chance of immunity to transient phenomena. However, there are also defensive measures that may be applied in software. A simple strategy for hardening microcontroller-based systems is presented.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Computer software; Computer systems programming; Electric discharges; Electric surges; Electrostatics; Microcontrollers; Microprocessor chips; Nonvolatile storage; Oscillators (electronic); PROM; Transients; Bose-Chanduri-Hocqenheim algorithms; Cyclic redundancy checking (CRC); Electrical fast transient bursts (EFT); Electrically erasable programmable random read only memory (EEPROM); Electrostatic discharges (ESD); In-circuit emulators (ICE); Multidimensional parity checking; Electromagnetic compatibility

Authors: Liu Y.C., Chen J.R., Hsu K.T., Kuo C.C., Lau W.K., Luo G.H., Sah R.C., Ueng T.S.
Title: Operational experience at SRRC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Y.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan; Chen, J.R., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan; Hsu, K.T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan; Kuo, C.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan; Lau, W.K., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan; Luo, G.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan; Sah, R.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan; Ueng, T.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Taiwan
Abstract: The Taiwan Light Source (TLS) is a synchrotron radiation facility that has operated for the past four years at SRRC. At this time, the operating energy has been increased from 1.3 GeV to 1.5 GeV, and the beam lifetime is 9 hours at a current of 200 mA. The monthly uptime is normally more than 90%, and the orbit stability better than 5 micrometers. Both transverse and longitudinal instabilities have been observed, and the corresponding feedback systems have been constructed. The transverse feedback system is in routine operation. A fast orbit feedback system is capable of restricting orbit errors to within 10 micrometers, even in the presence of strong orbit perturbations such as insertion-device gap changes.
Index Keywords: Fast orbit feedback systems; Insertion devices; Transverse feedback systems; Light sources; Particle beams; Synchrotron radiation; Storage rings

Authors: Cassel R., Nguyen M.N.
Title: Unique power supply for the PEPII klystron at SLAC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cassel, R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Nguyen, M.N., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: Each of the eight 1.2 MW RF klystrons for the PEP-II storage rings require a 2.5 MVA DC power supply of 83 Kv at 23 amps. The design for the supply was base on three factors low cost, small size to fit existing substation pads, and good protection against damage to the klystron including klystron gun arcs. The supply uses a 12 pulse 12.5 KV primary thyristor `star point controller' with primary filter inductor to provide rapid voltage control, good voltage regulation, and fast turn off during klystron tube faults. The supply also uses a unique secondary rectifier, filter capacitor configuration to minimize the energy available under a klystron fault. The voltage control is from 0-90 KV with a regulation of <0.1% and voltage ripple of <1% P-P, (<0.2% RMS.) above 60 KV. The supply utilizes a thyristor crowbar, which under a klystron tube arc limits the energy in the klystron arc to <5 joules. If the thyristor crowbar is disabled the energy supplied is <40 joules into the arc. The size of the supply was reduced small enough to fit the existing PEP transformer yard pads. The cost of the power supply was <$140 per KVA.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric rectifiers; Klystrons; Thyristors; Voltage control; Klystron gun arcs; Storage rings

Authors: Sugimura T., Shirai T., Tonguu H., Iwashita Y., Noda A., Inoue M.
Title: Present status of the electron linac as the injector for KSR
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sugimura, T., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Shirai, T., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Tonguu, H., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Iwashita, Y., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Noda, A., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan; Inoue, M., Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Japan
Abstract: At Kyoto University, a 300 MeV electron storage ring, KSR, has been constructed for the research of the synchrotron radiation light. As an injector of the ring, an S-band electron linac with the energy of 100 MeV was constructed in October, 1995, and have been operated since then. We measured the transverse emittance of the 100 MeV electron beam using a profile monitor made of a fluorescent screen and quadrupole lenses. The horizontal and vertical ones are 0.44 π·mm·mrad and 1.3 π·mm·mrad, respectively. The beam from the linac is being used for the experiment of the parametric X-ray radiation from the silicon crystal at rather low duty factor.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Electron emission; Electron lenses; Fluorescent screens; Particle beam injection; Silicon; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; X rays; Electron storage rings; Linear accelerators

Authors: Luijckxs G., van Amersfoort P.W., Boer-Rookhuizen H., van den Brand J.F.J., Kroes F.B., de Jager C.W., Kuijer L.H., van der Laan J.B., Maas R., Noomen J.G., Passchier I., van den Putte M.J.J., Koop I., Militsyn B.
Title: Polarized electrons in the AmPS storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Luijckxs, G., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; van Amersfoort, P.W., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Boer-Rookhuizen, H., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; van den Brand, J.F.J., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Kroes, F.B., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; de Jager, C.W., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Kuijer, L.H., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; van der Laan, J.B., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Maas, R., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Noomen, J.G., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Passchier, I., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; van den Putte, M.J.J., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Koop, I., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Militsyn, B., NIKHEF, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: AmPS is a 300-900 MeV electron ring. The machine was designed as a pulse stretcher to provide continuous external beams. After years of successful operation in this mode the nuclear physics program now concentrates on experiments with stored beams interacting with internal gas targets. These experiments require currents between 50 and 200 mA through 60 cm long 15 mm wide cylindrical target cells. Gas pressures in the open-ended cells correspond to target thickness of 1014 to 1016 atoms/cm2. Strong stray fields from a spectrometer and from target holding fields disturb the closed orbit. Under operational conditions the linac provides a maximum energy of 700 MeV, so ramping is required to achieve 900 MeV. To further increase the luminosity at the target a reduced emittance lattice based on the existing magnet configuration has been designed. Late 1996 a polarized electron injector as well as a `Siberian Snake' to control the spin on the internal target became operational. The polarized injector delivers a few mA to the linac so stacked injection in the ring is required. With strained InGaAsP cathodes a polarization of 80% was obtained. Test results, performance and prospects are presented.
Index Keywords: Electron ring accelerators; Particle beam injection; Particle spectrometers; Polarization; Targets; Electron polarization; Luminosity; Stacked injection; Storage rings

Authors: Keller R.
Title: Transfer functions for the ALS lattice magnets
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keller, R., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: The primary purpose of the magnetic measurements performed on the ALS storage-ring lattice-magnets was to ascertain their compliance with the strict tolerances established for this third-generation synchrotron light source. In the course of the data evaluation, a novel approximation method has been developed that leads to four-parameter representations of all magnet transfer-functions, and includes saturation and residual field effects. These transfer functions were used to change the standard working point of the ALS storage ring at 1.5-GeV beam energy from the upper to the lower hysteresis branches, and later to ramp the ring energy from 1.5 GeV to the maximum design value of 1.9 GeV in one uninterrupted process that did not require any intermediate tune correction. Likewise, predicted magnet set values for 1.0-GeV conditions were applied and very closely led to the standard betatron tunes.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Betatrons; Elementary particle sources; Light sources; Magnetic hysteresis; Magnetic variables measurement; Storage rings; Synchrotrons; Transfer functions; Advanced light source (ALS) lattice magnets; Accelerator magnets

Authors: Jackson A., Byrd J., Decking W., Howells M., Keller R., Kim C.H., Massoletti D., Nishimura H., Robin D., Zyngier H.
Title: ALS-N - a candidate for a next-generation synchrotron light-source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jackson, A., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Byrd, J., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Decking, W., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Howells, M., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Keller, R., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Kim, C.H., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Massoletti, D., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Nishimura, H., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Robin, D., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Zyngier, H., E.O. Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: A next-generation light source is investigated and showed that a factor of 10-100 increase in photon brightness from undulators can be achieved in the soft X ray energy range. Both the electron emittance and bunch length suffer significantly from the effects of intrabeam scattering (IBS) at a beam current of 400 mA. Though this caps the achievable beam brightness, there is a favorable increase in Touschek lifetime. The brightness from bend magnets is also increased, to the level that it starts to become interesting for soft X ray microscopy. With specially tailored optics at the bend magnet sources, the photon brightness could be increased by another order of magnitude.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Elementary particle sources; Light sources; Particle beams; Particle optics; Photons; Storage rings; X ray microscopes; Advanced light sources (ALS); Intrabeam scattering (IBS); Soft X rays; Synchrotrons

Authors: Trbojevic D., Palmer R.B., Courant E.D., Gallardo J., Peggs S., Tepikian S., Ng K.Y.
Title: Lattice for the muon collider demonstration ring in the RHIC tunnel
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Trbojevic, D., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Palmer, R.B., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Courant, E.D., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Gallardo, J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Peggs, S., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Tepikian, S., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Ng, K.Y., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: The future μ+μ- Muon Collider should have a luminosity of the order of 1035 cm-2s-1, an the energy of 2×2 TeV. We present here a demonstration machine at a lower energy to test the feasibility of all components involved, which could be placed inside the existing Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) tunnel. The maximum energy of the muons in the RHIC tunnel depends on the maximum attainable field in the dipoles. The maximum energy in the existing RHIC rings for protons is 250 GeV, where the strength of the magnetic field in the dipoles is 3.5 T. A design of the storage ring lattice for a 50 GeV muon demonstration machine is also presented.
Index Keywords: Heavy ions; Optimization; Particle beam dynamics; Storage rings; Muon colliders; Relativistic heavy ion collider (RHIC) tunnels; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Conrad G.M.
Title: Advanced power conversion using a switch matrix
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Raytheon Systems Co, Sudbury, United States
Authors with affiliations: Conrad, G.M., Raytheon Systems Co, Sudbury, United States
Abstract: To obtain an efficient AC to AC (or DC) power conversion topology, one with minimum size and weight, all energy storage elements should be removed. The result is a Switch Matrix Converter that only has power switches and snubbers. This resulting topology was evaluated and found promising for many applications. It features Unity power factor by design, variable output voltage and frequency, low harmonic generation, and bi-directional power flow. This flexible power conversion topology consists of a switch matrix connected between the AC input and AC (or DC) output. Each switch ON-time is selected based upon input AC voltage and current and pulse-width modulated in accordance with developed algorithms. The output voltage can be preset from zero to 0.866* Vin or can be modulated during operation. The output frequency can be preset from zero Hz (DC) to a fraction of the switching frequency or can be modulated during operation. This paper presents a description of the Switch Matrix Converter based on a compilation of the work done by Messrs. Venturini, Ishiguro, and Holmes. It illustrates the basic components required and switching sequences necessary for efficient operation. It also presents simulated waveforms resulting from a Basic program written to verify the performance capabilities of this advanced power conversion technique.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric network topology; Electric power factor; Switch matrix converters; Power converters

Authors: Streibl M., Rocke C., Govorov A.O., Wixforth A.
Title: Novel optoelectronic signal processing via the combination of SAW and semiconductor heterostructures
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium
Affiliations: Sektion Physik der LMU, Muenchen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Streibl, M., Sektion Physik der LMU, Muenchen, Germany; Rocke, C., Sektion Physik der LMU, Muenchen, Germany; Govorov, A.O., Sektion Physik der LMU, Muenchen, Germany; Wixforth, A., Sektion Physik der LMU, Muenchen, Germany
Abstract: The combination of surface acoustic waves (SAWs) and the superior electrical and optical properties of band-gap engineered semiconductor layer systems yields a completely new and promising approach toward another generation of acoustoelectric and optoelectronic devices. The propagating potential modulations accompanying a SAW on a piezoelectric semiconductor heterostructure can be exploited to alter the optical properties of an optoelectronic structure in many ways and over a wide range. We demonstrate the SAW-induced separation, storage and transport of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Various schemes to release the carriers in form of a time delayed light signal are demonstrated and discussed. We present some basic structures and applications.
Index Keywords: Acoustic surface wave devices; Charge carriers; Electrooptical effects; Energy gap; Heterojunctions; Piezoelectric devices; Semiconducting films; Signal processing; Optoelectronic signal processing; Ultrasonics

Authors: Kurozumi Kazuhiro, Tawara Takeru, Tanaka Toshikazu, Kawagoe Yuji, Yamanaka Takashi, Ikebe Hiroaki, Shindou Kazuhiko, Miyazato Tetsuo
Title: Hybrid system composed of a wind power and a photovoltaic system at NTT Kume-jima radio relay station
Affiliations: NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kurozumi, Kazuhiro, NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan; Tawara, Takeru, NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan; Tanaka, Toshikazu, NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan; Kawagoe, Yuji, NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan; Yamanaka, Takashi, NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan; Ikebe, Hiroaki, NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan; Shindou, Kazuhiko, NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan; Miyazato, Tetsuo, NTT Power and Building Facilities, Inc, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes a 250 kW hybrid system composed of two systems which uses clean energy sources, a wind power system and a photovoltaic (PV) system. The hybrid system has been installed in the radio relay station at NTT in Kume-jima (a small island in the south-west of Japan). The hybrid system consists of a 230 kW wind turbine, a 50 kW resistor, a 230 kW bi-directional converter with storage batteries, 20 kW PV modules, and a 20 kW interactive inverter. The power generated in this system is supplied to telecommunications equipment at the radio relay station and to the power grid by reversing power flow. One of the advantages of this system is that it suppresses rapid change in the output power of the wind power system. This rapid change causes the grid voltage and the grid frequency to fluctuate because the grid capacity in Kume-jima is low.
Index Keywords: Electric inverters; Photovoltaic cells; Power converters; Radio links; Resistors; Secondary batteries; Solar cells; Solar energy; Telecommunication equipment; Wind power; Wind turbines; Bidirectional inverters; Radio relay stations; Electric power systems

Authors: Recupero Vincenzo, Pino Lidia, Di Leonardo Raffaele, Lagana Massimo
Title: Development of a hydrogen generator based on the partial oxidation of natural gas integrated with PEFC
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Petroleum Division (Publication) PD
Affiliations: Inst CNR-TAE, Messina, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Recupero, Vincenzo, Inst CNR-TAE, Messina, Italy; Pino, Lidia, Inst CNR-TAE, Messina, Italy; Di Leonardo, Raffaele, Inst CNR-TAE, Messina, Italy; Lagana, Massimo, Inst CNR-TAE, Messina, Italy
Abstract: As well known, the most acknowledged process for generation of hydrogen for fuel cells is based upon the steam reforming of methane or natural gas. A valid alternative could be a process based on partial oxidation of methane, since the process is mildly exothermic and therefore not energy intensive. Consequently, great interest is expected from conversion of methane into syngas, if an autothermal, low energy intensive, compact and reliable process could be developed. This paper covers the activities, performed by CNR Institute Transformation and Storage of Energy, Messina - Italy, on theoretical and experimental studies for a compact hydrogen generator, via catalytic selective partial oxidation of methane, integrated with a PEFC (Polymer Electrolyte Fuel Cell). In particular, the project focuses the attention on methane partial oxidation via heterogeneous selective catalysts, in order to: demonstrate the basic Catalytic Selective Partial Oxidation of Methane (CSPOM) technology in a subscale prototype, equivalent to a nominal output of 5 kWe; develop the CSPOM technology for its application in electric energy production by means of fuel cells; assess, by a balance of plant analysis, and a techno-economic evaluation, the potential benefits of the CSPOM for different categories of fuel cells.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen; Methane; Natural gas; Oxidation; Polyelectrolytes; Partial oxidation; Polymer electrolyte fuel cell; Fuel cells

Authors: Dallin L.O., Skopik D.M.
Title: Canadian Light Source proposal
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dallin, L.O., Univ of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada; Skopik, D.M., Univ of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada
Abstract: The storage ring for a 2.9 GeV Canadian Light Source has been designed. The lattice is composed of twelve compact DBA cells resulting in a ring that is 148 meters in circumference with twelve drifts of 4.5 meters for the inclusion of insertion devices. The emittance is less than 20 nm-rad, resulting in radiation brightness competitive with other `third generation' sources. Details of orbit correction, beam stability and lifetime and the effect of insertion devices have been investigated. The RF requirements have been defined and preliminary magnet designs have been done. The light source will operate with full energy injection and the injection scheme has been fully defined. Injection includes a 300 MeV linear accelerator, low energy transfer line, booster synchrotron and high energy transfer to the storage ring. With this configuration it will be possible to operate the storage ring with beam currents up to 500 mA, resulting in a source of very intense light over a broad range of photon energies. For example, with a state of the art undulator, it will be possible to produce 20 keV photons with a brightness close to 1018 photons/s/mm2/mrad2/0.1% bandwidth.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Light sources; Linear accelerators; Particle beam injection; Photons; Synchrotrons; Double bend achromat (DBA); Storage rings

Authors: Johnstone C.J., Mokhov N.V.
Title: Shielding the muon collider interaction region
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Fermilab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnstone, C.J., Fermilab, Batavia, United States; Mokhov, N.V., Fermilab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: One of the most serious technical problems in the design of a 2-TeV muon collider arises from muon decay. Immersed in strong magnetic fields, the induced electromagnetic showers deposit about 2 kW/meter in the storage ring; far surpassing the heat load capacity of cryogenic systems. Yet a more problematic background is the intense, highly directional, neutrino flux generated by the decays. This background does not respond to conventional shielding techniques; in fact the total radiation dose from neutrino interactions is worsened in the presence of shielding. The work presented here will discuss methods to reduce or compensate for the severe decay backgrounds and radiation produced in a very high-energy muon collider.
Index Keywords: Accelerator shielding; Particle beam dynamics; Luminosity; Muon colliders; Nonlinear interaction region; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Pappas G.C., Donaldson A.R., Williams D.
Title: PEP II injection kicker system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pappas, G.C., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Donaldson, A.R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Williams, D., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: PEP II or the B Factory consists of two asymmetric storage rings. The injection energy for electrons is 9 GeV, while that for positrons is 3.1 Gev. The bend angle into the high energy ring (HER) is 0.35 m-rad, and the angle into the low energy ring (LER) is 0.575 m-rad. The magnetic length for the HER kicker is 0.85 m, and 0.55 m for the LER kicker. The field produced by the magnet is therefore 123.5 G for the HER, and 132 G for the LER. Each ring has a kicker magnet upstream of the injection line which is used to distort the orbit of the stored beam. An identical magnet downstream of the injection line is used to restore the orbit of the stored beam and inject the incoming beam. The two magnets are driven in parallel by the modulator. The aperture of the magnets is 3.86×3.46 cm (H×V). Therefore the current required to drive the HER is 863 A, while for the LER it is 756 A. The inductance of the magnet is approximately 1.4 μH/m. The current pulse is a critically damped sinusoid with a rise time of less than 300 ns. A kicker system has been designed which can be used for injection of both beams by varying the charge voltage. The modulator uses a conjugate circuit to match the impedance of the magnet, and coupling to the beam chamber.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Damping; Modulators; Particle beam dynamics; Particle beam injection; Damped sinusoids; Injection kicker systems; Magnetic inductance; Storage rings

Authors: Nassiri A., Cours A., Grelick A., Horan D., Kang Y.W., Kustom R.L., Smith T.L., Song J.
Title: Overview of the APS 352-MHz rf systems
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nassiri, A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Cours, A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Grelick, A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Horan, D., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Kang, Y.W., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Kustom, R.L., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Smith, T.L., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Song, J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Photon Source (APS) is a 7-GeV full energy positron storage ring for generating synchrotron radiation with an injector. The booster synchrotron rf system consists of a single 1-MW klystron which drives four five-cell cavities at 352 MHz. The storage ring cavities consist of four groups of four single cells powered by two 1-MW klystrons for 100-mA operation. An overview of the operation of the APS 352-MHz rf systems is presented.
Index Keywords: Klystrons; Light sources; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Booster synchrotrons; Storage rings

Authors: Shakiba M.H., Johns D.A., Martin K.W.
Title: BiCMOS circuits for analog viterbi decoders
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Analog and Digital Signal Processing
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ont., M5S 3G4, Canada; Gennum Corp., Burlington, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Shakiba, M.H., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ont., M5S 3G4, Canada; Johns, D.A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ont., M5S 3G4, Canada; Martin, K.W., Gennum Corp., Burlington, Ont., Canada
Abstract: Analog Viterbi decoders are finding widespread use in class-IV partial-response disk-drive applications. These analog realizations are often used because they are smaller and consume less power than their digital counterparts. However, class-IV signaling allows simplifications during Viterbi detection and thus existing analog decoders have limited applications. The purpose of this paper is to develop efficient analog circuits that can be used for general Viterbi detection. To demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed approach, the analog portions of two analog Viterbi decoders were fabricated in a 0.8-jum BiCMOS process. With an off-chip digital path memory, operation up to 50 Mb/s is demonstrated. However, simulations indicate that with on-chip digital path memory, speeds on the order of 300 Mb/s can be achieved. The power consumption of the proposed approach is estimated to be 15 mW/state drawn from a single 5-V power supply. Index Terms-Analog, BiCMOS, communications, Viterbi. © 1998 IEEE Publisher Item Identifier S 1057-7130(98)09976-5.
Index Keywords: Analog storage; CMOS integrated circuits; Efficiency; Energy utilization; Performance; Signal detection; Analog circuits; Decoding

Authors: Rodrigues A.R.D., Farias R.H.A., Ferreira M.J., Franco G.S., Jahnel L.C., Lin Liu, Lira A.C., Neuenschwander R.T., Pardine C., Rafael F., Rosa A., Scorzato C., Goncalves da Silva C.E.T., Romeu da Silva A., Tavares P.F.
Title: Commissioning and operation of the Brazilian synchrotron light source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Rodrigues, A.R.D., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Farias, R.H.A., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Ferreira, M.J., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Franco, G.S., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Jahnel, L.C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Lin, Liu, Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Lira, A.C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Neuenschwander, R.T., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Pardine, C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Rafael, F., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Rosa, A., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Scorzato, C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Goncalves da Silva, C.E.T., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Romeu da Silva, A., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Tavares, P.F., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: The Brazilian National Synchrotron Light Laboratory, LNLS, operates a 1.37 GeV electron storage ring with a 120 MeV injector Linac. Commissioning of the storage ring at low energy started on May 1996 and now, an year later, we can store 120 mA at 120 MeV and ramp more than 75 mA to 1.37 GeV. A summary of the latest commissioning results and a description of the present operational performance of the LNLS Synchrotron Light Source facility is presented.
Index Keywords: Light sources; Linear accelerators; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Synchrotron light source; Particle optics

Authors: Lumpkin A.H., Yang B.X., Litvinenko V., Park S., Wang P., Wu Y.
Title: Initial application of a dual-sweep streak camera to the Duke storage ring OK-4 source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lumpkin, A.H., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Yang, B.X., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Litvinenko, V., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Park, S., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Wang, P., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Wu, Y., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The visible and UV spontaneous emission radiation (SER) from the Duke OK-4 wiggler has been used with a Hamamatsu C5680 dual-sweep streak camera to characterize the stored electron beams. Particle beam energies of 270 and 500 MeV in the Duke storage ring were used in this initial application with the OK-4 adjusted to generate wavelengths from 500 nm to near 200 nm. The OK-4 magnetic system with its 68 periods provided a much stronger radiation source than a nearby bending magnet source point. Sensitivity to single-bunch, single-turn SER was shown down to 4 μA beam current at λ = 450 nm. The capability of seeing second passes in the FEL resonator at a wavelength near 200 nm was used to assess the cavity length versus orbit length. These tests (besides supporting preparation for UV-visible SR FEL startups) are also relevant to possible diagnostics techniques for single-pass FEL prototype facilities.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electric currents; Electron beams; Electron ring accelerators; Free electron lasers; Magnetic lenses; Spontaneous emission; Streak cameras; Wigglers; Storage rings

Authors: Shintake T., Akasaka N., Matsumoto H.
Title: Development of C-band RF pulse compression system for e+e- linear collider
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shintake, T., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Akasaka, N., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Matsumoto, H., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: A new type of RF compression scheme was proposed by the authors for the C-band RF system in the e+e- linear collider in 1996. This scheme generates a flat pulse output using 3-cell coupled-cavity for the high-Q energy-storage. A cold model cavity was fabricated and tested to test the flat pulse generation. The input RF amplitude is modulated with a scheduled waveform in order to compensate the output power ripple associated with the coupled cavity resonances. The cold model generated a flat pulse compressed with gain Gp of 3.25.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Linear accelerators; Resonance; Spectrum analysis; Cold cavity; Coupled cavity resonances; Power ripple; Pulse compression; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Chou W.
Title: Accelerator physics issues of a Very Large Hadron Collider
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Fermilab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chou, W., Fermilab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: A Very Large Hadron Collider (VLHC) was proposed for the post-LHC future. This paper gives a quick survey of a number of accelerator physics issues based on the information obtained from a parameter spreadsheet SSP. The main technical challenges to build such a machine appear to be: the large number of events per crossing (in hundreds), enormous beam stored energy (equivalent to tens tons of TNT), ground motion (which is particularly harmful when the synchrotron frequency is in the sub-Hertz range), small dynamic aperture (due to long filling time), fast growth of the resistive wall instability (in a fraction of one turn), low threshold of the single bunch transverse instability (due to big machine size), strong synchrotron radiation (at a level close to the LEP) and short radiation damage lifetime, etc. Possible solutions to some of these problems will also be discussed.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; High energy physics; Particle beam dynamics; Spreadsheets; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotron frequency; Very large hadron colliders (VLHC); Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Wilson Michael J., Goerz David A., Speer Ron D.
Title: Elegant impulser developed for flat beam injection
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, Michael J., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Goerz, David A., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States; Speer, Ron D., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Abstract: The following report describes the design, construction, and checkout of a high-voltage (HV) impulser built for the heavy ion fusion (HIF) project. The purpose of this impulser is to provide an adjustable diode voltage source of sufficient quality and level to allow the optimization of beam transport and accelerator sections of HIF. An elegant, low-impedance, high-energy storage capacitor circuit has been selected for this application. Circuit parameters of the retrofit to the diode region have been included to provide the controlled rise time. The critical part of this circuit that is common to all candidates is the impedance matching component. The following report provides a description of the implemented circuit, the basic circuit variables for wave shaping, screening techniques revealing the weakest circuit component, and the resulting output of the injector.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Impedance matching (electric); Particle beam injection; Flat beam injection; High-voltage impulsers; Pulse circuits

Authors: Ma Li, Shi Ping
Title: Upgrade of the BPM system for the BEPC storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Inst of High Energy Physics, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Ma, Li, Inst of High Energy Physics, Beijing, China; Shi, Ping, Inst of High Energy Physics, Beijing, China
Abstract: The Beijing Electron Positron Collider (BEPC) is a machine with a designing energy up to 2.8 GeV. Thirty-two button-type beam position monitors (BPMs) are used for the position measurement of the colliding e+ e- beams in the storage ring. In order to improve the measurement resolution and reduce the measurement time, the hardware and the software of the BPM system have been partially modified at last year and have been tested with beams. The BPM processing electronics and the measurement behavior can be fully controlled by a personal computer (PC) in the local control room. The measured beam position data are stored in the memory on another PC, which serves as a communication server. These data can be accessed by the main computer in the central control room through the network. The short-term reproducibility of the measurement is better than 10 microns. The measurement time for scanning all 32 BPMs is about 11 seconds. The reliability of the measurement is assured by the self-consistency check. The dynamic rang of the system is over 81 dB and the minimum measurable beam intensity is less than 0.5 mA. This paper will describe the hardware and the software of our upgraded BPM system. The performances of the BPM system are also given in the paper.
Index Keywords: Client server computer systems; Colliding beam accelerators; Computer hardware; Computer software; Position measurement; Beam position monitor (BPM) systems; Storage rings

Authors: Cheng D., Hunt D., Hsieh H., Meneghetti J., Kennedy K., Stevens T., Jones G., Miller T., Colomb D., Bertolini L., Belser C., Kerns J., Daly E.
Title: Status of the PEP-II Low-Energy Ring vacuum system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, D., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Hunt, D., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Hsieh, H., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Meneghetti, J., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Kennedy, K., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Stevens, T., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Jones, G., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Miller, T., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Colomb, D., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Bertolini, L., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Belser, C., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Kerns, J., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Daly, E., Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: The PEP-II B Factory Low-Energy Ring (LER) will operate at 3.1 GeV with 2.1 A; design specifications are based on 3.5 GeV at 3 A. The vacuum system, 2200 m long, consists of 6 arcs and 6 straights. The arc vacuum system is based on an aluminum antechamber pumped by titanium sublimators located directly under discrete photon stops, supplemented by 110 l/s ion pumps near the end of each dipole. The straight sections serve various utility functions, including emittance control with a wiggler, injection, and an interaction region (IR). Vacuum chambers in most of the straight sections are circular stainless steel pipe with external copper plating to facilitate heat transfer to cooling tubes brazed to the outside wall. The wiggler chicane vacuum system uses both aluminum and stainless steel technology, along with a 24 m long distributed copper photon dump. The IR vacuum system is mainly based on copper extrusions. LER vacuum system components are either in the late stage of prototyping or already in full production.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Cooling systems; Heat transfer; Photons; Stainless steel; Vacuum technology; Low-energy ring (LER) vacuum system; Titanium sublimation pump; Storage rings

Authors: Matsuo Hirofumi, Kobayashi Kimiyoshi, Sekine Yutaka, Asano Matsuyoshi, Wenzhong Lin
Title: Novel solar cell power supply system using the multiple-input DC-DC converter
Affiliations: Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuo, Hirofumi, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan; Kobayashi, Kimiyoshi, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan; Sekine, Yutaka, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan; Asano, Matsuyoshi, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan; Wenzhong, Lin, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: Recently, the clean electric power generation systems have attracted a great deal of social attention to exploit the clean energy resources such as solar array, wind generator, fuel cell and so forth. In this case, the multiple-input dc-dc converter is useful to combine the several input power sources and to supply the regulated output voltage for the load. The novel solar cell power supply system using the buck-boost type two-input dc-dc converter is proposed, in which the solar array and the commercial ac line are exploited as power sources and they are combined by the two input windings of the energy-storage reactor, also, its operation principle and performance characteristics are discussed. Furthermore, the solar cell optimum operating point tracker is proposed and examined. It is confirmed by the experiment that the proposed solar cell power supply system has the excellent performance characteristics.
Index Keywords: Power converters; Solar cells; Solar energy; Buck boost converters; Solar cell power supply systems; Electric power systems

Authors: Morash Richard T., Roesel John F., Barber Ronnie J.
Title: Integral system for energy storage and power generation uses Written-PoleTM AC motor and DC generator plus flywheel and gas engine; Eliminates batteries at cellular sites
Affiliations: Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morash, Richard T., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States; Roesel, John F., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States; Barber, Ronnie J., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Abstract: A Written-PoleTM brand of variable magnetic pole AC motor is used to drive a generator to produce DC power to be used in place of batteries and rectifiers for critical loads. The motor-generator set starts with low inrush current, has very high inertia, and uses flywheel energy storage to ride-through momentary power interruptions while the DC output remains very stable. An internal combustion engine is integrally mounted on the M-G sets and is used to drive the system during long, extended utility outages. The engine is started using the M-G set inertia instead of a battery. The Written-PoleTM motor converts to a generator while the engine is the prime mover. This supplies AC power for loads such as air conditioners for electronics. The system has been field-tested and is in commercial production.
Index Keywords: AC motors; DC generators; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy storage; Flywheels; Gas engines; Magnetic pole AC motors; Electric power generation

Authors: Wisnivesky D., Lira A.C., Silva A.R., Arroyo F.C., Oliveira L.H.
Title: Commissioning and first year operation of the LNLS magnet power supplies
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Wisnivesky, D., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Lira, A.C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Silva, A.R., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Arroyo, F.C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil; Oliveira, L.H., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: We describe the commissioning and operation of over 100 power supplies used in the LNLS injector, transport line and storage ring. In particular, we discuss the power supply characteristics required for low energy injection and ramping as well as for high energy operation. Low current ripple and stability at injection energies as well as repeatability and performance at high beam energy are specially considered.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electric currents; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Transport lines; Synchrotrons

Authors: Fuja R., Grelick A.E., Meyer D., Pile G., White M.
Title: Constant-current charging supplies for the advanced photon source (APS) linear accelerator modulators
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fuja, R., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Grelick, A.E., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Meyer, D., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Pile, G., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; White, M., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The APS linac beam energy must be stable to within ±1% to match the energy acceptance of the positron accumulator ring. The klystron pulse modulators must therefore provide a pulse-to-pulse repeatability of 0.1% in order for the beam to have the required energy stability. The modulators have had difficulty achieving the necessary repeatability since the pulse forming network (PFN) charging scheme does not include a deQing circuit. Several of the major charging circuit components are also less reliable than desired. In order to increase operating reliability and to improve pulse-to-pulse stability, it is planned to replace the high voltage power supplies in all modulators with constant-current power supplies. A new modulator charging supply that contains two EMI series 303 constant-current power supplies was constructed. Each of these EMI supplies delivers 1.5 A at up to 40 kV. One supply is sufficient for linac operation at up to 45 Hz, and two supplies in parallel enable linac operation at the nominal rf repetition rate of 60 Hz. This paper discusses test results from the new modulator, and also describes the existing modulators and their performance limitations.
Index Keywords: Electric charge; Electric currents; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Klystrons; Modulators; Photons; Positrons; Storage rings; Positron accumulator rings; Linear accelerators

Authors: Nadji A., Flynn G., Laclare J.-L., Level M.-P., Nghiem P., Payet J.
Title: Energy acceptance and Touschek lifetime calculations for the SOLEIL project
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France
Authors with affiliations: Nadji, A., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Flynn, G., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Laclare, J.-L., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Level, M.-P., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Nghiem, P., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France; Payet, J., DRIF Cent Natl de la Recherche, Scientifique, Gif sur Yvette, France
Abstract: Touschek scattering is an important beam lifetime limiting effect for the SOLEIL storage ring and the dominant one for high single bunch current operation. The Touschek relevant energy acceptance may be determined by the radiofrequency system, dynamic aperture or vacuum chamber physical aperture. In the latter two cases, Touschek induced betatron oscillations must be considered. We present energy acceptance and Touschek lifetime calculations for SOLEIL in the presence of these three limitations taking into account the non-linear chromatic orbit as well as energy variation of the optical functions. In light of these considerations, Touschek lifetime lattice optimization will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Computational methods; Mathematical models; Optimization; Oscillations; Particle beam dynamics; Chromaticity; Dynamic aperture; Particle energy; Touschek lifetime; Touschek scattering; Vacuum chamber physical aperture; Storage rings

Authors: Shoji Y., Ando A., Tanaka H., Takao M., Soutome K.
Title: Ring `New SUBARU'
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Himeji Inst of Technology, Hyogo-ken, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shoji, Y., Himeji Inst of Technology, Hyogo-ken, Japan; Ando, A., Himeji Inst of Technology, Hyogo-ken, Japan; Tanaka, H., Himeji Inst of Technology, Hyogo-ken, Japan; Takao, M., Himeji Inst of Technology, Hyogo-ken, Japan; Soutome, K., Himeji Inst of Technology, Hyogo-ken, Japan
Abstract: The longitudinal radiation excitation is a diffusion process in time axis which came from the stochastic fluctuation of where the photo-emission takes place. Usually this radiation excitation hides behind the well-known radiation excitation of energy spread. However in a quasi-isochronous ring, it dominates over the bunch stretch owing to the radiation excitation of energy spread. We give an analytical expression for the equilibrium state within linear optics including this excitation. Some consequencies of this excitation is calculated using parameters of New SUBARU.
Index Keywords: Particle optics; Photoemission; Quasi-isochronous rings; Radiation excitation; Storage rings

Authors: Eto Akira, Hidaka Mitsumori, Okuyama Yutaka, Kimura Katsutaka, Hosono Masayuki
Title: Impact of neutron flux on soft errors in MOS memories
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Hitachi, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Eto, Akira, Hitachi, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Hidaka, Mitsumori, Hitachi, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Okuyama, Yutaka, Hitachi, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Kimura, Katsutaka, Hitachi, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Hosono, Masayuki, Hitachi, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Investigation of the effect of neutrons on MOS memory devices showed that such devices are sensitive to neutrons. Neutron irradiation of DRAMs and SRAMs caused bit errors due to soft errors; however, no errors occurred in FRAMs and flash memories. The irradiation of alpha-rays caused only single-bit-errors, but when neutrons were irradiated, both single-bit-errors and adjacent multi-bit-errors (about 5% of the total) occurred on our results. Soft errors in RAM were estimated not to occur when the energy of the neutron particles is about 5 MeV or less. Two tendencies were identified between the error rate and the collected charge, depending on the device structures. In particular, presence of a triple-well played a significant role for lowering the error rate. Simulation using a simplified two-dimensional model produced results close to the experiment results, in terms of error mode and device configurations.
Index Keywords: Bit error rate; Computer simulation; Dynamic random access storage; Ferroelectric devices; MOS devices; Neutron irradiation; Radiation effects; Ferroelectric random access memory (FRAM); MOS memories; Static random access memory (SRAM); Semiconductor storage

Authors: Badawy I.
Title: Environmental impact of nuclear materials as radiation source
Source title: National Radio Science Conference, NRSC, Proceedings
Affiliations: Atomic Energy Authority, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Badawy, I., Atomic Energy Authority, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: The present investigation considers the major aspects of the production, use, storage, handling or transport and the environmental impact of nuclear materials - being considered as nuclear fuel and radiation source. Nowadays the nuclear power offers a significant contribution to the world's need of energy, the production of steam and desalinated water and many other applications. The national regulatory systems for nuclear and radiation safety are implemented in order to control the nuclear materials in all aspects. The study can show that the nuclear energy is almost free of gases causing environmental problems such as climate changes or acid rains. Also, the nuclear energy - being characterized by high energy densities in the processes - would utilize low quantities of nuclear materials and consequently of wastes. The occupational risks would be related mainly to accidents in mining and power production while public risks are relatively small.
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Materials handling; Occupational risks; Storage (materials); Radioactive materials handling; Radioactive materials storage; Radioactive materials transport; Radioactive materials

Authors: Einfeld D., Perez F., Rossmanith R., Walther R.
Title: ANKA injector
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Einfeld, D., Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, Germany; Perez, F., Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, Germany; Rossmanith, R., Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, Germany; Walther, R., Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: ANKA is a 2.5 GeV synchrotron radiation storage ring under construction at the Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe in Germany. The beam is accelerated up to 0.5 GeV in a booster synchrotron and afterwards injected into ANKA. In ANKA the beam is accumulated to 200 mA (second stage: 400 mA) and afterwards accelerated to 2.5 GeV. The injector system will consist of a pre-injector with an end energy of 20 or 50 MeV, a booster synchrotron and transport channels. The booster synchrotron should be as simple and inexpensive as possible. In the following three different concepts for designing the booster synchrotron are compared.
Index Keywords: Particle beam dynamics; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Booster synchrotrons; Synchrotron radiation storage rings; Synchrotrons

Authors: Ebeling W., Maidment J.R.
Title: Proton synchrotron Desy III
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron, DESY, Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ebeling, W., Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron, DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Maidment, J.R., Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron, DESY, Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: Desy III is one link in the chain of injectors for HERA, the electron/positron - proton colliding beam storage ring. Because of the relatively low injection (kinetic) energy of 50 MeV space charge plays a significant role in determining the achievable accelerated current. The luminosity in HERA is critically dependent on the transverse beam brightness hence the need to examine, and where possible minimize, emittance blow-up. Measurements of the beam emittance as a function of intensity in Desy III and the derived incoherent space charge tune shift are presented and discussed. Finally some preliminary investigations with regard to upgrading the injection energy via a pre-booster are described.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electric space charge; Electron beams; Kinetic energy; Particle beam injection; Positrons; Storage rings; Luminosity; Synchrotrons

Authors: Khan S.
Title: Generation of sub-picosecond X-ray pulses at BESSY-II
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: BESSY-II, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Khan, S., BESSY-II, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Two methods to generate sub-picosecond x-ray pulses using the electron beam of the BESSY-II storage ring in combination with a femtosecond laser are discussed: (1) Thomson scattering of laser pulses crossing electron bunches at a small angle. (2) Energy-modulation of a short region within an electron bunch interacting with the laser in an undulator, and subsequent emission of synchrotron radiation.
Index Keywords: Electron scattering; Mathematical models; Synchrotrons; X rays; Thomson scattering; Storage rings

Authors: Pillai C., Stevens R.R., Fitzgerald D.H., Garnett R.W., Ingalls W.B., Merrill F.E., Rybarcyk L.J., Sander O.R.
Title: Performance of the LANSCE H- source and low energy beam transport at higher peak current
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
