Authors with affiliations: Pillai, C., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Stevens, R.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Fitzgerald, D.H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Garnett, R.W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Ingalls, W.B., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Merrill, F.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Rybarcyk, L.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Sander, O.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: The Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE) 800 MeV accelerator facility uses a multicusp-field, surface production ion source to produce H- beam for delivery to the Proton Storage Ring (PSR) and to the Weapon Neutron Research (WNR) areas. The average current delivered to the short-pulse spallation target is nominally 70 μA. One goal of the present PSR upgrade project is to increase the average beam current to 200 μA. This will be accomplished by a combination of increased repetition rate (from 20 Hz to 30 Hz), upgraded PSR bunchers, and a brighter H- ion source that is being designed to produce higher peak current with lower beam emittance. The present ion source and LEBT system were studied to investigate beam quality and performance at higher peak currents. Beam parameters from the ion source and in the LEBT at higher currents are compared to those for standard operating conditions.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Hydrogen; Ion beams; Ion sources; Particle beam dynamics; Protons; Storage rings; Low-energy beam transport (LEBT) systems; Particle accelerator accessories

Authors: Miyahara Y.
Title: Possibility of X-ray free electron laser with single crystal optical resonator for Bragg reflection
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyahara, Y., SPring-8, Hyogo, Japan
Abstract: Noting the X-ray reflection coefficient of a single crystal as high as 90% at a Bragg angle, a possibility of X-ray free electron laser in a storage ring was investigated. An optical resonator composed of four Si single crystal mirrors with diffraction angle 45 degrees provides a light beam size in the optical resonator about 30 μm rms at a wavelength of 0.217 nm. Assuming an electron beam emittance of 46 pm-rad at a beam energy of 3 GeV, and a peak current of 1200 A, we obtain an FEL gain of 39% for an undulator with a number of periods of 300, which is slightly higher than the radiation loss in the mirrors. At the same time a conceptual design of a storage ring with such a small emittance beam is presented.
Index Keywords: Crystal resonators; Electromagnetic wave reflection; Electron emission; Free electron lasers; Laser resonators; Reflection; Single crystals; X rays; Bragg reflection; Storage rings

Authors: Torikoshi M., Endo M., Kumada M., Noda K., Yamada S., Kawachi K.
Title: Plan of synchrotron light source for medical applications at NIRS
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Natl Inst of Radiological Sciences, Chiba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Torikoshi, M., Natl Inst of Radiological Sciences, Chiba, Japan; Endo, M., Natl Inst of Radiological Sciences, Chiba, Japan; Kumada, M., Natl Inst of Radiological Sciences, Chiba, Japan; Noda, K., Natl Inst of Radiological Sciences, Chiba, Japan; Yamada, S., Natl Inst of Radiological Sciences, Chiba, Japan; Kawachi, K., Natl Inst of Radiological Sciences, Chiba, Japan
Abstract: We are designing a synchrotron light source dedicated to medical applications including an intravenous coronary angiography for practical uses at a hospital. The synchrotron light source system is required to be compact for installation in a limited space of the hospital. The system is also required to be operated easily as medical diagnostic devices. For the energy subtraction coronary angiography, required design parameters of a storage ring are circumference of about 45 m, 1.8 GeV electron energy and a stored beam currents of 400 mA. A multipole wiggler with superconducting coils is considered to be one of key devices to realize a required high photon intensity. A microtron with higher energy than that of commercially obtainable ones could be a good candidate of an injector for downsizing the whole system. Two optional beam lines are planned to be used for clinical diagnoses, and other beam lines of bending magnets are prepared for biology, physics, and other experiments to support the clinical diagnoses. We report the design of the compact system for the medical uses.
Index Keywords: Angiography; Light sources; Photons; Storage rings; Superconducting devices; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotron light source; Particle optics

Authors: Naito F., Akai K., Akasaka N., Ezura E., Kageyama T., Mizuno H., Nakanishi H., Takeuchi Y., Yamazaki Y., Kobayashi T.
Title: Coupling cavity damper for the ARES
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Naito, F., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Akai, K., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Akasaka, N., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Ezura, E., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Kageyama, T., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Mizuno, H., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Nakanishi, H., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Takeuchi, Y., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Yamazaki, Y., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan; Kobayashi, T., KEK, High Energy Accelerator, Research Organization, Tsukuba, Japan
Abstract: The coaxial (WX120D) antenna damper has been developed for damping the parasitic 0 and π modes of the KEKB ARES cavity. It is installed in the coupling cavity of the ARES. The damper consists of a disk-type coaxial ceramic window and a cross stub angle. The damper has a broadband rf property in order to absorb the rf power of the parasitic modes. The cross angle is utilized for supplying the cooling water to the antenna. The damper was designed by using a computer simulation code without a cold model test. Finally the properties of the damper has been confirmed by the high-power and the beam test for the ARES cavity.
Index Keywords: Antennas; Cavity resonators; Ceramic materials; Computer aided design; Computer simulation; Cooling water; Damping; Energy absorption; Coupling cavity dampers; Storage rings

Authors: Patteri P., Baldini R., Bini C.
Title: Asymmetric linac-ring collider for baryon timelike form factor measurements with existing high energy storage rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Patteri, P., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Baldini, R., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy; Bini, C., INFN-LNF, Frascati, Italy
Abstract: It is considered the possibility of using a positron storage ring like CESR and a low emittance, high duty cycle electron linac or a CW racetrack microtron of 100-200 MeV to realize an asymmetric collider providing a luminosity L approximately 1030 cm-2s-1. A suitable linac can be based on the superconducting modules developed for the TESLA Test Facility (TTF) at DESY or for CEBAF at TJ Laboratory. The microtron option can be developed similarly to the existing first 2-stage of the Mainz microtron or based on the studies for the RTM of NIST/LANL in late 80's.
Index Keywords: Linear accelerators; Microtrons; Positrons; Storage rings; Superconducting devices; Racetrack microtrons; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Minty M.G.
Title: Low-level RF system design for the next linear collider damping rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SLAC, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Minty, M.G., SLAC, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The design current for the Next Linear Collider (NLC) damping rings is an order of magnitude higher than existing damping rings. As opposed to storage rings, damping rings are required to operate at a high repetition frequency. Transient beam loading is therefore particularly severe. The NLC design calls for a full current fill pattern consisting of up to 4 trains of 90 bunches for a total dc current of 1.2 A. However, using conventional filling techniques, with a rapid current ramp the ring energy acceptance could decrease due to transient loading and the beam might not be captured. In this paper we describe two features of the low-level rf system design. The first avoids any reduction of duty cycle while the second ensures beam capture and regulation of the cavity voltages and beam phase.
Index Keywords: Damping; Electric loads; Linear accelerators; Current fill pattern; Damping rings; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Minty M.G., Akre R., Decker F.J., Turner J.
Title: Operation and performance of bunch precompression for increased current transmission at the SLC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: SLAC, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Minty, M.G., SLAC, Stanford, United States; Akre, R., SLAC, Stanford, United States; Decker, F.J., SLAC, Stanford, United States; Turner, J., SLAC, Stanford, United States
Abstract: As the beam currents at the SLC are increased, transverse aperture restrictions in the ring-to-linac transport line (RTL) become increasingly important. The RTL contains a bunch compressor which introduces a large energy variation across the bunch and hence a larger transverse beam size. Since 1994 the compressor amplitude has been operating at higher than design voltage. While advantageous for shaping the bunch distribution, this increased the bunch energy spread and therefore resulted in more beam loss. Moreover, due to current-dependent bunch lengthening in the damping ring, the higher the beam current, the more the current loss. To avoid such losses, the bunch length may be precompressed in the damping ring. Until recently, bunch precompression with high beam currents was not stable. In this paper we identify the reasons for the difficulties, describe the changes made to accommodate bunch precompression, and discuss performance aspects after implementation. The estimated increase in current at the interaction point is 15%.
Index Keywords: Linear accelerators; Storage rings; Bunch precompression; Particle beam dynamics

Authors: Chen C.S., Chen Jenny, Chen J.S., Wang C.J., Liu K.B., Liu C.Y., Sheu J.T., Hsu K.T.
Title: New power supply control interface and energy ramping design in SRRC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, C.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chen, Jenny, Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chen, J.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Wang, C.J., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Liu, K.B., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Liu, C.Y., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Sheu, J.T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hsu, K.T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: For the purpose of lattice optimization, eighteen individual quadrupole power supplies was installed in the SRRC storage ring in March 1997 to replace the three quadrupole family power supplies. In order to accommodate newly installed and already existed power supplies, the control interface of Taiwan Light Source (TLS) has been rejuvenated recently. The new control interface has improved drastically on control speed in comparison with the existed interface. Operation of the power supply system from device level to system level is reorganized to make control and access easier. This new control interface provides capability from complex operation such as lattice file loading, magnet degaussing, to file energy ramping scheme, etc. Performance of this power supply control interface including hardware components and software applications is presented.
Index Keywords: Computer hardware; Computer software; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Interfaces (computer); Energy ramping; Magnet degaussing; Storage rings

Authors: Kobayashi T., Akai K., Akasaka N., Ezura E., Kageyama T., Mizuno H., Naito F., Nakanishi H., Sakai H., Takeuchi Y., Yamazaki Y.
Title: HOM characteristics of the ARES cavity
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kobayashi, T., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Akai, K., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Akasaka, N., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Ezura, E., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Kageyama, T., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Mizuno, H., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Naito, F., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Nakanishi, H., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Sakai, H., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Takeuchi, Y., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Yamazaki, Y., Tsukuba Univ, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: The ARES (Accelerator Resonantly coupled with an Energy Storage) cavity, which consists of three cells, has been developed for the KEK B-Factory, and two types of the ARES cavity have been constructed for the beam test. Both the types were installed in the KEK TRISTAN Accumulation Ring and beam-tested. The accelerating cell of the ARES has a HOM-damped structure to lower the impedance of HOM's in order to store a high current beam. The spectra excited by the beam (single bunch, 100mA) were measured for both the cavities with scanning of the resonant frequency. Basically these results are consistent with those of calculations. The HOM's appear to be damped as expected. But the actual spectra for three cells are more complicated than only the accelerating cell. During this experiment, however, any beam instabilities due to the impedance of the cavities were not observed. This paper describes only the `ARES95`- one of the two types of the ARES.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Equipment testing; Natural frequencies; Accelerator resonantly coupled with an energy storage (ARES); Higher-order mode (HOM); Storage rings

Authors: Mitsunobu S., Asano K., Furuya T., Ishi Y., Kijima Y., Sennyu K., Tajima T., Takahashi T., Zhao S.
Title: Status and development of superconducting cavity for KEKB
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mitsunobu, S., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Asano, K., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Furuya, T., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Ishi, Y., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Kijima, Y., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Sennyu, K., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Tajima, T., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Takahashi, T., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan; Zhao, S., KEK High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: After successful test of 500 mA (Max 573 mA) electron beam at TRISTAN Accumulation ring (AR) using a prototype superconducting cavity, more than 4 superconducting cavities will be installed in high energy ring (HER) of KEK B-factory. The initial 4 superconducting cavities are almost same as the prototype one. The tests and results of the critical components of superconducting cavity system is described.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Electron beams; Superconducting devices; Accumulation rings; Superconducting accelerator cavities; Storage rings

Authors: Ohkawa T., Katayama T.
Title: Design of booster synchrotron for MUSES
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: RIKEN, Saitama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohkawa, T., RIKEN, Saitama, Japan; Katayama, T., RIKEN, Saitama, Japan
Abstract: The Booster Synchrotron Ring (BSR) is a part of Multi-USe Experimental Storage rings (MUSES). BSR functions exclusively for the acceleration of ion and electron beams. The maximum accelerating energy is, for example, to be 3 GeV for proton; 1.45 GeV/nucleon for light ions of q/A = 1/2; 800 MeV/nucleon for heavy ions of q/A = 1/3. Electron beam is accelerated to 2.5 GeV from the injection energy 300 MeV. The accelerated ion and electron beams will be fast extracted and injected into the Double Storage Rings (DSR) by one turn injection. As another operation mode, ion beams will be slowly extracted for the experiments. In this paper, results of lattice study and injection and extraction procedures of the BSR are presented.
Index Keywords: Electron beams; Heavy ions; Ion beams; Particle beam dynamics; Particle beam extraction; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Booster synchrotron rings (BSR); Multi-use experimental storage rings (MUSES); Synchrotrons

Authors: Sasaki Shigemi, Schlueter Ross, Marks Steve
Title: Crossed elliptical polarization undulator
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sasaki, Shigemi, Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Schlueter, Ross, Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States; Marks, Steve, Lawrence Berkeley Natl Lab, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: The first switching of polarization direction is possible by installing two identical helical undulators in series in a same straight section in a storage ring. By setting each undulator in a circular polarization mode in opposite handedness, one can obtain linearly polarized radiation with any required polarization direction depending on the modulator setting between two undulators. This scheme can be used without any major degradation of polarization degree in any low energy low emittance storage ring.
Index Keywords: Light polarization; Particle optics; Synchrotron radiation; Elliptical polarization undulator (EPU); Storage rings

Authors: Singh O., Krinsky S.
Title: Orbit compensation for the time-varying elliptically polarized wiggler with switching frequency at 100 hz
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, O., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Krinsky, S., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: In October 1996, the elliptically polarized wiggler, installed in the X13 straight section of the NSLS X-ray ring, was commissioned at an operating frequency of 100 hz. This wiggler generates circularly polarized photons in the energy range of 0.1 to 10 keV with AC modulation of polarization helicity. The vertical magnetic field is produced by a hybrid permanent magnet structure, and the horizontal magnetic field is generated by an electromagnet capable of switching at frequencies up to 100 hz. Here, we discuss the compensation of the residual vertical and horizontal orbit motion utilizing a time-domain algorithm employing a function generator to drive trim coils at the wiggler ends, and the wideband high precision orbit measurement system of the X-ray ring. The residual orbit motion has been reduced to a level below 1 micron, and the device has been run in regular operations with no negative effect on other users.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Light polarization; Magnetic fields; Permanent magnets; Photons; Time domain analysis; X rays; Time-varying elliptically polarized wigglers; Storage rings

Authors: Letourneau Claude, Rouillard Jean, Choquette Yves, Worboys David C.
Title: Progress in lithium polymer battery development for telecommunication system
Affiliations: ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Letourneau, Claude, ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada; Rouillard, Jean, ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada; Choquette, Yves, ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada; Worboys, David C., ARGO-TECH Productions Inc, Boucherville, Canada
Abstract: This paper is the second of a series describing the development of a new battery technology for use as an energy storage system in telecommunications applications. Lithium Polymer Battery (LPB) promises to be the next generation power source. This paper describes the LPB energy storage system, including battery module thermal management and monitoring & control devices. Lab cells in the range of 7 Ah capacity and prototype battery modules of 24 V and 80 Ah capacity were built and tested. Also discussed is the battery module design flexibility which allows for various battery string configurations.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Plastic products; Product design; Telecommunication systems; Lithium polymer batteries; Lithium batteries

Authors: Wisnivesky D., Rafael F.S., Bagnato O.R., Picoli R.A., Lira A.C., Silva A.R., Pardine C.
Title: Upgrading of the LNLS injection system
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron - LNLS/CNPq, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Wisnivesky, D., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron - LNLS/CNPq, Campinas, Brazil; Rafael, F.S., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron - LNLS/CNPq, Campinas, Brazil; Bagnato, O.R., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron - LNLS/CNPq, Campinas, Brazil; Picoli, R.A., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron - LNLS/CNPq, Campinas, Brazil; Lira, A.C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron - LNLS/CNPq, Campinas, Brazil; Silva, A.R., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron - LNLS/CNPq, Campinas, Brazil; Pardine, C., Laboratorio Nacional de Luz, Sincrotron - LNLS/CNPq, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: The energy of the injection linac and transport line into the LNLS synchrotron storage ring will be increased to 170 MeV by doubling the microwave power of the linac. The new system will operate with 4 klystrons, delivering 25 MW pulses into each one of 4 accelerating SLAC-type structures. This paper describes the design and construction and tests of 2 new klystron modulators, microwave drive system, waveguides, as well as the upgrading of the power supplies for the linac and transport line magnets.

Authors: Yano Y., Goto A., Katayama T.
Title: RIKEN RI-Beam Factory project
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: RIKEN, Saitama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yano, Y., RIKEN, Saitama, Japan; Goto, A., RIKEN, Saitama, Japan; Katayama, T., RIKEN, Saitama, Japan
Abstract: The RIKEN Accelerator Research Facility (RARF) has proposed the `RI-Beam Factory' project. In 1997 fiscal year, the construction budget for the first phase of this project has been formally approved. The factory is aimed at providing the world's most intense RI (radioisotope) beams at energies of several hundreds MeV/nucleon over the whole range of atomic masses. RI beams will be generated by the projectile frag-mentation. For the efficient generation a cascade of a K930-MeV ring cyclotron and a K2500-MeV super-conducting ring cyclotron will boost the energy of heavy-ion beams from the existing ring cyclotron up to 400 MeV/nucleon for light ions and more than 100 MeV/nucleon for very heavy ions. Moreover, this factory includes a next generation of the multi-use experimental storage rings (MUSES) consisting of an accumulator-cooler ring, a booster synchrotron ring and double storage rings. The MUSES will enable us to conduct various types of unique colliding experiments.
Index Keywords: Cyclotrons; Particle beam dynamics; Radioisotopes; Storage rings; Superconducting devices; Synchrotrons; Multiuse experimental storage rings (MUSES); Superconducting ring cyclotrons; Particle accelerators

Authors: Jacobs K., Averill R., Bradley S., Dodson G., Dow K., Farkhondeh M., Kowalski S., McAllister B., Tieger D., Tschalaer C., Tsentalovich E., Turchinetz W., Wang F., Zolfaghari A., Zwart T.
Title: High duty factor beams extracted from the MIT-Bates South Hall Ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jacobs, K., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Averill, R., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Bradley, S., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Dodson, G., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Dow, K., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Farkhondeh, M., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Kowalski, S., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; McAllister, B., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Tieger, D., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Tschalaer, C., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Tsentalovich, E., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Turchinetz, W., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Wang, F., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Zolfaghari, A., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States; Zwart, T., MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Cent, United States
Abstract: The South Hall Ring at the MIT-Bates Linear Accelerator Center is a combination of pulse stretcher ring to produce high duty factor extracted beams and storage ring for use with internal targets. It is designed to operate at energies from 300 MeV to 1 GeV for nuclear physics experiments. In pulse stretching mode, half-integer resonant extraction is used to convert the <1% duty factor beam from the linac into near CW beam. To date, we have extracted beams with duty factors in excess of 50%, and high throughput efficiencies. The first nuclear physics experiments using extracted beam are planned for the near future. Details of commissioning the ring for extracted beam operation are presented.
Index Keywords: High duty factor beams; Pulse stretcher; Nuclear physics; Particle beam extraction; Linear accelerators

Authors: Luo Gwo-Huei, Chang Peace, Hsu K.T., Chen Jenny, Kuo C.C., Lin Y.K., Sah R.C., Liu Y.C.
Title: 1.5 GeV operation parameters and performance at SRRC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Luo, Gwo-Huei, Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chang, Peace, Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Hsu, K.T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chen, Jenny, Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Kuo, C.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lin, Y.K., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Sah, R.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Liu, Y.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: The storage ring at SRRC is highly promising as an ultra-violet to soft x-ray radiation source for use in basic research and industrial applications. Energy ramping of the storage ring can push the critical photon energy to the edge of hard x-ray. The tune drifting, during the ramping procedure, is expected and should be minimized such that the beam can survive through the ramping process. The betatron frequencies and the ramping function of magnets were carefully monitored in order to avoid the betatron tunes cross fatal resonance line. A successful ramping results and lattice parameters were measured and discussed in this paper. The measured photon flux increased by six to seven folds at the x-ray beam line. Life time reaches 9 hours of 200 mA beam current.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Betatrons; Lattice constants; Particle beam dynamics; Photons; Synchrotron radiation; Ultraviolet radiation; X rays; Energy ramping; Storage rings

Abstract: The ATF Damping Ring (ATF DR) aims to demonstrate the technical feasibility of a low-energy part of next-generation electron-positron linear colliders by producing an electron bunch train with extremely small emittance. To diagnose the beam profile and radiation damping there, a synchrotron radiation (SR) monitor which uses visible light has been designed and built. This paper presents the system configuration of this SR monitor and the preliminary results from the initial beam commissioning.
Index Keywords: Electron emission; Linear accelerators; Positrons; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Accelerator test facility (ATF) damping rings; Synchrotron radiation (SR) monitors; Colliding beam accelerators

Abstract: The High Energy Ring of the PEP-II B-Factory has been constructed in the PEP tunnel. It is now beginning beam commissioning. This report will address the status of the ring systems and our experience in commissioning the systems as well as the first beam running.

Authors: Tallerico Paul J., Reass William A.
Title: Modulator considerations for the SNS RF system
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tallerico, Paul J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Reass, William A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: The Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) is an intense neutron source for neutron scattering experiments. The project is in the research stage, with construction funding beginning next year. The SNS is comprised of an ion source, a 1000 MeV, H- linear accelerator, an accumulator ring, a neutron producing target, and experimental area to utilize the scattering of the neutrons. The linear accelerator is RF driven, and the peak beam current is 27 mA and the beam duty factor is 5.84%. The peak RF power required is 104 MW, and the H- beam pulse length is 0.97 ms at a 60 Hz repetition rate. The RF pulses must be about 0.1 ms longer than the beam pulses, due to the Q of the accelerating cavities, and the time required to establish control of the cavity fields. The modulators for the klystrons in this accelerator are discussed in this paper. The SNS is designed to be expandable, so the beam power can be doubled or even quadrupled in the future. One of the double-power options is to double the beam pulse length and duty factor. We are specifying the klystrons to operate in this twice-duty-factor mode, and the modulator also should be expandable to 2 ms pulses at 60 Hz. Due to the long pulse length and low RF frequency of 805 MHz, the klystron power is specified at 2.5 MW peak, and the RF system will have 56 klystrons at 805 MHz, and three 1.25 MW peak power klystrons at 402.5 MHz for the low energy portion of the accelerator. The low frequency modulators are conventional floating-deck modulation anode control systems.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Ion beams; Ion bombardment; Ion sources; Klystrons; Linear accelerators; Modulators; Neutron scattering; Storage rings; Targets; Floating deck modulation anode control systems; Spallation neutron sources (SNS); Neutron sources

Authors: Holmes Andrew D., Fang Jing
Title: Linear modelling and Fourier spectroscopy of stress-relaxation in the cervical spine
Source title: Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Holmes, Andrew D., Univ of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Fang, Jing, Univ of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: Single joints of the cervical spine were subject to axial compressive loads and the load relaxation recorded for 15 minutes. Isochronal plots of stress against strain were plotted for each specimen and showed high linear correlation coefficients (>0.955). Accordingly, a linear model was chosen and fitted to data obtained from a fuller range (3 hours) of the complete relaxation curve. The relaxation times extracted from this model were approximately 10 minutes and 5 hours. Fourier transform of the relaxation curve allows the storage modulus and the loss modulus of the relaxation spectrum to be shown separately as functions of frequency. Fourier analysis shows that the cervical spine has a wide and smooth distribution of relaxation times. Examination of the higher frequency components of the relaxation in the region of 1 to 20 Hz show the loss modulus to be almost flat and tending towards zero. This work shows that while the disc is capable of dissipating a large proportion of the applied strain energy, it can only do this slowly, and the discs of the cervical spine are inefficient as `shock absorbers' of axial loads.
Index Keywords: Bone; Fourier transforms; Joints (anatomy); Load testing; Mathematical models; Spectroscopic analysis; Strain; Stress analysis; Stress relaxation; Loss modulus; Storage modulus; Biomechanics

Authors: Harmon S.Y.
Title: Evaluating and comparing information systems
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Zetetix, Oak Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harmon, S.Y., Zetetix, Oak Park, United States
Abstract: This paper proposes that all information systems can be treated as thermodynamic engines, therefore their performance can be measured, evaluated and compared with observable thermodynamically-related properties. This proposition suggests a simple, parsimonious method for characterizing information systems using physically measurable properties to represent their performance. Measurements of these properties can compare, both absolutely and relatively, the performance of information systems performing identical tasks, independent of their designs. These measurements are realistically accessible, come at reasonable cost, and can be performed in an acceptable amount of time. This method derives directly from the physical dependencies between the energy-based and information-based worlds and explores the performance of entire systems as well as their individual components.
Index Keywords: Data storage equipment; Mathematical models; Systems analysis; Thermodynamic properties; Information systems; Thermodynamic engines; Information technology

Authors: Dikansky N.S., Parkhomchuk V.V., Petrov V.M., Shamovsky V.G., Smirnov A.N., Vobly P.D., Volkov V.N.

Authors with affiliations: Dikansky, N.S., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Parkhomchuk, V.V., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Petrov, V.M., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Shamovsky, V.G., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Smirnov, A.N., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Vobly, P.D., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Volkov, V.N., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: An alternative way to obtain a high energy electron beam applicable for the electron cooling is considered. An electron beam with an energy of 15 MV, a current of up to 1A, an energy spread of Δγ/γ to approximately 10-4, and ΔP⊥/P∥ to approximately 10-4 spread in a transverse momentum is provided to obtain electron cooling at the collider ENC for GSI storage ring. With these electron beam properties, electron cooling can be extended to heavy particles in a several GeV range energies per nucleon.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electron beams; Mathematical models; Electron cooling devices; Linear accelerators

Authors: Bertolini L., Behne D., Bowman J., Hathaway D., Kishiyama K., Mugge M., Swan T.
Title: Design of the linear non-evaporable getter pump for the PEP-II B Factory
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bertolini, L., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Behne, D., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Bowman, J., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Hathaway, D., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Kishiyama, K., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Mugge, M., Univ of California, Livermore, United States; Swan, T., Univ of California, Livermore, United States
Abstract: There are several regions in the PEP-II B Factory at SLAC that require distributed pumping to deal with large photo-desorbed gas loads or to produce very low pressures (<10-9 Torr). These regions include the Low Energy Ring Wiggler dump chambers, the transitions between the High Energy Ring arcs and straight sections, and most importantly the Interaction Region. We have designed a compact Non-Evaporable Getter pump using commercial getters that combines high pumping speed and high sorption capacity. We describe the design features of the NEG pumps, and our test results from prototype pumps. In addition, we discuss future variations of this style of NEG pump.
Index Keywords: Getters; Storage rings; Vacuum pumps; High energy ring arcs; Low energy ring wiggler dump chambers; Non-evaporable getter pump; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Kiselev A.V., Shiltsev V.D.
Title: Proposed intense positron source for TESLA based on HERA-e
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference

Authors with affiliations: Kiselev, A.V., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Shiltsev, V.D., Budker Inst of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: In this article we perform a general study of possible positron source for linear collider TESLA based on the HERA electron ring. 30 GeV electrons passing 10T wiggler can produce intense synchrotron radiation with characteristic energy of photons of about 6 MeV. High energy photons are converted to few-MeV positrons in a suitable target. The ability of such a source to fit for the TESLA requirements is discussed.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Elementary particle sources; Linear accelerators; Photons; Positrons; Storage rings; Superconducting devices; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Wigglers; Particle accelerator accessories

Authors: Sullivan M.
Title: B-factory interaction region design
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sullivan, M., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Abstract: High luminosity B-factories are generally high current (1-3 A) e+e- storage ring accelerators that operate at a center-of-mass energy equal to the mass of the Upsilon (4S) resonance (10.58 GeV). The high beam currents are achieved by storing a large number of bunches (several hundred to several thousand) into each beam. Two designs, the ones located at SLAC and KEK, also have asymmetric beam energies. This imparts a boost to the nearly stationary B mesons formed from the decay of the 4S resonance and allows precision vertex tracking detectors to look for a difference between the decay profiles of the matter and anti-matter B mesons, thereby observing a violation of CP. Bringing the stored beams into collision is one of the major challenges of any B-factory design. In order to achieve high luminosity the beams must be tightly focused. This pushes the final focusing elements close enough to the interaction point to be inside the solenoidal field of the physics detector. In addition, beam-related detector backgrounds from synchrotron radiation and scattered beam particles must be kept below an acceptable level. The major B-factory designs at Cornell University, KEK, and SLAC have all addressed these problems in various ways that depend on specific accelerator design decisions. This paper discusses the accelerator parameters and detector constraints that influence an interaction region (IR) design, as well as how the various IR designs address the challenges posed by a high luminosity B-factory.
Index Keywords: Particle beam dynamics; Particle beam tracking; Particle detectors; Synchrotron radiation; Interaction region; Vertex tracking detectors; Storage rings

Authors: Chang L.H., Wang Ch., Lau W.K., Kuo C.C.
Title: Effects of the Landau cavity on the electron beam
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, L.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Wang, Ch., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lau, W.K., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Kuo, C.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Cent, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: This paper presents the procedure and the formulas to analyze the effects of Landau cavity on the electron beam while the main RF system is operated on the compensated condition. It is shown that the maximal available current, determined by the phase instability limit, is reduced with Landau cavity. The model of `potential energy' is used for the calculations of the bunch length and the synchrotron frequency of the storage ring with double RF system. It is shown that the bunch length can be manipulated by tuning the resonance frequency of the passive Landau cavity, and the spread of synchrotron frequency can be induced by the addition of a Landau cavity.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Electric currents; Electron beams; Natural frequencies; Potential energy; Synchrotron radiation; Tuning; Landau cavity; Storage rings

Authors: Pietryka M., Gaydosh M.
Title: Survey and alignment of SLAC's B-factory
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pietryka, M., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Gaydosh, M., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: The survey and alignment of SLAC's B-factory injector and high energy ring will be complete in March 1997. Modern digital electronic surveying tools are contributing to new, efficient alignment procedures. A laser tracker was used to fiducialize almost 300 quadrupole magnets. Digital levels were used to pre-set base plate elevations. Theodolites with very accurate co-axial distance meters were used for everything from layout to 3D magnet positioning to network surveys, all in free stationing mode. A number of procedures and measurement results are outlined.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Digital electronic surveying; Linear accelerators

Authors: Takeda Seishi, Hayano H., Akemoto M., Naito T., Matsumoto H., Urakawa J., Oide K., Terunuma N., Kubo K., Hinode R., Korhonen T., Funahashi Y., Araki S., Kashiwagi S., Okugi T.
Title: Status of 1.54 GeV ATF linac
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takeda, Seishi, High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Hayano, H., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Akemoto, M., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Naito, T., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Matsumoto, H., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Urakawa, J., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Oide, K., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Terunuma, N., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Kubo, K., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Hinode, R., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Korhonen, T., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Funahashi, Y., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Araki, S., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Kashiwagi, S., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan; Okugi, T., High Energy Accelerator Research, Organization (KEK), Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: Accelerator Test Facility (ATF) consists of a 1.54 GeV S-band linac, a beam transport line, a damping ring and an extraction beam line. A beam commissioning of the linac was performed in November 1995. A single bunch and multi-bunch beam were accelerated up to 1.43 GeV at the end of the beam transport line. The beam experiments on high-gradient acceleration, structure BPM and multi-bunch energy compensation were performed after the beam commissioning. The operation of the linac was suspended from April 1996 for the construction of the damping ring. The operation of the linac was restarted from December 1996, and the beam commissioning of the damping ring was carried out in January 1997.
Index Keywords: Energy utilization; Storage rings; Damping rings; Energy compensation; Linear accelerators

Authors: Bailey R., Bordry F., Bottura L., Burla P., Collier P., Henrichsen K., Koutchouk J.P., Lauckner R., Parker R., Pett J., Proudlock P., Schmickler H., Schmidt R., Walckiers L., Wolf R.
Title: Dynamic effects and their control at the LHC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Bordry, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Bottura, L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Burla, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Collier, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Henrichsen, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Koutchouk, J.P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lauckner, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Parker, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Pett, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Proudlock, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Schmickler, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Schmidt, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Walckiers, L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Wolf, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Tune, chromaticity and orbit of the LHC beams have to be precisely controlled by synchronizing the magnetic field of quadrupole, sextupole and corrector magnets. This is a challenging task for an accelerator using superconducting magnets, whose field and field errors will have large dynamic effects. The accelerator physics requirements are tight due to the limited dynamic aperture and the large energy stored in the beams. The power converters need to be programmed in order to generate the magnetic functions with defined tolerances. During the injection process and the energy ramp the magnetic performance cannot be predicted with sufficient accuracy, and therefore real-time feedback systems based on magnetic measurements and beam observations are proposed. Beam measurements are used to determine a correction factor for some of the power converters. From magnetic measurements the excitation of small magnets to compensate the sextupolar (b3) and decapolar (b5) field components in the dipole magnets will be derived. To meet these requirements a deterministic control system is envisaged.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Energy storage; Error analysis; Error correction; Magnetic field effects; Magnetic variables measurement; Particle beam dynamics; Particle beam injection; Power converters; Superconducting magnets; Synchronization; Chromaticity; Dynamic aperture; Large hadron colliders (LHC); Colliding beam accelerators

Abstract: The proposed UK light Source DIAMOND has an operating energy of 3 GeV, with a current of 300 mA. With the full complement of insertion devices the energy loss per turn is greater than 2.25 MeV, and the required RF energy acceptance is greater than 3%, consequently an accelerating voltage of 5.1 MV is needed. Investigations using a warm cavity system for DIAMOND have been reported elsewhere, this paper discusses the advantages of using a superconducting RF system, and outlines a possible system arrangement that fulfils the requirements.

Title: Comparison of the destruction of E. Coli O157:H7 in ground beef using pulsed X-rays and gamma rays

Abstract: The University of Missouri-Columbia compared the effectiveness of pulsed X-rays for destruction of E. Coli O157:H7 in frozen ground beef and the use of gamma rays from a cobalt-60 radioisotopes. Results indicate that the pulsed X-ray sources have the same effect on E. Abstract: In this paper, the influence of a Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) unit on the performance of the Automatic Generation Control (AGC) system is investigated. A comprehensive mathematical model of a two area interconnected power system is developed, taking into account boiler dynamics and nonlinearities such as governor dead band and generator rate constraints (GRC). The gain settings of the governor control system are obtained by using a least square criterion of the performance index. The results of the simulation studies on a typical test system are presented and discussed.

Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Nanyang Technological Univ, Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Tan, Yoke Lin, Nanyang Technological Univ, Singapore, Singapore; Wang, Youyi, Nanyang Technological Univ, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: The transient stability control of a power system is a typical nonlinear control problem. Although many controller design approaches have been developed, most of the existing controllers are designed by using linear control theory. In this paper, a nonlinear robust controller for the excitation and thyristor-controlled superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit is proposed to enhance the transient stability of a power system with unknown or varying parameters like equivalent reactance of the transmission lines. The SMES unit is located near the generator bus terminal in a power system. Our simulation results demonstrate that the proposed controller can ensure transient stability of a single-machine-infinite-bus system under a large sudden fault that may occur near the generator bus terminal.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Electric lines; Electric power transmission; Nonlinear control systems; Robustness (control systems); Superconducting devices; System stability; Transients; Flexible AC transmission systems (FACTS); Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Electric power systems

Authors: Toyoda J., Saitoh H.
Title: Proposal of an Open-Electric-Energy-Network (OEEN) to realize cooperative operations of IOU and IPP
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Toyoda, J., Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Saitoh, H., Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: A new electric power network, called open electric energy network (OEEN), makes it possible for many types of dispersed generation plants owned by non-utility organizations to participate in an electric power market without disadvantages of existing power utilities and consumers. Elements of OEEN system are dispersed energy storage devices, load controllers and a data communication link. In OEEN system, a transaction power is treated as an energy package wrapped with an information tag. This concept is called electricity power packet.
Index Keywords: Competition; Computer simulation; Data communication systems; Electric energy storage; Electricity; Mathematical models; Power control; Electricity power packet (EPP); Lotka-Volterra competition model; Open electric energy network (OEEN); Electric utilities

Authors: Tsang M.W., Sutanto D.
Title: Control strategies to damp inter-area oscillations using a Battery Energy Storage System
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Tsang, M.W., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hung Hom, Hong Kong; Sutanto, D., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Abstract: The paper will describe our investigation of several control strategies for use with a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) to damp inter-area oscillation, such as PI controllers and novel artificial intelligence control techniques utilizing fuzzy logic controller to modulate the active and reactive power output of the BESS. Preliminary studies show that both types of controllers can provide significant damping. Fuzzy logic controllers can provide superior performance in its ability to damp machine oscillation. The use of bus voltage signals to control the reactive power output of the BESS is found to provide very little damping.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Damping; Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Electric potential; Fuzzy control; Fuzzy sets; Modulation; Oscillations; Power control; Battery energy storage systems (BESS); Electric power systems

Authors: Leung K.K., Sutanto D.
Title: New topology of a Battery Energy Storage System
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Leung, K.K., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hung Hom, Hong Kong; Sutanto, D., Hong Kong Polytechnic Univ, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper will describe a new topology of a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) that can provide simultaneously fast control of both its MW and MVAr outputs to improve power system operation and control. The proposed BESS topology also provides several other important contributions to the power systems such as active harmonic filtering to meet power quality standards, load leveling, damping of inter-area oscillations, damping of transient stability, effective and fast control of power flow along a transmission line corridor, many of the Flexible AC Transmission System (FACTS) features, and emergency supply on loss of AC source (very similar to UPS applications). This paper shows that BESS can offer an important resource for improving power system control.
Index Keywords: Damping; Electric batteries; Electric lines; Electric loads; Electric network topology; Electric power systems; Electric power transmission; Oscillations; Power control; Transients; Battery energy storage systems (BESS); Electric energy storage

Authors: Huang F., Nath Ganesh, Kow Q.T., Chua Y.K., Tan Y.H., Chong P.W.
Title: Capacitor energy powered voltage booster for crane operations in the case of transient power dip
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Huang, F., Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore; Nath, Ganesh, Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore; Kow, Q.T., Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore; Chua, Y.K., Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore; Tan, Y.H., Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore; Chong, P.W., Ngee Ann Polytechnic, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: In recent years it has been reported that the transient power dip, say 10 to approximately 40% power down for a duration of 60 to approximately 200 millisecond, has made serious damages to high power electric drives such as cranes operated in the Port of Singapore Authority. This paper presents a feasibility study of a capacitor energy powered voltage booster for crane operations in the case of transient power dip. The voltage booster consists of a monitor unit which is used to detect power dip and a Cuk converter. A charged capacitor is used as the input dc source of the converter. PSPICE is used to investigate various different operation conditions. A laboratory based prototype is constructed and tested. The experimental results are compared with the simulated ones.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Computer simulation; Cranes; DC motors; DC power transmission; Electric drives; Transients; Software package PSPICE; Voltage booster; Power converters

Authors: Ngamroo Issarachai, Mitani Yasunori, Tsuji Kiichiro
Title: LFC and stabilization of multi-area interconnected power system by decentralized control of a SMES and solid-state phase shifters
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ngamroo, Issarachai, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Mitani, Yasunori, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Tsuji, Kiichiro, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized direct tie-line power flow control strategy of a Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) and Solid-State Phase Shifter (SSPS) for Load Frequency Control (LFC) and power system stabilization in multi-area interconnected power systems. Simulation results distinctly exhibit that, under the occurrence of sudden load fluctuations or some disturbances in any areas, the proposed control strategy is capable of suppressing the area frequencies as well as stabilizing inter-area oscillations modes, simultaneously and effectively.
Index Keywords: Decentralized control; Electric energy storage; Electric frequency control; Electric load flow; Phase shifters; Power control; Superconducting devices; System stability; Solid-state phase shifter (SSPS); Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Electric power system interconnection

Authors: Rabbani M.G., Devotta J.B.X., Elangovan S.
Title: Fuzzy controlled SMES unit for power system application
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Natl Univ of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Rabbani, M.G., Natl Univ of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; Devotta, J.B.X., Natl Univ of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; Elangovan, S., Natl Univ of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: This paper presents a new approach to control Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) unit for power system application. The SMES unit is used to improve the dynamic performance of P-f and Q-V loops of a power system. Two independent fuzzy controllers are assigned, one for the frequency control and another for the voltage control. Speed deviation (Δω) and acceleration of a synchronous generator are taken as the input signals to the Fuzzy Frequency Controller (FFC). The terminal voltage deviation (ΔVt) and its derivative are considered as the inputs to the Fuzzy Voltage Controller (FVC). To get the maximum benefit from the SMES unit, a supplementary control is generated by using the output of FFC and the inductor current deviation (ΔIsm) as inputs. ΔIsm is also used as a negative feedback signal to ensure the SMES energy is restored to its predisturbance level. The desired P-modulation from the SMES is obtained by adding this supplementary control signal to the output of FFC while the output of the FVC is the desired Q-modulation. The effective use of the SMES unit is verified for small as well as large disturbances for a single machine infinite bus system, and simulation results are presented and discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric frequency control; Fuzzy control; Superconducting devices; Synchronous generators; Voltage control; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Electric power systems

Authors: Egelhoff Jr. W.F., Chen P.J., Powell C.J., Parks D., McMichael R.D., Judy J.H., Martien D., Berkowitz A.E., Daughton J.M.
Title: Optimizing GMR spin valves: the outlook for improved properties
Source title: Biennial IEEE International Nonvolatile Memory Technology Conference
Affiliations: Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Egelhoff Jr., W.F., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Chen, P.J., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Powell, C.J., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Parks, D., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; McMichael, R.D., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Judy, J.H., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Martien, D., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Berkowitz, A.E., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Daughton, J.M., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States
Abstract: The current generation of giant magnetoresistance (GMR) spin valves exhibits performance characteristics which are not quite as good as desired for ultrahigh-density nonvolatile memory applications. This paper addresses the scientific issues underlying the challenge of making major improvements in future generations of GMR spin valves, assesses the likelihood of making such improvements, and will outline some of the trade-offs in spin valve properties that will probably have to be made in memory applications. In our research on the underlying scientific issues, we have found that many of the magnetic and magnetoresistive properties of spin valves are strongly influenced by surface and interface effects occurring during film deposition. Some of the most important issues are the balance of surface and interface free energies, surface diffusion, interdiffusion at interfaces, low-temperature deposition, the use of surfactants to modify growth, and specular electron scattering at surfaces. In some cases, it is possible to control these factors or to use them to manipulate the growth or improve post-growth processing of spin valves to improve their magnetic and magnetoresistive properties. If research on these topics can be increased, it is very likely that major improvements can be made in the properties of future generations of GMR spin valves.
Index Keywords: Deposition; Electron scattering; Interdiffusion (solids); Interfacial energy; Magnetic films; Magnetic properties; Magnetization; Magnetoresistance; Surface properties; Giant magnetoresistance spin valves; Ultrahigh density nonvolatile memory; Nonvolatile storage

Authors: Chen G., Xu X., Poon C.C., Tam A.C.
Title: Laser-assisted microscale deformation of stainless steels and ceramics
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, G., School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Xu, X., School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Poon, C.C., School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Tam, A.C., School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Abstract: This work investigates deformation of stainless steel and ceramic specimens with a precision on the order of sub-micrometers by use of a pulsed laser beam as the energy source. Such a technique is useful, for example, in a process of removing distortions on magnetic head components for a better contact between the magnetic disk head and the hard disk surface. Experiments are conducted to study the bending behavior of stainless steel and ceramics due to laser irradiation. A pulsed Nd:YLF laser beam is used to scan over the specimen to create out-of-plane deformation. The amount of deformation from each laser scan is correlated with various laser and processing parameters. A theoretical model of the laser deformation process is presented based on thermo-elasticity/plasticity. The laser deformation process is explained as the result of the laser-induced non-uniform distribution of the residual strain. Numerical simulations are carried out to estimate the laser-induced temperature field, the residual stress field, and the amount of deformation of the specimen. These theoretical studies help to understand the complex phenomena involved in the pulsed laser deformation process.
Author Keywords: Curvature modification; Laser bending; Laser forming; Pulsed laser; Thermal stress; Thermo-mechanics
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Deformation; Hard disk storage; Laser beam effects; Neodymium lasers; Pulsed laser applications; Stainless steel; Laser forming; Ceramic materials

Authors: Tarasenko V.F., Baksht E.H., Lomaev M.I., Orlovskii V.M., Panchenko A.N., Sosnin E.A.
Title: Efficient non-chain chemical HF-lasers initiated by e-beam and self-sustained discharge
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: High Current Electronics Institute, 4, Akademicheskii av., Tomsk 634055, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Tarasenko, V.F., High Current Electronics Institute, 4, Akademicheskii av., Tomsk 634055, Russian Federation; Baksht, E.H., High Current Electronics Institute, 4, Akademicheskii av., Tomsk 634055, Russian Federation; Lomaev, M.I., High Current Electronics Institute, 4, Akademicheskii av., Tomsk 634055, Russian Federation; Orlovskii, V.M., High Current Electronics Institute, 4, Akademicheskii av., Tomsk 634055, Russian Federation; Panchenko, A.N., High Current Electronics Institute, 4, Akademicheskii av., Tomsk 634055, Russian Federation; Sosnin, E.A., High Current Electronics Institute, 4, Akademicheskii av., Tomsk 634055, Russian Federation
Abstract: Non-chain HF lasers initiated by electric discharge and e-beam are described. A generator with an inductive energy storage and semiconducting opening switch was used for discharge formation. The generator was shown to be very promising for development of efficient discharge HF lasers with high output energy. It produces very uniform discharge in SF6-H2(C3H8) gas mixtures at elevated pressure and increases its stability. Discharge HF laser efficiency up to 5,5% was demonstrated. Radially convergent e-beam was used to pump 30 1 HF laser. Optimal gas mixture SF6:H2 = 8:1 under pressure of 0.45 atm was chosen to provide no more that two-fold specific output power variations across the laser beam area. Output energy as high as 115 J and efficiency with respect to e-beam energy deposited into gas mixture up to 7-8% were demonstrated. Total laser energy and efficiency with respect to deposited energy at pressure of 1.1 atm when the output distribution was non-uniform were found to be up to 200 J and 11%, respectively. The "jump" of pressure in SF6-H2 mixture at the instance of e-beam injection was found to be lower than that in excimer laser mixtures due to SF6 high density. This simplifies creation of wide-aperture e-beam HF-lasers. We expect that the use of pulse generators and wide-aperture laser setup available at HCEI enable us to develop 1 kJ non-chain HF laser initiated either by self-sustained discharge or e-beam.
Author Keywords: Discharge non-chain HF lasers; e-beam; Generator with inductive energy storage; High efficiency; Semiconducting opening switch
Index Keywords: Electric discharges; Electron beams; Energy storage; Excimer lasers; Gas lasers; Magnetic field effects; Pumping (laser); Semiconducting opening switches; Chemical lasers

Authors: Refsland S.T., Ojika T., Stone R.
Title: Development of a chaotic environment engine for dynamic virtual world heritage environments
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Authors with affiliations: Refsland, S.T., Intl. Soc. Virtual Syst. MultiMedia, Virtual System Laboratory, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Ojika, T., Intl. Soc. Virtual Syst. MultiMedia, Virtual System Laboratory, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan; Stone, R., Intl. Soc. Virtual Syst. MultiMedia, Virtual System Laboratory, Gifu University, Gifu, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the development of a Chaotic Environment Engine for the multiplexed management of Dynamic Virtual World Heritage Environments. The Chaotic Environment Engine enables immersive, networked environments to be complex, allowing real-time processing of relationships between 1) many-to-many users, 2) users, artificial life and data storage, 3) virtual environmental hydrology, 4) many-to many-environments, and 5) the aggregate relationship between users, artificial life and environments. The Chaotic Environment Engine is similar to a multiplexing system, yet extended to process communication protocols between humans, artificial life, machines and environments. This research is currently a work in progress and is the first stage of a larger, international project to develop an interactive, Virtual World Heritage Network using advanced virtual reality and multimedia technologies.
Author Keywords: Artificial life; Dynamic virtual reality environments; Emergent energy; World heritage
Index Keywords: Chaos theory; Computer networks; Ecology; Ecosystems; Human engineering; Multimedia systems; Network protocols; Real time systems; Systems analysis; Artificial life; Dynamic virtual reality environments; Emergent energy; Multiplexed management; World heritage; Virtual reality

Abstract: Two different types of sensors were fabricated and evaluated. The evaluation showed that their performance is similar. The local differential version is somewhat better in terms of static noise but loses in sensitivity and dissipation. The global uses less area and power and is less susceptible to substrate noise.

Abstract: The variation of thermal, optical and dynamic properties, and their correlation to microstructure in nitrogen-doped Ge2Sb2Te5 phase-change recording media was investigated. The addition of optimum amount of nitrogen in Ge-Sb-Te alloy increased the crystallization temperatures and activation energy barrier against crystallization. The phase change optical disks led to an enhanced recording sensitivity, extended data retention time, and reduced overwrite jitter resulting in longer media cyclability in pulse width modulation (PWM) recording.

Authors: Borovkov V.V., Voronov S.L., Lazhintsev B.V., Nor-Arevyan V.A., Feodorov G.I.
Title: Three-electrode CO2-laser with a middle control electrode
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Abstract: There was developed a three-electrode discharge CO2-laser of atmospheric pressure. The discharge in the gaps was ignited sequentially in time at the application of high-voltage pulse to the middle control electrode. A storage capacitor of the main discharge is connected directly to the other two electrodes. The system and the operation method allow to form the discharge with the input energy up to 250 J/1-atm with 11,5 % laser efficiency. The voltage on the main laser electrodes before the discharge ignition was in the range of 0.6...0.9 of the static breakdown voltage for the laser medium. The energy for the discharge formation was only 1...3% of the stored pump energy. Such system and the operation method can reduce by tens of times the load on the switches in the CO2-laser.

Authors: Nakagawa Masahiro
Title: Periodic chaos neural network with autocorrelation dynamics
Source title: International Conference on Knowledge-Based Intelligent Electronic Systems, Proceedings, KES
Affiliations: Nagaoka Univ of Technology, Niigata, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakagawa, Masahiro, Nagaoka Univ of Technology, Niigata, Japan
Abstract: In this paper a novel chaos neural network model is proposed and applied to memory search and the autoassociation. The proposed artificial neuron model is substantially characterized in terms of a time-dependent periodic activation function to involve a chaotic dynamics on the basis of the energy steepest descent strategy. It is elucidated that the present neural network has an ability of the dynamic memory retrievals beyond the conventional models with the nonmonotonous activation function as well as such a monotonous activation function as sigmoidal one. This advantage results from the nonmonotonous property of the analogue periodic mapping accompanied with a chaotic behaviour of the neurons. It is also found that the present analogue neuron model with the periodicity control has a remarkably large memory capacity in comparison with the previously proposed association models.
Index Keywords: Associative storage; Chaos theory; Correlation methods; Dynamics; Functions; Mathematical models; Autocorrelation dynamics; Chaos neural networks; Neural networks

Authors: Sun Fengchun, Zhang Chengning, Guo Haitao
Title: Battery management system with state of charge indicator for electric vehicles

Authors with affiliations: Sun, Fengchun, Beijing Inst of Technology, Beijing, China; Zhang, Chengning, Beijing Inst of Technology, Beijing, China; Guo, Haitao, Beijing Inst of Technology, Beijing, China
Abstract: On the basis of analyzing the electro-chemical characteristics of lead-acid battery, the state of charge indicator for lead-acid battery was developed by means of an algorithm based on combination of ampere-hour, Peukert's equation and open-voltage method with the compensation of temperature, aging, self-discharging, etc. The BMS based on this method can attain an accurate surplus capacity which error is less than 5% in static experiments. It is proved by experiments that the BMS is reliable and can give the driver an accurate surplus capacity, precisely monitor the individual battery modules as the same time, even detect and warn the problems early. A BMS can make the energy of the storage batteries used efficiently, develop the batteries cycle life and increase the driving distance of electric vehicles.

Authors: Matheron C., Delort A.-M., Gaudet G., Forano E.
Title: In vivo 13C NMR study of glucose and cellobiose metabolism by four cellulolytic strains of the genus Fibrobacter
Affiliations: Lab. Synt., Electsynt. Etud. S., UMR 6504 Univ. Blaise Pascal, CNRS, 63177 Aubière Cedex, France; Laboratoire de Microbiologie, INRA, Ctr. Rech. de Clermont-Ferrand-Theix, 63122 Saint-Genès-Champanelle, France
Authors with affiliations: Matheron, C., Lab. Synt., Electsynt. Etud. S., UMR 6504 Univ. Blaise Pascal, CNRS, 63177 Aubière Cedex, France; Delort, A.-M., Lab. Synt., Electsynt. Etud. S., UMR 6504 Univ. Blaise Pascal, CNRS, 63177 Aubière Cedex, France; Gaudet, G., Laboratoire de Microbiologie, INRA, Ctr. Rech. de Clermont-Ferrand-Theix, 63122 Saint-Genès-Champanelle, France; Forano, E., Laboratoire de Microbiologie, INRA, Ctr. Rech. de Clermont-Ferrand-Theix, 63122 Saint-Genès-Champanelle, France
Abstract: The metabolism of glucose and cellobiose, products of cellulose hydrolysis, was investigated in four cellulolytic strains of the genus Fibrobacter: Fibrobacter succinogenes S85, 095, HM2 and Fibrobacter intestinalis NR9. In vivo 13C nuclear magnetic resonance was used to quantify the relative contribution of glucose and cellobiose to metabolite production, glycogen storage and cellodextrins synthesis in these four strains. The same features were found in all four strains of the genus Fibrobacter metabolizing simultaneously glucose and cellobiose: i) differential metabolism of glucose and cellobiose; glucose seems preferentially used for glycogen storage and energy production, while part of cellobiose seems to be diverted from glycolysis, ii) synthesis of cellodextrins, mainly from cellobiose not entering into glycolysis, iii) accumulation of glucose 6-phosphate, iv) simultaneous presence of cellobiose phosphorylase and cellobiase activities. Although genetically diverse, the Fibrobacter genus appears to possess a marked homogeneity in its carbon metabolism.

Abstract: Electrical codes and standards that apply specifically to rural applications are reviewed. These include applications to grain bins, storage structures, irrigation pump motors, oil pumps, other motor applications, animal confinement buildings, and wet or corrosive installations. Abstract: The design and breadboard implementation of a constant-frequency, zero-voltage-switched, full-bridge pulsewidth modulation converter delivering a 12-V-at-l-kW output from a 350-450-Vdc input bus is described. The zero-voltage switching characteristic is maintained over a wide operating range by utilizing the transformer magnetizing inductance as an energy storage element. Output voltage regulation is accomplished entirely on the secondary side through magamp control, thus simplifying the methods used for maintaining control and isolation. © 1998 IEEE.

Title: Program transformation strategies for memory size and power reduction of pseudoregular multimedia subsystems
