Authors: Cenkowski S., Ramanathan S., Scanlon M.G., Dexter J.E.
Title: Thermodynamic and functional properties of mechanically compacted flour
Affiliations: Department of Biosystems Engineering, 438 Engineering Building, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Man. R3T 5V6, Canada; Department of Food Science, Ellis Building, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Man. R3T 2N2, Canada; Grain Research Laboratory, Canadian Grain Commission, 1404-303 Main St., Winnipeg, Man. R3C 3G8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Cenkowski, S., Department of Biosystems Engineering, 438 Engineering Building, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Man. R3T 5V6, Canada; Ramanathan, S., Department of Biosystems Engineering, 438 Engineering Building, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Man. R3T 5V6, Canada; Scanlon, M.G., Department of Food Science, Ellis Building, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Man. R3T 2N2, Canada; Dexter, J.E., Grain Research Laboratory, Canadian Grain Commission, 1404-303 Main St., Winnipeg, Man. R3C 3G8, Canada
Abstract: Compaction of flour can be beneficial as it may prevent or slow down the diffusion of oxygen into the flour and thereby reduce enzymatic activity within the flour and infestation by mites and microorganisms. Also, the reduction in volume through compaction would facilitate relatively easier mechanical handling and reduce the space requirement for storage and transportation. The overall objective of this research was to determine whether mechanical compaction of flour would adversely effect its thermodynamic and functional properties. Two different grades of flour were used in this investigation: a low extraction (64%) patent flour and a high extraction (79%) straight grade flour. Loose flour was compacted mechanically, which corresponded to a reduction in flour volume of 55%, and exposed to sorption desorption tests. Dough prepared from treated (compacted and reconstituted) and loose flour was exposed to standard empirical and imitative rheological tests. The analysis involved determination of the sorption desorption characteristics, the specific area of the absorption sites, heat of sorption and desorption, free energy changes, and rheological tests including farinograph, mixograph, viscoamylograph, alveograph, wet gluten content, short baking tests, and capillary rheometer tests for the treated and control flours. In general, compaction and reconstitution of flour had no adverse influence on the thermodynamic and rheological behaviour of the dough.
Index Keywords: Compaction; Desorption; Food processing; Materials testing; Rheology; Rheometers; Thermodynamic properties; Capillary rheometer tests; Farinograph; Mixograph; Short baking tests; Viscoamylograph; Wet gluten content; Food products

Authors: Werner W.S.M., Lakatha H., Smith H.E., LeTarte L., Ambrose V., Baker J.
Title: Auger voltage contrast imaging for the delineation of two-dimensional junctions in cross-sectioned metal-oxide-semiconductor devices
Source title: Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology B: Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures
Affiliations: Institut für Allgemeine Physik, Vienna University of Technology, A-1040 Vienna, Austria; Digital Equipment Corporation, Hudson, MA 01749, United States; Physical Electronics Inc., Eden Prairie, MN 55344, United States
Authors with affiliations: Werner, W.S.M., Institut für Allgemeine Physik, Vienna University of Technology, A-1040 Vienna, Austria; Lakatha, H., Institut für Allgemeine Physik, Vienna University of Technology, A-1040 Vienna, Austria; Smith, H.E., Digital Equipment Corporation, Hudson, MA 01749, United States; LeTarte, L., Digital Equipment Corporation, Hudson, MA 01749, United States; Ambrose, V., Digital Equipment Corporation, Hudson, MA 01749, United States; Baker, J., Physical Electronics Inc., Eden Prairie, MN 55344, United States
Abstract: A new two-dimensional junction delineation technique named Auger voltage contrast (AVC) is described. AVC is a mapping tool that indicates the dopant type of each point of the cross-sectioned surface by measuring the Auger electron energy shifts that mirror the workfunction differences caused by the built-in junction, i.e., caused by Fermi level differences between n- and p-doped silicon. AVC makes use of the dual capabilities of field emission Auger electron spectroscopy instrumentation for spectroscopy at each pixel and for high spatial resolution. A theoretical examination is made of the important practical aspects of this previously observed Auger energy line shift, in particular the effect of surface states on the Fermi level position and the effect of beam-induced electron-hole pair creation and transport. AVC results obtained from cross-sectioned metal-oxide-semiconductor structures are shown to have good agreement with both theory and with one-dimensional secondary ion mass spectroscopy and spreading resistance probe profiles from the same sample. A fast and efficient algorithm has been devised which fits the Auger Si LVV spectrum to that of a reference spectrum obtained from a region of known doping, so that it is possible to make a calculation of the energy shift at each pixel with resolution on the order of 50 meV and in a way that speeds analysis and minimizes storage size. © 1998 American Vacuum Society.

Authors: Johnson W., Roesel J., Morash R.
Title: Variable pole flywheel motor-generator for clean power, UPS and IPS energy storage module applications
Affiliations: John J. McMullen Associates, Inc., United States; Newport News Shipbuilding, United States; U.S. Navy, United States; Precise Power Corporation, United States; Electric Power Research Institute
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, W., John J. McMullen Associates, Inc., United States, Newport News Shipbuilding, United States, U.S. Navy, United States; Roesel, J., Precise Power Corporation, United States; Morash, R., Precise Power Corporation, United States, Electric Power Research Institute
Abstract: This paper examines a class of permanent magnet machines that offer advantages for clean power, UPS and IPS energy storage module applications. The chief feature of this class of machines is the ability to control the location and number of poles on the rotating field structure. Using this technology, motor-generators with integral flywheel high inertia can supply a constant frequency (for AC application) and constant voltage (AC or DC) output over a wide range of shaft rotation speed. This technology is proven and in service in many applications throughout the country, including severe environment service for weather radars. 400 kW and larger machines are under development which merit consideration for Navy requirements for clean power, uninterruptible power supply (UPS) and integrated power system (IPS) energy storage module applications and which could reduce or eliminate the need for battery backup systems. This capability can be backfit into current AC distribution systems and forward fit into IPS AC/ DC distribution systems.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric ship equipment; Flywheels; Permanent magnets; Warships; Integrated power system (IPS); Electric motor generator sets

Authors: Nor Jiri K., Vogt Janet L.
Title: Fast battery charging enhances electric transit vehicle operation
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: Norvik Traction Inc, Mississauga, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Nor, Jiri K., Norvik Traction Inc, Mississauga, Canada; Vogt, Janet L., Norvik Traction Inc, Mississauga, Canada
Abstract: The Minit Charger ultra fast battery charging technique has been applied to electric vehicles by Norvik since 1991, with very good results: savings of time, of energy, utilization of full battery capacity, and significantly extended battery life. Recent efforts have been aimed at further refinements of this technology and on implementation of the concept of Total Energy Management (TEM) leading to high battery energy throughput and long service life. This paper focuses on application of Minit Charger to electric transit bus operation, a demonstration project within the Santa Barbara Metropolitan Transit District.
Index Keywords: Energy management; Energy utilization; Secondary batteries; Service life; Storage battery vehicles; Total energy management (TEM); Ultrafast battery charging technique; Charging (batteries)

Authors: Mitkin Valentin N.
Title: Known fluorocarbon materials and future possibilities in the fluorocarbon-lithium power sources
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Mitkin, Valentin N., Russian Acad of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: There were realized a reference studying of interaction between the fluorocarbons of a various composition and `prehistory' with a gaseous hydrogen by using of the quantitative thermal analysis. There has been shown that standard enthalpies of various fluorocarbon reduction's reactions linearly depends only on the atomic ratio of carbon to fluorine. The value of standard formation's enthalpy of all different nature's CFx samples of fluorocarbons CFx(sol) has been calculated statistically from all experimental series and it is equal to 48.52±1.63 kcal/mol. It has been shown that the novel superstoichiometrical fluorocarbon of the general formula CF1.18-1.33 is the most existing today fluorocarbon semi-industrial material. It's application in lithium cells gives the maximal theoretical electrical capacity closely to 900 mAhrs/g. The theoretical estimations shows that extremal achievable discharge current density of a Li-cell made from the hybrid cathodes on low-temperature dicarbon monofluoride basis with introduced `liquid cathodes'-such molecules as SO2, SOCl2, N2O4 and others should about of 4-10 times surpass those for known cathode on the basis of monofluorocarbon (graphite monofluoride) and real voltage of the discharge process about on 300-500 mV to exceed the known value of 2.7 volts achieved for system `CF1.00 - nonaqueous solvent - Li'.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Cathodes; Current density; Electric discharges; Enthalpy; Fluorocarbons; Lithium; Redox reactions; Statistical methods; Stoichiometry; Thermoanalysis; Fluorocarbon lithium power sources; Electric energy storage

Authors: Ha S.K., Jeong H.-M., Cho Y.-S.
Title: Optimum design of thick-walled composite rings for an energy storage system
Affiliations: Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, #1271, Sa-1 dong, Ansan-Si, Kyungki-do, 425-791, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Ha, S.K., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, #1271, Sa-1 dong, Ansan-Si, Kyungki-do, 425-791, South Korea; Jeong, H.-M., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, #1271, Sa-1 dong, Ansan-Si, Kyungki-do, 425-791, South Korea; Cho, Y.-S., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, #1271, Sa-1 dong, Ansan-Si, Kyungki-do, 425-791, South Korea
Abstract: An optimum design has been performed to maximize the specific energy density (SED) of a composite flywheel rotor for an energy storage system. The flywheel rotor consists of multiple rings, and the interferences and ply angles vary in the radial direction. For the structural analysis the rotor is assumed to be an axisymmetric thick laminated shell with a plane strain state. Considering the ring-by-ring variation of fiber orientations, a symmetric local stiffness matrix was derived for each ring. Using the stiffness matrix, the continuity conditions of radial stresses and displacements between the rings with a consideration of the interferences can be easily incorporated. A symmetric global stiffness matrix is then obtained assembling the local stiffness matrices. Displacements are obtained by solving the global stiffness matrix, and the stresses in each ring are then calculated. Three-dimensional intra-laminar quadratic Tsai-Wu criterion for the strength analysis is used yielding the strength ratio for each ring. The optimization has been also performed maximizing the kinetic energy stored in the rotor. For that purpose the sensitivities of the strength ratios and displacements with respect to the design variables have been derived. As a result, the optimal design has attained 2.4 times of total energy compared to the case of 0 degree ply angle and no interference. The effects of interferences are found to be much more considerable than those of fiber orientations.
Author Keywords: Axisymmetric laminated shell; Composite flywheel rotor; Energy storage system; Optimum design; Sensitivity analysis
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Flywheels; Optimization; Rings (components); Sensitivity analysis; Shells (structures); Stiffness matrix; Stress analysis; Structural analysis; Yield stress; Thick-walled composite rings; Three-dimensional intra-laminar quadratic Tsai-Wu criterion; Laminated composites

Authors: Redey Laszlo
Title: Heat effects in batteries and measurements by electrochemical calorimetry
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: Communication Systems LR, Downers Grove, United States
Authors with affiliations: Redey, Laszlo, Communication Systems LR, Downers Grove, United States
Abstract: Sources and magnitude of heat effects in batteries are analyzed in this article. The evolving heat, as a result of the inefficiency of operation, is wasted energy at the expense of the chemically stored energy of the battery. At high rates of battery operations, the heat can be even commensurate with the obtained electrical energy. Measurement and analysis of the heat effects by electrochemical calorimetry play an important role in advanced battery development, diagnostics, and application. The electrochemical calorimeter measures heat effects and electrochemical parameters simultaneously while any standard or research testing procedure is being executed. The electrochemical calorimetry and mathematical thermal modeling together are the important means of thermal management design.
Index Keywords: Calorimeters; Calorimetry; Electric energy storage; Electrochemistry; Temperature measurement; Thermal effects; Thermoanalysis; Thermal management designs; Secondary batteries

Authors: Wester E.C.N., Mace B.R.
Title: A Statistical Analysis of Acoustical Energy Flow in two Coupled Rectangular Rooms
Affiliations: Industrial Research Limited, Auckland, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Wester, E.C.N., Industrial Research Limited, Auckland, New Zealand; Mace, B.R.
Abstract: A statistical 'wave component' decomposition technique which avoids the usual assumptions of Statistical Energy Analysis (SEA) and statistical room acoustics is used to analyse ensemble averaged energy flow in a system comprising two large rectangular rooms, acoustically coupled through a mass controlled partition. Four distinct regimes of energy flow and storage are identified and the dependence of these on the physical properties of the room system are examined. The strength of acoustic coupling between the rooms is quantified, together with the conditions under which traditional, approximate, methods yield acceptably accurate predictions of room response. The SEA hypothesis of proportionality between coupling power and the difference in subsystem mean modal energies is found to hold for the ensemble average response of the present system, for all coupling strengths. The accuracy of the traditional SEA coupling loss factor estimate is investigated and an improved estimate is suggested. The implications of the present findings for the measurement of partition transmission loss by the method of coupled reverberant rooms are examined and it is found that these measurements may be in error if, for the type of room system considered here, the ratio of the partition area to equivalent room absorption area is large.
Index Keywords: Acoustic wave absorption; Acoustic wave transmission; Reverberation; Statistical methods; Walls (structural partitions); Acoustic coupling; Acoustical energy flow; Statistical wave component decomposition; Architectural acoustics

Authors: Disosway Mark
Title: Development of high power nickel-cadmium batteries for hybrid vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: Saft America Inc, Valdosta, United States
Authors with affiliations: Disosway, Mark, Saft America Inc, Valdosta, United States
Abstract: A new high performance, long life, low cost, nickel cadmium battery has been developed for heavy hybrid vehicles. The Saft STX 600 offers the highest power to weight and longest life available with 500 W/kg peak power, 350 W/kg at 50% state of charge, and over 600 K cycles at 2% depth of discharge. Development work was funded through a cost share grant from the FTA to the New York State Consortium. The battery was developed to provide lighter weight, smaller size, lower cost energy storage for the series hybrid propulsion system on the Consortium's highly successful low floor demonstration bus. The battery was designed with durability to level peaks and valleys of propulsion power for 6 years on demanding New York City bus routes. Cell construction is based on Saft's time tested aviation battery technology and weighing only 2.0 kg offers users a lightweight alternative for their HEV application needs. In this paper, we focus on the specific design criteria of this cell, elements of the development program, and characterization test results.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric energy storage; Electric vehicles; Light weight vehicles; Hybrid vehicles; Nickel cadmium batteries

Authors: Menjak I., Gow P.H., Corrigan D.A., Venkatesan S., Dhar S.K., Stempel R.C., Ovshinsky S.R.
Title: Advanced Ovonic high-power nickel-metal hydride batteries for hybrid electric vehicle applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: Ovonic Battery Co, Troy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Menjak, I., Ovonic Battery Co, Troy, United States; Gow, P.H., Ovonic Battery Co, Troy, United States; Corrigan, D.A., Ovonic Battery Co, Troy, United States; Venkatesan, S., Ovonic Battery Co, Troy, United States; Dhar, S.K., Ovonic Battery Co, Troy, United States; Stempel, R.C., Ovonic Battery Co, Troy, United States; Ovshinsky, S.R., Ovonic Battery Co, Troy, United States
Abstract: In response to intense development of hybrid electric vehicles throughout the world spurred by energy and environmental concerns, Ovonic Battery Company has developed a series of high power batteries suitable for a range of vehicle design concepts. We have developed a 60 Ah HEV battery with a power capability of 620 W/kg and 1700 W/L. This high power capability was achieved without tradeoffs in energy density. With a specific energy of 70 Wh/kg, this battery is especially attractive for high energy applications such as the range-extender hybrid vehicle. We have also developed 20 and 30 Ah battery designs for lower energy applications that require a higher power-to-energy ratio such as the charge-sustaining power-assist vehicle. Ovonic NiMH batteries exhibit an excellent acceptance of regenerative brake energy, highly superior to that exhibited by high power lead-acid batteries. These properties together with a high voltaic and coulombic efficiency make Ovonic batteries the technology of choice for the diverse variety of HEVs under development. These batteries retain the excellent cycle life characteristics of the NiMH EV battery. They are maintenance-free, do not contain toxic heavy metals, and can be 100% recycled.
Index Keywords: Gas emissions; Nickel compounds; Storage battery vehicles; Hybrid electric vehicle (HEV); Nickel metal hydride batteries; Secondary batteries

Authors: Wu T.-F., Yu T.-H., Liu Y.-C.
Title: Principle of synthesizing single-stage converters for off-line applications
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition - APEC
Affiliations: Natl Chung Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wu, T.-F., Natl Chung Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan; Yu, T.-H., Natl Chung Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan; Liu, Y.-C., Natl Chung Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan
Abstract: Principle of synthesizing single-stage converters (SSC's) for off-line applications is presented in the paper. The principle is primarily based on the concept of dither effect, from which power factor corrector (PFC) cells comprising energy buffers and high frequency dither signals are introduced. Properly selecting an eligible PFC cell and inserting it in between input rectifier and dc-link capacitor can yield an SSC. In the paper, principle and configuration of PFC cells are addressed; thus, quite a few families of SSC's for off-line applications can be synthesized from the derived PFC cells. With this principle, not only the SSC's discussed in literature can be developed alternatively, but novel SSC's can be synthesized. Most of the SSC's have been proved in the literature to be feasible in applications with moderate power levels.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric network synthesis; Electric power factor correction; Electric rectifiers; Energy buffers; Single stage converters (SSC); Power converters

Authors: Lipka Stephen M.
Title: Carbon nanofibers and their applications for energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: Florida Atlantic Univ, Boca Raton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lipka, Stephen M., Florida Atlantic Univ, Boca Raton, United States
Abstract: Carbon nanofibers can be produced in relatively large scale from the catalytic decomposition of certain hydrocarbons on small metal particles. These materials possess some rather unique properties that may find use in a number of electrochemical energy storage systems including primary and secondary batteries, fuel cells and electrochemical capacitors. The structure and properties of the nanofibers can be controlled at the nanometer-level by manipulating the process variables. Although the use of carbon nanofibers in electrochemical capacitors will be emphasized, the potential use of these materials in other energy storage systems will be addressed.
Index Keywords: Carbon fibers; Electric energy storage; Electrochemistry; Nanostructured materials; Carbon nanofibers; Electrochemical capacitors; Capacitor storage

Authors: Gu W.B., Wang C.Y., Liaw B.Y.
Title: Integrated simulation and testing of electric vehicle batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gu, W.B., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States; Wang, C.Y., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States; Liaw, B.Y., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States
Abstract: An integrated simulation and testing approach is presented to evaluate batteries for electric vehicle (EV) applications. This new approach combines traditional experimental testing with first principles computer simulations, thus providing a cost-effective means to evaluate EV batteries and offer important information that is difficult or impossible to obtain from purely experimental measurements. The present simulators for lead-acid and Ni-MH batteries are developed based on the fundamental principles governing their electrochemical behaviors and created using an advanced computational fluid dynamics (CFD) technique. Computer simulations are validated by experimental data under the dynamic stress test (DST) procedure for a lead-acid battery module and a Ni-MH cell with good agreement. Moreover, computer simulations reveal that the studied lead-acid battery under-utilizes the active material by as much as 70% and the MH electrode of the Ni-MH cell is over-designed by about 30% under the simulated EV duty. Therefore, there is a great potential of increasing the specific energy and reducing the cost if batteries are designed specifically for electric vehicles using a simulation-based approach.
Index Keywords: Computational fluid dynamics; Computer simulation; Cost effectiveness; Electrochemistry; Electrolytic cells; Storage battery vehicles; Stress analysis; Electric vehicle batteries; Lead acid batteries; Nickel metal hydride cells; Secondary batteries

Authors: Yeager V.J.
Title: Use of downhole diagnostics enhances determination of damage mechanisms
Source title: Proceedings - SPE International Symposium on Formation Damage Control
Affiliations: Halliburton Energy Services, Inc
Authors with affiliations: Yeager, V.J., Halliburton Energy Services, Inc
Abstract: This paper presents a systematic approach used in an intensive, 2-year study that was funded by the Gas Research Institute (GRI) and Department of Energy (DOE) and undertaken to determine the damage mechanisms that affect the over 15,000 U.S. gas storage wells. Multiple diagnostic tools were used to determine the damage mechanisms in 32 wells in 12 different reservoirs. The approach used included (1) transient pressure analysis and well testing to quantitatively determine if damage existed, (2) downhole video to observe the wellbore and formation areas, (3) physical sampling of downhole liquids and solids, and (4) rotary sidewall coring of the wellbore face to provide a `biopsy' of the formation of interest. This paper also includes (1) special sampling/handling considerations and laboratory procedures that were developed and (2) illustrations of some of the various damage mechanisms that were identified.
Index Keywords: Boreholes; Sampling; Well testing; Downhole well diagnostics; Rotary sidewall coring; Transient pressure analysis; Natural gas well completion

Authors: Van Sciver S.W., Hascicek Y.S., Markiewicz W.D., Schwartz J., Schneider-Muntau H.J.
Title: High field HTS magnet technology and applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on Cryogenics and Refrigeration
Affiliations: Natl High Magnetic Field Lab, Tallahassee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Van Sciver, S.W., Natl High Magnetic Field Lab, Tallahassee, United States; Hascicek, Y.S., Natl High Magnetic Field Lab, Tallahassee, United States; Markiewicz, W.D., Natl High Magnetic Field Lab, Tallahassee, United States; Schwartz, J., Natl High Magnetic Field Lab, Tallahassee, United States; Schneider-Muntau, H.J., Natl High Magnetic Field Lab, Tallahassee, United States
Abstract: A review of the status of development in high field applications of high temperature superconductors is presented. These magnet systems operate at liquid helium temperatures in a background field supplied by a magnet using low temperature superconducting materials, NbTi and Nb3Sn. By this method, the HTS magnet takes greatest advantage of the high upper critical field properties of the material, usually a composite of Ag and BSCCO. The near term application for this technology is in high field NMR spectrometer magnets; however, longer term one could expect these systems to be used in high energy physics, energy storage and fusion magnet systems.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Fusion reactions; High energy physics; High temperature superconductors; Niobium alloys; Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; Fusion magnet systems; Superconducting magnets

Authors: Beaurepaire E., Maret M., Halte V., Merle J.-C., Daunois A., Bigot J.-Y.
Title: Ultrafast demagnetization in CoPt3 alloy films
Source title: Technical Digest - European Quantum Electronics Conference
Affiliations: Inst de Physique et Chimie des, Materiaux de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France
Authors with affiliations: Beaurepaire, E., Inst de Physique et Chimie des, Materiaux de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France; Maret, M., Inst de Physique et Chimie des, Materiaux de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France; Halte, V., Inst de Physique et Chimie des, Materiaux de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France; Merle, J.-C., Inst de Physique et Chimie des, Materiaux de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France; Daunois, A., Inst de Physique et Chimie des, Materiaux de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France; Bigot, J.-Y., Inst de Physique et Chimie des, Materiaux de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, France
Abstract: The CoPt3 alloy films are studied in the context of magnetooptical recording. Time-resolved Kerr hysteresis loops are measured with 2 μJ energy per pump pulse. The loop obtained without pump beam is typical of materials with high perpendicular magnetic anisotropy with coercivity of approximately 1 kOe. When the delay between the pump and probe pulses is 630 fs, the field dependence of the magnetization does not show any hysteresis but rather a weak linear increase. This behavior is typical of the paramagnetic phase. When the probe precedes the pump, the hysteresis loop is very different from what is observed without the pump. The coercivity nearly vanishes and the loop has an s-like shape with a saturation field of approximately 500 Oe.
Index Keywords: Cobalt alloys; Coercive force; Demagnetization; Magnetic anisotropy; Magnetic field measurement; Magnetic film storage; Magnetic hysteresis; Optical Kerr effect; Optical pumping; Ultrafast phenomena; Time resolved polar Kerr hysteresis loops; Ultrafast demagnetization; Magnetic recording

Title: Microstructural evolution and thermal stability of thin CoCrTa/Cr films for longitudinal magnetic recording media
Affiliations: Komag, Inc., Milpitas, CA 95035, United States; Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, National Center for Electron Microscopy, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Bertero, G., Komag, Inc., Milpitas, CA 95035, United States; Tang, K., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: The microstructure and time-dependent magnetic properties of 2.8-60-nm-thick films of CoCrTa sputtered onto a Cr underlayer were measured. The thinnest films have a discontinuous microstructure with several CoCrTa nuclei forming on each Cr grain, with small angular misalignments from the exact epitaxial crystal orientation. For films of 10-nm thickness and above, the grains coalesce. There is evidence for stacking faults at all thicknesses although their appearance in atomic resolution micrographs changes with thickness. Magnetic switching volumes were measured from the change in coercivity with the scan rate of the external magnetic field. The ratio KV/kT of magnetic-to-thermal energy within the switching volume decreases as the film thickness decreases, and films thinner than 10 nm have KV/kT < 60 and would show significant decay of recorded data if used in longitudinal media applications. The magnetic switching volumes are similar in magnitude but generally larger than the physical grain volume indicating magnetic interactions between the grains. © 1998 IEEE.
Author Keywords: CoCrTa; Hard-disk media; Longitudinal media; Superparamagnetism; Transmission electron microscopy

Authors: Chernov S.A., Trinkler L., Popov A.I.
Title: Photo- and thermo-stimulated luminescence of CsI-Tl crystal after UV light irradiation at 80 K
Source title: Radiation Effects and Defects in Solids
Affiliations: Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St., LV-1063, Riga, Latvia; CIRIL, Lab. CEA/CNRS, Rue Claude Bloch, BP.5133, F-14040 Caen Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Chernov, S.A., Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St., LV-1063, Riga, Latvia; Trinkler, L., Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St., LV-1063, Riga, Latvia; Popov, A.I., Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St., LV-1063, Riga, Latvia, CIRIL, Lab. CEA/CNRS, Rue Claude Bloch, BP.5133, F-14040 Caen Cedex, France
Abstract: Thermo- and photo-stimulated luminescence are studied for CsI-Tl crystal after the irradiation with the UV light at 80 K. Creation spectrum of the photostimulated luminescence coincides with the D absorption band of Tl+ ions. Nature of the defects created by UV light at low temperatures is discussed basing on the correspondence between the thermostimulated glow curve peaks and thermal evolution of the photostimulation spectra observed after irradiation in the D absorption band. Three bands at 1400, 950 and 580 nm have been observed in the stimulation spectrum at 80 K. The 1400 and 950 nm stimulation bands are presumably explained as the optical transitions in the Tl0 centre forming the spatially correlated defect pair with Vk centre while the 580 nm stimulation band is connected with the unperturbed Tl0 centres. It is concluded that the Tl+ luminescence at low temperature is connected with the electron recombination with the Tl2+ centre.
Author Keywords: Alkali halide crystals; CsI-Tl; Energy storage; Impurity centres; Photostimulated luminescence; Radiation defects; Scintillators; Self-trapped excitons; Thermoluminescence; Tl impurity

Authors: Smith Kevin M., Morgan Kimberly A.
Title: Development of advanced thin/lightweight grids for valve-regulated lead-acid (VRLA) electric vehicle (EV) batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference on Applications and Advances
Affiliations: East Penn Manufacturing Co, Inc, Lyon Station, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, Kevin M., East Penn Manufacturing Co, Inc, Lyon Station, United States; Morgan, Kimberly A., East Penn Manufacturing Co, Inc, Lyon Station, United States
Abstract: Critical goals of the ALABC include improved specific energy (energy-to-weight ratio), specific power (power-to-weight ratio), and life cycles (DST) in VRLA EV batteries. Current factors limiting the realization of these goals include excess grid weight and inadequate active material utilization. In order to resist the active material forces and corrosion effects experienced during EV service, conventional gravity cast book mold grids, as thick as 0.125 inches (3.175 mm) and as heavy as 150 grams, are used. ALABC Project No. AMC-008 investigates the solution to these goals via the development, utilization, and evaluation of new, advanced thin and lightweight grids. Each of two new grid types, Wirtz Conroll and Cominco Expanded Metal, is being evaluated in both `thick' and `thin' plate applications. The thick overpaste plate designs, which significantly increase the active material weight to grid weight ratio, reduce the total grid weight per battery by approximately 50-70%. The thin overpaste plate designs, which enhance active material utilization, increase the number of plates per battery by approximately 100%. The concurrent optimization of both of these plate designs is expected to provide marked insights for the development of future VRLA EV batteries that will meet the ALABC's performance and life goals.
Index Keywords: Corrosion; Plate metal; Storage battery vehicles; Advanced thin/lightweight grids; Valve regulated lead acid (VRLA) batteries; Secondary batteries

Abstract: Time-resolved number densities of the fluorine negative ion in a discharge-pumped ArF excimer laser are measured by a dye laser absorption method. The peak density of F - is 0.93 × 10 15 cm -3 at a total gas pressure of 2.5 atm, a gas mixture ratio of F 2-Ar-He = 0.2-10.0-89.8, and a charging voltage of 28 kV for a 68-nF storage capacitor bank. The dependences of the peak F - density and the ArF laser output power on the F 2 gas fraction in F 2-Ar-He mixture are investigated. The effects of F - ions and F 2 molecules on the ArF laser oscillation process are discussed by considering the F 2 mixture-ratio dependences of particle densities, laser output power, mean electron energy, and laser power extraction efficiency. With increasing F 2 mixing ratio, the ArF* excimer formation first increases as F - increases, but in F 2-rich conditions the laser power decreases because of the laser photon absorption due to F - ions and quenching of ArF* with F 2 molecules.
Author Keywords: ArF excimer laser; Density measurement; Excimer formation mechanism; F - ion; Mean electron energy; Photon absorption

Authors: Large V., Arner P.
Title: Regulation of lipolysis in humans. Pathophysiological modulation in obesity diabetes, and hyperlipidaemia
Affiliations: INSERM U499, Faculté de Médecine, Laennec, rue G. Paradin, 69372 Lyon Cedex 08, France
Authors with affiliations: Large, V., INSERM U499, Faculté de Médecine, Laennec, rue G. Paradin, 69372 Lyon Cedex 08, France; Arner, P.
Abstract: Adipose tissue is considered as the body's largest storage organ for energy in the form of triglycerides, which are mobilised through the lipolysis process to provide fuel to other organs and to deliver substrates to liver for gluconeogenesis (glycerol) and lipoprotein synthesis (free fatty acids). The release of glycerol and free fatty acids is intensively regulated by hormones and agents. In man, the major hormones are insulin (inhibition of lipolysis) and catecholamines (stimulation of lipolysis). Physiological factors such as dieting, physical exercise and ageing also regulate lipolysis. The lipolytic process is modified in pathological conditions, e.g. obesity (both upper and lower obesity), diabetes (non- and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus), and dyslipidaemia (in particular, familial combined hyperlipidaemia. The regulation of lipolysis is complex because of the heterogeneity of fat depots (visceral versus subcutaneous), which may contribute to the well-known gender differences in accumulation of fat. Since visceral fat depot is directly drained into the liver and has a high turnover of visceral triglycerides, 'portal' free fatty acids seem to be an important pathophysiological factor in common complications of obesity (in particular, metabolic syndrome). New advances in genetic studies indicate that polymorphisms in several genes encoding for proteins that regulate the lipolysis process are important for the development of obesity and its complications.
Author Keywords: Adipose tissue; Adrenoceptor; Free fatty acids; Hormone-sensitive lipase; Triglycerides
Index Keywords: adrenergic receptor; catecholamine; cholecystokinin; fatty acid; glucagon; growth hormone; hydrocortisone; parathyroid hormone; sex hormone; thyroid hormone; thyrotropin; triacylglycerol; triacylglycerol lipase; tumor necrosis factor alpha; body fat; diabetes mellitus; gluconeogenesis; hormonal regulation; human; hyperlipidemia; insulin dependent diabetes mellitus; lipid storage; lipolysis; lipoprotein synthesis; metabolic regulation; non insulin dependent diabetes mellitus; obesity; pathophysiology; review

Authors: Andersson Karin, Ohlsson Thomas, Olsson Par
Title: Screening Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of tomato ketchup: A case study
Affiliations: SIK, Goteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, Karin, SIK, Goteborg, Sweden; Ohlsson, Thomas, SIK, Goteborg, Sweden; Olsson, Par, SIK, Goteborg, Sweden
Abstract: A Screening Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of tomato ketchup has been carried out. The purpose was to identify `hot-spots', that is parts of the life-cycle that are important to the total environmental impact. The system investigated includes agricultural production, industrial refining, packaging, transportation, consumption and waste management. Energy use and emissions were quantified and some of the potential environmental effects assessed. Packaging and food processing were found to be hot-spots for many, but not all, of the impact categories investigated. For primary energy use, the storage time in a refrigerator (household phase) was found to be a critical parameter.
Index Keywords: Agriculture; Energy utilization; Environmental impact; Food processing; Food storage; Industrial waste disposal; Life cycle; Packaging; Transportation; Life cycle assessment (LCA); Waste management; Food products

Authors: Lebon M., Nabil R., Lehuen P.
Title: Case study of gas BTU control for operational strategy and inert gas injection planning
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Gaz de France, France
Authors with affiliations: Lebon, M., Gaz de France, France; Nabil, R., Gaz de France, France; Lehuen, P., Gaz de France, France
Abstract: The aquifer gas storage of Goumay-sur-Aronde (France) has been in operation since 1976. There was a few months of low Btu gas injection, followed by ten years with high Btu gas injection. A gas sweeping was achieved in 1986 to convert the reservoir to a low Btu value gas storage. The cushion gas is therefore a mixture of low and high Btu value gases. The average Btu value during withdrawal periods since 1986 is occasionally very close to the maximum allowed value, potentially raising operational difficulties. For the next ten years, additional wells and surface facilities will be gradually added to increase the working gas and the peak flow rate capacities. This paper describes how a history matching of gas Btu content is performed for the first time using a full field in-house reservoir simulator. In fact, a model was matched the conventional way, then the detailed Btu value history was added. The results of the model in terms of energy and nitrogen content during withdrawal periods have accurately reproduced the actual behavior of the gas storage. This confirms as correct the previous history matching of the reservoir pressure and saturation. By calculating the evolution of Btu values within the storage, the model proves very efficient in assisting the engineer to define the best strategy for injection and withdrawal periods in order to meet the customers required gas Btu value. Therefore emissibility problems can be avoided by choosing the most suitable wells. It has been possible to optimize inert gas injection planning by evaluating, under various operational scenarios, the influence of gas mixing on the withdrawn gas Btu values. © Copyright 1998, Society of Petroleum Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Froes F.H., Senkov O.N., Jonas J.J.
Title: Thermohydrogen processing of titanium
Affiliations: Univ of Idaho, Moscow, United States
Authors with affiliations: Froes, F.H., Univ of Idaho, Moscow, United States; Senkov, O.N., Univ of Idaho, Moscow, United States; Jonas, J.J., Univ of Idaho, Moscow, United States
Abstract: Although high hydrogen levels in metals can have a devastating effect on mechanical properties, many positive effects can also be derived from high solubility. The use of hydrogen as an energy storage device and as a means of detecting overheating/fires in jet engines are two positive effects. Thermohydrogen processing (THP) (use of hydrogen as a temporary alloying element) can also strongly enhance processing behavior and final component characteristics of titanium based alloys. This paper reviews processing using THP, including wrought product, powder metallurgy (PM) materials, and superplastic forming. The refinement of the microstructure and improvement in mechanical properties achievable using THP is presented for wrought product, PM material and castings; the latter product form offering the largest improvement compared to conventional material. The state of our knowledge of the mechanism(s) by which THP enhances processing and final mechanical properties is reviewed.
Index Keywords: Alloying; Hydrogen; Mechanical properties; Metallographic microstructure; Titanium powder metallurgy; Superplastic forming; Thermohydrogen processing; Wrought product; Titanium alloys

Authors: Kim Ki-Se, Yoon Jong-Ho, Lee Euy-Joon, Choi Sangho, Krarti Moncef
Title: Building energy performance simulations to evaluate energy conservation measures for a commercial building in Korea
Affiliations: Korea Inst of Energy Research, Taejon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Ki-Se, Korea Inst of Energy Research, Taejon, South Korea; Yoon, Jong-Ho, Korea Inst of Energy Research, Taejon, South Korea; Lee, Euy-Joon, Korea Inst of Energy Research, Taejon, South Korea; Choi, Sangho, Korea Inst of Energy Research, Taejon, South Korea; Krarti, Moncef, Korea Inst of Energy Research, Taejon, South Korea
Abstract: The building simulation program, DOE-2.1E, can be used to quantitatively evaluate possible energy conservation measures for existing buildings. This paper presents an energy-use analysis for an office building in Seoul, Korea, and evaluates the energy and cost savings of several energy conservation measures. In order to develop a DOE-2 model for the building, all available data related to building and its energy systems were collected. The analysis of energy use patterns from the collected information on energy end-use in the building was used to calibrate the base case simulation model. The calibrated base case model was then used to evaluate six selected energy conservation opportunity (ECO) options for the building. Those options considered in this study included 1) the conservation of CAV to VAV, 2) optimal ice storage control, 3) glazing retrofit, 4) indoor temperature reset, 5) fan and pump motor replacement, and 6) daylighting control. Based on both energy and cost savings, some recommendations on reducing the operating cost of the building were provided.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Computer simulation; Computer software; Electric power measurement; Energy utilization; Mathematical models; Daylighting control; Energy conservation opportunity (ECO) options; Energy use analysis; Optimal ice storage control; Energy conservation

Title: ITER pulsed power supply system
Affiliations: ITER Joint Central Team, Ibaraki-ken, Japan

Abstract: The ITER Pulsed Power Supply System includes the superconducting coils power supplies and the Heating and Current Drive power supplies. After a short introduction the paper reports the interruption of very high current (170 kA) for the Central Solenoid, which is a critical issue, and other aspects of the design not described previously: the high voltage power supply (1.0 MV) for the neutral beams and the pulse step modulators for the ion cyclotron power generators. Finally the paper presents the work done on local energy storage that could be required at a site with limited power capability.

Abstract: A brief recommendation about solar energy resources and the status of solar house research and development in China is introduced. The reasons for the slow development of an active solar house in the past is analysed. By combining with various research achievements, the passive solar house has had good advancement and applications. The demonstration transparent insulation material (TIM) solar house project in Shanghai is described as an example showing that with the development of solar material, absorbing and storage wall and air-conditioning measures, the passive and hybrid solar house has the potential to provide future wider applications in China. © IMechE 1998.

Authors: Salkind A.J.
Title: Advances in battery technologies and markets: Material science aspects
Affiliations: State Univ of New Jersey, Piscataway, United States
Authors with affiliations: Salkind, A.J., State Univ of New Jersey, Piscataway, United States
Abstract: Advances in materials innovation, availability, processing, and volumetric and gravimetric utilization, have lead to dramatic changes in the technologies and markets for batteries, and other electrochemical storage devices, in recent years. The increased ability to cycle of the new materials and preparations has also resulted in a more dominant proportion of secondary batteries in the market. The growth of the various technology sectors of the battery and energy storage device industry will be compared to the relevant improvements in materials science. The developments needed in materials, composites, and processing techniques is reviewed, in order to match the ongoing changes in electronic circuits, power devices, transportation, and the growth of portable appliances. An analysis of the technical/market segments of the battery industry is presented.

Abstract: This study confirms that improvement in scaling active fiber devices with single-transverse mode output to higher power levels can be achieved by increasing mode-field area. The output mode does not depend on either launching condition, nor fiber bending. The device delivers up to 770 mW of output power with a highest conversion efficiency of 58%. In addition, the amplifier that uses the fiber with larger mode-field area demonstrates the better ability to energy storage and high-energy pulse extraction.

Abstract: A small gas-puff Z-pinch plasma device is composed of a capacitor energy storage bank, field distortion switches, a discharge chamber, vacuum pumping system, fast operation gas valve and diagnostics. A compact Thomson ion energy analyzer is installed inside the gas-puff Z-pinch device. X ray emission is observed with pinhole camera in the radial and axial direction, the diameter of the pinch is about 1 mm. A laser interferometer device is used to study the movement of the plasma sheath and pinch and the electron density in the pinched plasma.

Title: Experimental electrochemical capacitor test results
Affiliations: Idaho Natl Engineering &, Environmental Lab, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wright, R.B., Idaho Natl Engineering &, Environmental Lab, Idaho Falls, United States; Murphy, T.C., Idaho Natl Engineering &, Environmental Lab, Idaho Falls, United States; Rogers, Susan A., Idaho Natl Engineering &, Environmental Lab, Idaho Falls, United States; Sutula, Raymond A., Idaho Natl Engineering &, Environmental Lab, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: Various electrochemical capacitors (ultracapacitors) are being developed for hybrid vehicles as candidate power assist devices for the Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles (PNGV) fast-response engine. The envisioned primary functions of the ultracapacitor are to level the dynamic power loads on the primary propulsion device and recover available energy from regenerative breaking during off-peak power periods. This paper will present test data from selected U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) supported ultracapacitor projects designed to meet the fast response engine requirements. This paper will address the temperature dependence of test data obtained from a set of three devices provided from Maxwell Energy Products, Inc. These devices are rated at 2300 F at 2.3 V. Constant-current, constant-power, and self-discharge testing as a function of temperature have been conducted. From these tests were determined the capacitance, equivalent series resistance, specific energy and power, and the self-discharge energy loss factor as a function of the device operating temperature.

Title: New polymer cathode-conducting polymer interconnected with sulfur-sulfur bonds: Poly(2,2′-dithiodianiline)

Abstract: Poly(2,2′-Dithiodianiline)(Poly(DTDA)), a conducting polymer having disulfide bond in it, has been proposed as a new class of high energy storage material. DTDA has one S-S bond interconnected between two moieties of anilines. The structure of the poly(DTDA) was similar to that of polyaniline in addition that the S-S bond is preserved after electropolymerization of DTDA. The poly(DTDA) has some advantages because of its high theoretical energy density, faster kinetics and higher electrical conductivity than other organosulfur cathodes.

Authors: Bahar R.Iris, Albera Gianluca, Manne Srilatha
Title: Power and performance tradeoffs using various caching strategies
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Brown Univ, Providence, RI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bahar, R.Iris, Brown Univ, Providence, RI, United States; Albera, Gianluca, Brown Univ, Providence, RI, United States; Manne, Srilatha, Brown Univ, Providence, RI, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we propose several different data and instruction cache configurations and analyze their power as well as performance implications on the processor. Unlike most existing work in low power microprocessor design, we explore a high performance processor with the latest innovations for performance. Using a detailed, architectural-level simulator, we evaluate full system performance using several different power/performance sensitive cache configurations such as increasing cache size or associativity and including buffers along side L1 caches. We then use the information obtained from the simulator to calculate the energy consumption of the memory hierarchy of the system. As an alternative to simply increasing cache associativity or size to reduce lower-level memory energy consumption (which may have a detrimental effect on on-chip energy consumption), we show that, by using buffers, energy consumption of the memory subsystem may be reduced by as much as 13% for certain data cache configurations and by as much as 23% for certain instruction cache configurations without adversely effecting processor performance or on-chip energy consumption.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Microprocessor chips; Architectural level simulators; Buffer storage

Authors: Meza Jose I., Khan Arshad Y., Gonzalez Jorge E.
Title: Experimental assessment of a solar-assisted air conditioning system for application in Puerto Rico
Affiliations: Univ of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Mayaguez, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meza, Jose I., Univ of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Mayaguez, United States; Khan, Arshad Y., Univ of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Mayaguez, United States; Gonzalez, Jorge E., Univ of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, Mayaguez, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the design and experimental performance of a pilot solar-assisted air cooling and dehumidification system located in Cabo Rojo, Puerto Rico. The system consists of a 35-kW LiBr-H2O absorption chiller, a 113 m array of selective surface flat plate collectors, a 5700-liter hot water storage tank, an 84-kW cooling tower, a 1800-liter per hour air handling unit, and a 50-kW auxiliary heater. The system is installed to supply conditioned air to the visitor center and the conference room area of a building in Cabo Rojo, Puerto Rico. The experimentally measured thermal performance of the absorption chiller along with the solar energy collection system is reported in this paper. The data to estimate the thermal performance of the system were taken at ten-minute intervals. Daily, weekly, and monthly performance parameters, such as system COP, collector efficiency, latent and sensible load on the chiller, and auxiliary heat requirement are estimated and documented in this work. To optimize the performance of this system, serial and parallel solar collector arrangement were considered. Results from the comparison between the two collector arrangements along with the collector array performance when operating with the chiller, are included in the paper. Finally, the performance over a long period of operation of the system is also compared with similar systems installed in Italy, Singapore, and Hong Kong.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Cooling; Solar collectors; Thermal variables measurement; Solar assisted air conditioning systems; Solar assisted dehumidification systems; Thermal performance; Solar absorbers

Abstract: The objective of this paper is to describe salient features of a small refrigerator powered by a field of photovoltaic panels backed up by a petrol-start, kerosene-run portable generator set. Authors: Medevielle A., Thevenot F., Treheux D.
Title: Dielectric approach of the wear of zirconia
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Electric Charge in Solid Insulators, CSC
Affiliations: Ecole des Mines de St. Etienne, Saint Etienne, France
Authors with affiliations: Medevielle, A., Ecole des Mines de St. Etienne, Saint Etienne, France; Thevenot, F., Ecole des Mines de St. Etienne, Saint Etienne, France; Treheux, D., Ecole des Mines de St. Etienne, Saint Etienne, France
Abstract: The wear resistance of stabilized zirconia (MgPSZ and YTZP) was investigated on both ball-on-flat tribometer an impact apparatus. Those tests allowed us to determine respectively the sliding resistance and the impact resistance. The wear of zirconia can not be explained by the intrinsic mechanical properties (hardness, toughness) but by dielectrical phenomena like storage and release of polarization energy. Indeed, during friction, charges are trapped on sites. Two families of trapping sites can be detected and are related to the presence of monoclinic and tetragonal phases. The detrapping is achieved at room temperature causing wear. For one type of zirconia (PSZ or TZP) the higher the charging capacity of ceramic (measured by electron beam implantation), the bigger the wear.

Abstract: The properties and transient mechanism of excited-state optical storage in azo dyes polymer system were reported, including the dynamic process of optical storage, phase conjugation signal versus pre-excitation intensity. Moreover, the micro-mechanism of excited-state nonlinearity and optical storage of material are explained. The experiments are performed by a four-wave mixing (FWM) using a He-Ne laser as under pre-excitation of a Nd:YAG laser for searching the transient mechanism of azo polymer system, and another forward FWM using a He-Ne laser as a source of forward FWM under a pre-excitation of an argon ion laser for searching pre-excitation optical storage mechanism. An energy level model of azo dye doped in polymer is set up to explain excited-state optical storage mechanism.

Authors: Le Gressus C., Sarjeant J.
Title: IEEE/DEIS CT 32-13 & 32-4 project of recommendations for space charge characterization. Charge and energy localization parameters to measure
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Electric Charge in Solid Insulators, CSC
Affiliations: CEA - Cent du Ripault
Authors with affiliations: Le Gressus, C., CEA - Cent du Ripault; Sarjeant, J., CEA - Cent du Ripault
Abstract: The creation of a technical committee for space charge characterization (IEEE/DEIS CT 32-13 & 32-4) reflects technological needs in the domains where insulators are used (energy transport, energy storage, nuclear waste materials). The two committees have join their effort because radiation ageing is likely of similar nature that electrical and mechanical ageing. Moreover, recent theoretical supports suggest that insulator behaviours are related to charge localization and energy localization. The Committee applies these supports to recommend the parameters to measure and the experimental procedures to follow. Until now the current practice is to measure an average distribution of charges that are injected in arbitrarily chosen conditions (temperature, electric field, time). However, this level of information is not enough to establish the links that exist between the charge distribution and the quantities that are measured during breakdown or ageing tests. The TC works deal with the research of fundamental basis for good measurement practices, for the research of the links between space charge characteristics and material behaviours and the demonstration that characterization techniques may contribute to improve the product quality. The recommended practices will be illustrated by their application to space charge characterization by using an electron beam technique.
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Electric space charge; Electron beams; Radiation damage; Charge localization; Energy localization; Radiation aging; Space charge characterization; Electric insulating materials

Title: Two-color plane-wave holography in reduced, near-stoichiometric lithium niobate
Source title: Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe - Technical Digest
Affiliations: IBM Almaden Research Cent, San Jose, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guenther, H., IBM Almaden Research Cent, San Jose, CA, United States; Macfarlane, R.M., IBM Almaden Research Cent, San Jose, CA, United States; Furukawa, Y., IBM Almaden Research Cent, San Jose, CA, United States; Kitamura, K., IBM Almaden Research Cent, San Jose, CA, United States
Abstract: Two-color, or photon-gated, holographic recording materials show promise for applications such as optical data storage where nondestructive readout is required. In this paper, the growth and decay of plane-wave holograms as a function of the degree of reduction for a crystal of LiNbO3 with a composition close to stoichiometric are studied. The photorefractive sensitivity of for the two-color recording at 852 nm, gates at 488 nm is approximately 30,000 times higher than of fully oxidized congruent material for writing and gating intensities of 1 W/1 cm2. Gating with shorter-wavelength light would increase this sensitivity still further.
Index Keywords: Crystals; Diffraction gratings; Energy gap; Holograms; Lithium compounds; Optical data storage; Optical recording; Stoichiometry; Lithium niobate; Photorefractive sensitivity; Two color plane wave holography; Holography

Authors: Boutchenkov V., Kuchma I., Levoshkin A., Mak A., Petrov A., Hollemann G.
Title: High efficiency diode pumped Yb:Er:glass lasers
Source title: Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe - Technical Digest
Affiliations: Research Inst for Laser Physics, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Boutchenkov, V., Research Inst for Laser Physics, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Kuchma, I., Research Inst for Laser Physics, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Levoshkin, A., Research Inst for Laser Physics, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Mak, A., Research Inst for Laser Physics, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Petrov, A., Research Inst for Laser Physics, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Hollemann, G., Research Inst for Laser Physics, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The processes of energy storage and extraction in Yb-Er phosphate glass were analyzed. It was found that the maximum transformation efficiency of optical pumping energy to laser output could reach 2-7% depending on Er concentration, pumping pulse duration and intra-resonator energy flux density. Various types of possible pumping systems were considered. It was shown that, it was really to ensure the efficiency up to 80% from a theoretical limit and more.
Index Keywords: Continuous wave lasers; Laser modes; Mathematical models; Optical frequency conversion; Optical pumping; Q switching; Semiconductor lasers; Free running mode; High efficiency laser; Solid state lasers

Authors: Lelewer Steven A., Barnes Heidi, Haberman David
Title: Hazards assessment for failures involving hydrogen production and transfer
Affiliations: Bechtel Nevada
Authors with affiliations: Lelewer, Steven A., Bechtel Nevada; Barnes, Heidi, Bechtel Nevada; Haberman, David, Bechtel Nevada
Abstract: Liquid hydrogen is a candidate energy carrier for delivery renewable energy to the public and industry. Unfortunately, the public's first response to the proliferation hydrogen fuel is not associated with hydrogen's environmental benefits but instead focuses on the safety issues and hydrogen's dubious association with the Hindenburg disaster. Before regulations and the market drive hydrogen to the fuel of chose, the safety issues must be systematically addressed and interdisciplinary techniques defined for application. The paper proposes a generic methodology for performing hazards assessments of integrated systems in the hydrogen fuel cycle. The cycle elements include production, stationary storage, transport, and transfer operations. A generic assessment is presented for one such process in the fuel cycle. The assessment approach utilizes the chemical industry standard HAZOP procedure. Standardization of review questions include materials of construction, process control, leak detection, confined space, and ignition sources. Recommended approaches for addressing unanalyzed events is also presented. The Nevada Test Site is developing the capability to safely integrate liquid hydrogen based energy systems using new generation technologies. These technologies must be qualified in a systems approach. The Nevada Test Site's HAZMAT Spill Center has the capability to support testing and verification of liquid hydrogen systems and components which will be needed for deployment of a safe infrastructure.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Hazards; Hydrogen; Hydrogen fuels; Production; Storage (materials); Transportation; Hazard assessment; Hydrogen fuel cycle; Liquid hydrogen; Risk assessment

Authors: Ferelli Mark
Title: World's largest storage management challenge
Authors with affiliations: Ferelli, Mark
Abstract: CERN is the world's largest high-energy particle physics laboratory that is well known for their enormous particle accelerator that permits exploration and discovery of subatomic particles. They are known as the home of the hypertext markup language (HTML), the pervasive Internet language, and by the extension of the World Wide Web. Just two of CERN's installed experiments generate an additional 20 MB/s over a 100-day span. The total data generation run-rate on all experiments in the facility may soon reach 50 MB/s at peak, and 200 TB/year. All this data is captured on disk and moved off to tape cartridges for use by physicists in their analysis of the collision results.
Index Keywords: Atomic physics; Computer systems programming; Data acquisition; Data communication systems; Database systems; Information management; Information services; Management information systems; Particle accelerators; Response time (computer systems); Wide area networks; Automated library systems; Storage allocation (computer)

Authors: Lucier Alan A.
Title: Implications of carbon dioxide emissions and climate policies for forest management
Affiliations: NCASI, Research Triangle Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lucier, Alan A., NCASI, Research Triangle Park, United States
Abstract: Carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere are rising. Higher CO2 accelerates photosynthesis. Forest productivity may increase substantially in some regions. For example, growth rates of well-managed southern pines may increase by 20 percent over the next fifty years if climate doesn't change and if CO2 concentrations continue to increase. Models of climate change and its potential effects on forests include many untested assumptions. Environmental advocacy groups often assert that restrictions on forest management help control atmospheric CO2. They cite studies showing that a no-harvest regime can maximize carbon storage on isolated tracts of unmanaged forest. A more thorough analysis indicates that active management is usually a better strategy than preservation. Prohibiting harvest on selected areas (e.g., on federal lands in the Northwest) may provide no overall increase in forest carbon stocks because harvest activity will shift to other regions. Broad restrictions on harvest would eliminate economic incentives for forest management and encourage conversion of forest lands to other uses. Active forest management can significantly increase the productivity and carbon storage capacity of land. It also provides raw material for essential products that store significant amounts of carbon. Moreover, forest products often require less fossil energy to manufacture than non-renewable alternatives.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Carbon dioxide; Climate change; Environmental protection; Harvesting; Laws and legislation; Photosynthesis; Renewable energy resources; Abstract only; Carbon storage capacity; Forest management; Forestry

Authors: Wang Jinn-Shyan, Yang Po-Hui, Tseng Wayne
Title: Low-power embedded SRAM macros with current-mode read/write operations
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Design
Affiliations: Chung-Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Jinn-Shyan, Chung-Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan; Yang, Po-Hui, Chung-Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan; Tseng, Wayne, Chung-Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan
Abstract: The newly proposed SRAM performs both read and write operations in the current-mode. Due to the current-mode operations, voltage swings at bit-lines and data-lines are kept very small during read and write. The AC power dissipation of bit-lines and data-lines can thus be saved efficiently. For an embedded SRAM macro used in an 8-bit μ-controller, the SRAM using the fully current-mode technique consumes only 30% power dissipation as compared to the SRAM with only current-mode read operation. Experimental results show good agreement with the simulation results and prove the feasibility of the new technique.
Index Keywords: Amplifiers (electronic); Computer simulation; Current voltage characteristics; Energy dissipation; Logic design; MOSFET devices; Current mode read write operations; Current mode sensing circuit; Sense amplifier; Random access storage

Authors: Anon
Title: Insulator characterization by using a scanning electron microscope. Application to electrical insulation and to mechanics
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Electric Charge in Solid Insulators, CSC
Affiliations: LEO Electron Microscopy Ltd, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Anon, LEO Electron Microscopy Ltd, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: For many years it has been suspected that ageing and breakdown are related to the insulator charging properties. Although, no theory is still able to demonstrate the relation between charging and technological limitation, but it is established that a correlation exists between the trapping microscopic properties which depend on defects and the macroscopic behaviours. The demonstration that the defect formation is detected from charging analysis characteristics is made. It is suggested that the charge spreading characteristics may reflect the insulator aptitude to develop water tree. It will be shown that the observations which are made during high voltage can be reproduced under electron irradiation. Also, the correlation is illustrated in the field of Mechanics. It is shown that the wear rate depends on the trap energy and on the energy storage ability. Hence, the insulator characterization by using the Scanning Electron Microscope appears to be very powerful.
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Defects; Electric charge; Electric energy storage; Electron beams; Radiation damage; Scanning electron microscopy; Wear of materials; Charge spreading; Charge trapping; Electron irradiation; Insulator characterization; Electric insulating materials

Authors: Sokolov I.A., Kulikov V.V.
Title: Non-steady-state photocurrents and holographic recording in indium-oxide (In2O3) thin films
Source title: Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe - Technical Digest
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, St.-Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Sokolov, I.A., Russian Acad of Sciences, St.-Petersburg, Russian Federation; Kulikov, V.V., Russian Acad of Sciences, St.-Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: Indium-oxide thin films present interesting electrical and optical properties and high potential for technological applications. The conductivity of indium-oxide thin films grown by dc-magnetron or laser sputtering can be modified upon illumination with ultraviolet radiation (photon energy > 3.5 eV), resulting in a variable electrical state of the films from a resistive to a purely conductive one, while recently holographic recording has been demonstrated aiming to information storage and processing applications. We report simultaneous measurement of the non-steady-state photoelectromotive force and holographic recording in indium-oxide thin films at the He-Cd laser wavelength of 325 nm (Fig. 1). Two He-Cd laser beams formed a holographic grating in the thin film. One of the beams was phase modulated at frequency ω and a HeNe laser beam was monitoring the holographic recording. Two scattered beams of equal intensity were observed, corresponding to the ±1 diffraction orders of the recorded sinusoidal grating, and monitored. The non-steady-state photocurrent J$+ω/ was detected by applying lock-in techniques. The decay time constants of the diffraction efficiency and non-steady-state photocurrent were found to be in the range of 5-50 s, naturally depending on fringe spacing. Diffraction efficiency of the recorded grating was 2.5 × 10-5. The combination of the above methods provides a powerful tool for the investigation of holographic properties in this material.
Index Keywords: Diffraction gratings; Electric properties; Film growth; Helium neon lasers; Holography; Laser beams; Magnetron sputtering; Optical properties; Optical recording; Oxides; Phase modulation; Photocurrents; Holographic recording; Indium oxide; Laser sputtering; Thin films

Authors: Niemeyer Irmgard, Canty Morton, Klaus Dieter
Title: Possibilities and limits of remote sensing for the verification of international agreements: algorithms to detect changes at nuclear plants
Source title: International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (IGARSS)
Affiliations: Research Cent Juelich, Juelich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Niemeyer, Irmgard, Research Cent Juelich, Juelich, Germany; Canty, Morton, Research Cent Juelich, Juelich, Germany; Klaus, Dieter, Research Cent Juelich, Juelich, Germany
Abstract: The use of commercial satellite images for the verification of nuclear treaties has been suggested recently in the context of a new protocol extending the rights of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to verify the absence of undeclared nuclear activities within its member states. The present paper describes an application of principal component and canonical correlation analysis for change detection of Landsat TM images of the interim nuclear fuel storage and exploratory mine at Gorleben, Germany.

Authors: Kong M.G.
Title: Energy spread analysis for a multiharmonic optical klystron (MHOK)
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Univ of Liverpool, Liverpool, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kong, M.G., Univ of Liverpool, Liverpool, United Kingdom
Abstract: Optical klystrons (Oks) based on two wiggler sections of the same periodicity and a dispersion section in between are used to enhance the interaction gain in free electron lasers (FEL), especially those used in storage rings. It is shown that if the first wiggler section is replaced by a wiggler of multiple periodicities, a multiharmonic wiggler, more electrons in the beam will be grouped into tight bunches and as a result, the small signal gain of the resultant device will be enhanced considerably. Such arrangement is known as multiharmonic optical klystron (MHOK). The energy spread analysis of MHOK in the small signal limit is presented.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Electromagnetic dispersion; Electron beams; Free electron lasers; Harmonic analysis; Integral equations; Optical devices; Energy spread analysis; Multiharmonic optical klystrons (MHOK); Multiharmonic wigglers; Klystrons

Authors: Chinosi Mauro, Zafalon Roberto, Guardiani Carlo
Title: Automatic characterization and modeling of power consumption in static RAMs
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: STMicroelectronics CR&D, Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Chinosi, Mauro, STMicroelectronics CR&D, Milano, Italy; Zafalon, Roberto, STMicroelectronics CR&D, Milano, Italy; Guardiani, Carlo, STMicroelectronics CR&D, Milano, Italy
Abstract: An automatic modeling technique is presented in this paper that allows to build an accurate model of power consumption in embedded memory blocks. A software neural-network is used to create a regression tree by automatically splitting those variables that have a discontinuous effect on the power consumption. An application of the methodology to the modeling of a 0.35 μm CMOS embedded SRAM is presented.
