Authors: Morimoto T., Tsushima M., Suhara M., Hiratsuka K., Sanada Y., Kawasato T.
Title: Electric double-layer capacitor using organic electrolyte
Affiliations: Asahi Glass Co Ltd, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Morimoto, T., Asahi Glass Co Ltd, Yokohama, Japan; Tsushima, M., Asahi Glass Co Ltd, Yokohama, Japan; Suhara, M., Asahi Glass Co Ltd, Yokohama, Japan; Hiratsuka, K., Asahi Glass Co Ltd, Yokohama, Japan; Sanada, Y., Asahi Glass Co Ltd, Yokohama, Japan; Kawasato, T., Asahi Glass Co Ltd, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: Electric double-layer capacitors based on charge storage at the interface between a high surface area activated carbon electrode and a propylene carbonate solution are widely used as maintenance-free power sources for IC memories and microcomputers. New applications for electric double-layer capacitors have been proposed in recent years. The popularity of these devices is derived from their high energy density compared with conventional capacitors and their long cycle life and high power density relative to batteries. The performance of the capacitor depends not only on the materials used in the cells but also on the construction of the cells. The performance of power capacitors for large power sources as well as materials and construction of these capacitors are described.
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Carbonates; Electric batteries; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrodes; Electrolytes; Interfaces (materials); Electric double layer capacitors; Capacitor storage

Authors: Lewis Andrew L., Seppa Ilkka M.
Title: Right way to design medium consistency pulp pump systems
Source title: Proceedings of the TAPPI International Engineering Conference
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, Andrew L.; Seppa, Ilkka M.
Abstract: The right way to prevent pulsation and vibration in medium consistency pulp pipe system is to recognize and eliminate the sources of the pulsation and vibration during the design phase of the project. Minimizing the effect of pulsation and vibration in pulp piping systems has to be considered in the design phase of the project. All sources of pulsation and vibration have to be reviewed and the pump system design should include specifications that will minimize the effect of the energy source that can cause pulsation and vibration. Pulsation and vibration in pipe systems that transfer pulp in the consistency range of 8 to 16% BD, is a common problem in many pulp mills. The forces in the pipe system can rupture piping and can weaken and damage the piping system supports. The cost of maintenance and repair of the piping system and the piping support are usually high and are unbudgeted items. Production losses from unscheduled clown time for repair to the pipe system can also be high. One of the common `fixes' to reduce the pulsation level is to reduce the consistency of the pulp delivered to storage. At the lower consistencies the effective storage capacity of the storage vessel is reduced.
Index Keywords: Machine design; Maintenance; Paper and pulp mills; Piping systems; Pumps; Repair; Specifications; Storage (materials); Vibration control; Pulsation control; Papermaking machinery

Authors: Muggli P., Hoffman J., Liou R., Joshi C., Katsouleas T.
Title: Novel DARC sources
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Univ of Southern California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Muggli, P., Univ of Southern California, Los Angeles, United States; Hoffman, J., Univ of Southern California, Los Angeles, United States; Liou, R., Univ of Southern California, Los Angeles, United States; Joshi, C., Univ of Southern California, Los Angeles, United States; Katsouleas, T., Univ of Southern California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: A new device in the microwave frequency range is developed with pins inserted in the X-band waveguide through its narrow side wall to increase the power of the pulses produced by the direct current to alternating current radiation converter (DARC source). Cold tests show that between the stopbands created by the periodic pins the insertion loss of the structure is much smaller than that measured with previous structures. The stored electrostatic energy in the pin device is only a factor of 3 smaller than that of the plate case.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Plasma density; Power converters; Periodic pins; Tunable radiations; Plasma filled waveguides

Authors: von Czarnowski A., Fitting H.-J., Barfels T.
Title: IR mode softening due to charge trapping in SiO2
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Electric Charge in Solid Insulators, CSC
Affiliations: Rostock Univ, Rostock, Germany
Authors with affiliations: von Czarnowski, A., Rostock Univ, Rostock, Germany; Fitting, H.-J., Rostock Univ, Rostock, Germany; Barfels, T., Rostock Univ, Rostock, Germany
Abstract: The vibrational behaviour of amorphous SiO2 films thermally grown on silicon substrate has been investigated before and after electron irradiation and negative charge storage. The measurements were performed by means of Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. After an electron irradiation dose of 0.2 As/cm2 and saturated electron storage we realize a shift of the transverse-optical (TO) bond-stretching mode in SiO2 at 1090 cm-1 by about 10 cm-1 towards lower energies associated with an increase of the FWHM and a lowering of the vibrational strength. We interpret these experimental facts as creation of the twofold coordinated silicon defect = Si: starting from a simple oxygen vacancy in the SiO2 network as a precursor.
Index Keywords: Electric charge; Electrons; Film growth; Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy; Molecular vibrations; Silica; Charge trapping; Electron irradiation; Amorphous films

Authors: Clarkson Joseph B., Shackelford Peter R., Vega Luis A.
Title: Operation of a 360 kWh/day hybrid village power system
Affiliations: PICHTR, Honolulu, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clarkson, Joseph B., PICHTR, Honolulu, United States; Shackelford, Peter R., PICHTR, Honolulu, United States; Vega, Luis A., PICHTR, Honolulu, United States
Abstract: The operation of a 360 kWh/day hybrid village power system consisting of photovoltaic cell modules, battery storage, wind turbine generators, diesel generators and power converters is presented. The system is designed to serve as a testing and training facility for Pacific Islands applications. The hybrid system also supplies the electricity used at the Kahua Ranch Village on the Big Island of Hawaii. The Village is the residential and operational center for a cattle and sheep ranch.
Index Keywords: Diesel fuels; Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Photovoltaic cells; Power converters; Solar radiation; Wind power; Wind turbines; Hybrid village power systems; Electric power systems

Authors: Ibrahim Hajj Nikolaos Bellas, Polychronopoulos Constantine, Stamoulis George
Title: Architectural and compiler support for energy reduction in the memory hierarchy of high performance microprocessors
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Design
Affiliations: Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ibrahim Hajj, Nikolaos Bellas, Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States; Polychronopoulos, Constantine, Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States; Stamoulis, George, Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States
Abstract: In this paper we propose a technique that uses an additional mini cache located between the I-Cache and the CPU core, and buffers instructions that are nested within loops and are continuously otherwise fetched from the I-Cache. This mechanism is combined with code modifications, through the compiler, that greatly simplify the required hardware, eliminate unnecessary instruction fetching, and consequently reduce signal switching activity and the dissipated energy. We show that the additional cache, dubbed L-Cache, is much smaller and simpler than the I-Cache when the compiler assumes the role of allocating instructions in it. Through simulation, we show that, for the SPECfp95 benchmarks, the I-Cache remains disabled most of the time, and the 'cheaper' extra cache is used instead. We present experimental results that validate the effectiveness of this technique, and present the energy gains for most of the SPEC95 benchmarks.
Index Keywords: Computer hardware; Current voltage characteristics; Electric losses; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Microprocessor chips; Program compilers; Simulation; Switching; High performance microprocessors; Memory hierarchy; Signal switching activity; Buffer storage

Authors: Baker Shefford P., Keller Rose-Marie, Arzt Eduard
Title: Energy storage and recovery in thin metal films on substrates
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Inst fuer Metallforschung, Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Baker, Shefford P., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Metallforschung, Stuttgart, Germany; Keller, Rose-Marie, Max-Planck-Inst fuer Metallforschung, Stuttgart, Germany; Arzt, Eduard, Max-Planck-Inst fuer Metallforschung, Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: Dislocation segments which extend through the thickness of a film can move through the film only if dislocation line length is deposited or removed at the film/substrate and film/passivation (if any) interfaces. The dislocation density and, therefore, the energy stored in the film increase during plastic deformation. The reverse process, that is, the reduction of strain energy in the film by the reduction of dislocation line length, is here suggested to be the origin of a number of unexplained features of experimentally obtained stress-temperature curves, including very low (or even `negative') yield stresses in compression, tensile-compressive flow stress asymmetries, increasing strength with increasing temperature upon heating, and a very strong Bauschinger-like effect which has been seen in thin Cu films. The results of stress-temperature measurements of passivated Cu thin films on silicon substrates are presented.
Index Keywords: Compressive stress; Dislocations (crystals); Energy storage; Interfaces (materials); Passivation; Plastic flow; Strain; Stress analysis; Substrates; Temperature measurement; Thin films; Yield stress; Dislocation density; Dislocation line lengths; Metallic films

Authors: Biswal Subrat, Nees John, Faure Jerome, Nishimura Akihiko, Nishioka Hajime, Mourou Gerard
Title: Development of a compact, high-peak power ytterbium:glass laser
Source title: Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe - Technical Digest
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Biswal, Subrat, Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Nees, John, Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Faure, Jerome, Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Nishimura, Akihiko, Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Nishioka, Hajime, Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States; Mourou, Gerard, Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, United States
Abstract: In order to demonstrate the high-energy storage and the potential for high-energy extraction efficiency, a flat-flat cavity with an 18% output coupler was constructed around a 4.8-mm-long Yb:glass plate. The pump fluence incident on the Yb:glass was >300J/cm2 in a 100-μs pulse with no observed damage. With approximately 3.5 J stored by two-pass pumping, the Yb:glass, 1.5 J was extracted under free-running long-pulse conditions. However, efficient short-pulse amplification cannot occur with such a high gain in Yb:glass using current CPA techniques. The signal fluence can be reduced below damage threshold and can efficiently extract stored energy in a low-gain, low-loss regenerative amplifier (RA). Such a RA pumped by the 5-J Cr:LiSAF laser is currently being constructed.
Index Keywords: Band structure; Doping (additives); Etalons; Laser pulses; Light absorption; Optical pumping; Quantum theory; Spectrum analysis; Ytterbium; Absorption band; Chirped pulse amplification; Multiterawatt lasers; Quantum defect; Regenerative amplifier; Optically pumped lasers

Authors: Henze Gregor P., Dodier Robert H., Krarti Moncef
Title: Development of a predictive optimal controller for thermal energy storage systems
Affiliations: Johnson Controls, Essen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Henze, Gregor P., Johnson Controls, Essen, Germany; Dodier, Robert H., Johnson Controls, Essen, Germany; Krarti, Moncef, Johnson Controls, Essen, Germany
Abstract: This paper describes the development and simulation of a predictive optimal controller for thermal energy storage systems. The `optimal' strategy minimizes the cost of operating the cooling plant over the simulation horizon. The particular case of a popular ice storage system (ice-on-coil with internal melt) was investigated in a simulation environment. Various predictor models were analyzed with respect to their performance in forecasting cooling load data and information on ambient conditions (dry-bulb and wet-bulb temperatures). The predictor model provides load and weather information to the optimal controller in discrete time steps. An optimal storage charging and discharging strategy was planned at every time step over a fixed look-ahead time window utilizing newly available information. The first action of the optimal sequence of actions was executed over the next time step and the planning process was repeated at every following time step. The effect of the length of the planning horizon was investigated. It was found that short horizons of one day were only marginally suboptimal relative to one that is optimal over the entire simulation horizon of one week. Various utility rate structures were analyzed to cover a range of potential real-time pricing scenarios. The predictive optimal controller was then compared to conventional control heuristics. In summary, it was found that in the presence of complex rate structures the proposed controller had a significant performance benefit over the conventional controls, while requiring only a simple predictor.
Index Keywords: Control system analysis; Discrete time control systems; Energy efficiency; Heuristic methods; Ice; Mathematical models; Optimal control systems; Predictive control systems; Refrigerating machinery; Thermal load; Abstract only; Thermal energy storage systems; Energy storage

Authors: Li Y., Henkel J.
Title: A framework for estimating and minimizing energy dissipation of embedded HW/SW systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ  08544, United States; C and C Research Laboratories, NEC USA, 4 Independence Way, Princeton, NJ  08540, United States
Authors with affiliations: Li, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ  08544, United States; Henkel, J., C and C Research Laboratories, NEC USA, 4 Independence Way, Princeton, NJ  08540, United States
Abstract: Embedded system design is one of the most challenging tasks in VLSI CAD because of the vast amount of system parameters to fix and the great variety of constraints to meet. In this paper we focus on the constraint of low energy dissipation, an indispensable peculiarity of embedded mobile computing systems. We present the first comprehensive framework that simultaneously evaluates the tradeoffs of energy dissipations of software and hardware such as caches and main memory. Unlike previous work in low power research which focused only on software or hardware, our framework optimizes system parameters to minimize energy dissipation of the overall system. The trade-off between system performance and energy dissipation is also explored. Experimental results show that our Avalanche framework can drastically reduce system energy dissipation. © 1998 ACM.
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Economic and social effects; Embedded software; Embedded systems; Hardware; Mobile computing; Buffer storage; Computer aided design; Computer hardware; Computer software; Computer systems programming; Constraint theory; Energy dissipation; VLSI circuits; Hw/sw systems; Low energy dissipations; Low Power; Main memory; Mobile computing systems; Software and hardwares; Trade off; VLSI CAD; Energy dissipation; Embedded systems; Embedded hardware/software systems

Authors: Kaiser Andreas
Title: Two-step current-memory cells with optimal dynamic range for advanced CMOS technologies
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: UMR CNRS, Lille, France
Authors with affiliations: Kaiser, Andreas, UMR CNRS, Lille, France
Abstract: Improved two-step current-memory cell architectures employing current conveyors are proposed and compared with conventional ones over a wide range of technologies. Special emphasis is given to the evaluation of performance on very advanced state-of the art CMOS processes and the operation at low supply voltages. Up to 50% power savings can be expected with respect to conventional cells of same performance.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Computer architecture; Electric currents; Electric network analysis; Energy conservation; Two step current-memory cell architectures; Data storage equipment

Authors: Scalia Pietro
Title: Double-switch single-stage PFC Offline Switcher operating in CCM with high efficiency and low cost
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: ITALTEL - Energy Systems R&D, Carini, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Scalia, Pietro, ITALTEL - Energy Systems R&D, Carini, Italy
Abstract: A Three-Switched-Networks SEPIC, PFC 350 W Rectifier, utilizing magnetic integration at input and operating in CCM for every input and load conditions, is presented. The proposed Off-line Switcher shows convenient energy storage at low voltage, good load regulation, easy to implement output over-voltage and short-circuit protection, low inrush current and no heavy input filter. For all tire above reasons it assures high efficiency and low cost. Operation of the converter, most design rules and procedures are described and some basic results from a laboratory prototype are also given.
Index Keywords: Offline switchers; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric power factor correction; Electric power system protection; Electric rectifiers; Power converters; Electric switches

Authors: Noginov M.A., Loutts G.B., Noginova N., Warren M., Jackson C., Bonner C., Rakhimov R., Ries H.

Source title: Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe - Technical Digest
Affiliations: Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States
Authors with affiliations: Noginov, M.A., Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States; Loutts, G.B., Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States; Noginova, N., Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States; Warren, M., Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States; Jackson, C., Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States; Bonner, C., Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States; Rakhimov, R., Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States; Ries, H., Norfolk State Univ, Norfolk, United States
Abstract: Mn ions in different valence states as well as transitions between different valence states responsible for photoinduced coloration of Mn:YAlO3 were spectroscopically investigated. In as grown yellowish Mn:YAlO3, Mn4+ ions in optical absorption spectra and both Mn2+ and Mn4+ ions in electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were detected. No distinguishable concentration of Mn3+ ions was found in as grown yellowish Mn:YAlO3. Under (ultraviolet to green) illumination, the crystal changed its color from yellowish to grayish-bluish. At room temperature, Mn4+ luminescence was observed at 0.67-0.73 μm. Intense charge transfer (CT) bands were observed in ultraviolet (UV) absorption spectra of Mn:YAlO3.

Authors: Faehl R.J., Pogue E.W.
Title: Pulsed power approach to pumping dielectric-filled rf cavities
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Faehl, R.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Pogue, E.W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Dielectric-filled radiofrequency cavities facilitate the acceleration of high current pulses within the framework of conventional charged-particle accelerator architectures because it can store much greater electromagnetic energy than a similar size vacuum cavity. For water, with e/eo = 80, the additional energy storage result in proportionately high particle current before cavity depletion. The high dissipation rate of water leads to design constraints which restricts dielectric cavities to pulsed accelerator systems. A possible solution is to employ wakefield techniques which use inductive fields on the rising current segment of an intense electron beam to power the resonant dielectric cavities.
Index Keywords: Dielectric devices; Electric fields; Electron beams; Energy dissipation; Energy storage; Natural frequencies; Particle accelerators; Water; Wakefield technique; Cavity resonators

Authors: Goss Joel O., Hyman Lucas B., Corbett Jim
Title: Integrated heating and cooling thermal energy storage with heat pump provides economic and environmental solutions
Affiliations: Goss Engineering, Inc, Corona, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goss, Joel O., Goss Engineering, Inc, Corona, United States; Hyman, Lucas B., Goss Engineering, Inc, Corona, United States; Corbett, Jim, Goss Engineering, Inc, Corona, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the scenario that led to two unique thermal storage systems at a California state university: one for heating and one for cooling. The low-temperature water storage tank provides about 36,000 ton-hours of chilled water. The high-temperature storage system provides 150°F (66 °C) water for campus heating. The solution - low-temperature chilled water storage, medium-temperature heating water storage, and heat pump - is particularly interesting because of the high electrical rates in Southern California. This paper provides background on why the system was installed, its installation, and its performance since installation. Particular emphasis is placed on the ability of the system to meet environmental concerns unique to the Southern California region.
Index Keywords: Cold storage; Cooling; Cost effectiveness; Environmental protection; Heat pump systems; Heat storage; Heating; Thermoelectricity; Water tanks; Thermal energy storage systems (TES); Energy storage

Authors: Khripov A.A.
Title: Maximal RF energy storage in a probe of clinical MR tomograph using the system of flexible solenoids
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Biomedical Engineering Days
Affiliations: St. Petersburg State Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Khripov, A.A., St. Petersburg State Univ, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: This article shows that the flexible inductance coil, proposed by the author first in [1,2], can experimentally and theoretically be described as an infinite set of solenoidal coils which have a flexible form and a fixed radius within the range from the maximal to minimal one determined by the given coil construction. Here we call the proposed device as a system of flexible solenoids (SFS). Both the energy and amplitude consideration of Signal to Noise ratio (SNR) in Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) experiments of the low frequencies range up to 100 MHz tells about the optimal performance of the solenoidal coil for samples embraced by its winding. Many progressive NMR applications in medicine and biology reveal some restrictions with a conventional solenoid that can be expressed in its fixed, closed geometry and, as a consequence, low filling factor for in-vivo studies. The proposed device resolves the difficulties that becomes its main advantage. The test of the receiver SFS indicating the SNR improvement in comparison with a surface receiver and quadrature transmit/receive coils has been carried out on `Toross' 0.11 T (5 MHz) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) system, Russia and `Vectra' 0.5 T (21.29 MHz) GEMS MRI system.
Index Keywords: Magnetic resonance imaging; Nuclear magnetic resonance; Signal to noise ratio; Solenoids; Tomography; Flexible solenoids; Medical imaging

Authors: Kapoor Bhanu
Title: Analyzing effects of cache parameters on memory power consumption of video applications
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Texas Instruments Inc, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kapoor, Bhanu, Texas Instruments Inc, Dallas, United States
Abstract: Energy efficient computing is growing in demand as portable systems require energy efficiency in order to maximize the battery life. We provide data and insight into how the choice of cache parameters affects memory power consumption of video algorithms. We make use of memory traces generated as a result of running typical video algorithms to simulate a large number of cache configurations. The cache simulation data is then combined with on-chip and off-chip memory power models to compute memory power consumption. The configurations of particular interest are the ones that optimize power under certain constraints. We also study the role of process technology in these experiments. In particular, we look at how moving to a more advanced process technology for the on-chip cache affects optimal points of operation with respect to memory power consumption.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Energy efficiency; Memory power consumption; Video applications; Buffer storage

Authors: Hatipoglu Serkan, Mitra Sanjit K.
Title: Texture feature extraction using Teager filters and singular value decomposition
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers - IEEE International Conference on Consumer Electronics
Affiliations: Univ of California, Santa Barbara, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hatipoglu, Serkan, Univ of California, Santa Barbara, CA, United States; Mitra, Sanjit K., Univ of California, Santa Barbara, CA, United States
Abstract: The use of singular value decomposition (SVD) values and quadratic Teager filters for image characterization is investigated. SVD values and Teager filter outputs represent different characteristics of the image texture and this property is utilized to efficiently characterize the image. Local energy values of the image texture are found by using 2-D energy filters. Filter outputs are combined with the eigenvalues obtained from SVD of local image portions and they form the feature vector for the given image. The normalized Euclidian distance between feature vectors of different images gives us a similarity measure for these images. Experimental results show that the representation is efficient in terms of storage space and retrieval accuracy.
Index Keywords: Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Electric filters; Image processing; Signal filtering and prediction; Singular value decomposition (SVD); Teager filters; Texture feature extraction; Feature extraction

Authors: Perez Polanco Rene, Rodriguez Betancourt Enrique
Title: Natural gas transmission opening trade in Mexico: Energy and environmental benefits
Source title: Proceedings of the International Pipeline Conference, IPC
Affiliations: Pemex Gas y Petroquimica Basica, Mexico, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Perez Polanco, Rene, Pemex Gas y Petroquimica Basica, Mexico, Mexico; Rodriguez Betancourt, Enrique, Pemex Gas y Petroquimica Basica, Mexico, Mexico
Abstract: This paper provides a summary of some management-technical changes and Pemex's actions to face challenges derived from transportation, distribution, storage and marketing natural gas liberalization. Since natural gas consumption hasn't shown uniform growth for all consumer sectors, the Mexican Government decided to change the `rules of the game' to guarantee that such operations could attain the efficiency levels planned for 1995-2000. Thus, Constitutional Article 27 was reformed in 1995, the Energy Regulatory Commission and Natural Gas Regulation were created. This opened the doors to domestic and international investors to participate in transportation and distribution projects. So, to face this challenges and new missions, PGPB started working on new programs and projects to update it's pipeline transmission system, such as risk management, operational reliability, quality systems, scada operation, re-engineering business procedures and strategic planning to improve benefits and reduce incident/accidents. Finally, the energetic and environmental advantages of natural gas are addressed.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Commerce; Energy conservation; Environmental impact; Environmental protection; Gas fuel storage; Marketing; Quality assurance; Reliability; Risk management; SCADA systems; Strategic planning; Business procedure reengineering; Operational reliability; Natural gas pipelines

Authors: Matsuo Hirofumi, Tu Lishan, Kurokawa Fujio, Watanabe Haruo
Title: Novel soft-switching buck-boost type ac-dc converter with high power efficiency, high power factor and low harmonic distortion
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuo, Hirofumi, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan; Tu, Lishan, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan; Kurokawa, Fujio, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan; Watanabe, Haruo, Nagasaki Univ, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the novel soft-switching buck-boost type ac-dc converter with high power efficiency and high power factor. In this ac-dc converter, the power factor and harmonic distortions are improved by using the third winding of the energy-storage reactor, and the high power efficiency is achieved by the soft-switching operations of the main power switch and output rectifier diode. The equivalent circuit model with dc voltage sources is derived and the performance characteristics are analyzed by this model. The analytical results are confirmed by the experimental ones. As a result, it is clarified that the proposed ac-dc converter satisfies the maximum limits of the input current harmonics distortion in IEC 1000-3-2 Class D and that its power efficiency is 95% at the rated load current.
Index Keywords: Alternating current-direct current (AC-DC) converters; Soft-switching operations; Diodes; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric power factor; Electric rectifiers; Electric switches; Energy efficiency; Equivalent circuits; Harmonic analysis; Integrated circuit layout; Mathematical models; Power converters

Authors: Khellah Muhammad M., Elmasry M.I.
Title: Circuit techniques for high-speed and low-power multi-port SRAMs

Affiliations: Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Khellah, Muhammad M., Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada; Elmasry, M.I., Univ of Waterloo, Waterloo, Canada
Abstract: This paper presents a new approach based on current-mode to reduce the energy and improve the speed of write and read accesses in multi-port SRAMs. The design of a pipelined 32×64 register file that utilizes the above technique is described. Simulation results in a 0.6 um CMOS technology show that the register file can operate at a 500 MHz frequency using a 2.3 V supply.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Computer simulation; Power amplifiers; Low-power current-mode sense amplifiers; Static random access memory (SRAM); Random access storage

Authors: Chen Liang-Gee, Jiu Juing-Ying, Chang Hao-Chieh
Title: Design and implementation of low power DCT chip for portable multimedia terminals
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Systems, SiPS: Design and Implementation
Affiliations: Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, Liang-Gee, Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Jiu, Juing-Ying, Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Chang, Hao-Chieh, Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: This paper describes the design and implementation of a low power 2-D DCT chip for portable multimedia terminals. The chip architecture based on direct 2-D approach reduces computational complexity and the power dissipation can be reduced accordingly. In the implementation of the direct 2-D algorithm, a parallel distributed arithmetic (DA) architecture at reduced supply voltage is adopted. In the real circuit implementation of the chip, an adder of low power consumption is designed, as well as a power-saving ROM and a low voltage two-port SRAM with sequential access. The resultant 2-D DCT chip is realized by 0.6 μm single-poly double-metal technology. Critical path simulation indicates a maximum input rate of 133 MHz, and it consumes 138 mW at 100 MHz. The measured chip speed is around 100 MHz.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computational complexity; Computer architecture; Cosine transforms; Digital arithmetic; Energy dissipation; Energy utilization; Integrated circuit layout; Multimedia systems; Parallel processing systems; Random access storage; Discrete cosine transforms (DCT); Parallel distributed arithmetic (DA); Static random access memory (SRAM); Microprocessor chips

Authors: Norford Leslie K., Englander Scott L., Wiseley Benjamin J.
Title: Demonstration knowledge base to aid building operators in responding to real-time-pricing electricity rates
Affiliations: MIT, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Norford, Leslie K., MIT, Cambridge, United States; Englander, Scott L., MIT, Cambridge, United States; Wiseley, Benjamin J., MIT, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: The objective of ASHRAE Research Project 833, the results of which are summarized in this paper, was to develop a knowledge base, tested in demonstration software, that would assist building operators in assessing the benefits of controlling electrical equipment in response to electricity rates that vary hourly. The software combines a knowledge base with computations, both of which are controlled by the user via a graphical interface. Major electrical end uses of commercial buildings are considered. The knowledge base is used to assess the trade-off of service and cost that is implicit in establishing a threshold price, above which lighting is reduced or space temperatures are allowed to deviate from setpoint. The software also evaluates thermal storage systems and on-site generation, in which occupant comfort is not affected and the systems are operated to minimize operating costs. The thermal storage and generator control algorithms have proved to be optimal under limiting cases by comparison with mixed-integer programming.
Index Keywords: Computer software; Electric rates; Graphical user interfaces; Integer programming; Knowledge based systems; Office buildings; Real time systems; Mixed integer programming; Real time pricing electricity rates; Energy conservation

Authors: Das Bodhisattva, Black Jr. William C.
Title: Generalized HSPICE macro-model for pseudo-spin-valve GMR memory bits
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Iowa State Univ, Ames, United States
Authors with affiliations: Das, Bodhisattva, Iowa State Univ, Ames, United States; Black Jr., William C., Iowa State Univ, Ames, United States
Abstract: Nonvolatile semiconductor storage using Giant-Magneto-Resistance (GMR) memory bits has the potential for revolutionizing both high density and high speed memory applications with devices exhibiting unlimited write endurance and very low required write energy. This work presents the first generalized circuit macro-model for a pseudo-spin-valve GMR memory bit. The macro-model is realized as a four terminal sub-circuit which emulates GMR bit behavior over a wide range of sense and word line currents. The non-volatile and nonlinear nature of GMR memory bits are accurately represented by this model and simulations of non-volatile GMR latch structures with HSPICE show expected outcomes. The model is flexible and relatively simple: ranges of the write/read currents and bit resistance values are incorporated as parameterized variables and no semiconductor devices are used within the model.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Computer software; Magnetoresistance; Nonvolatile storage; Giant magnetoresistance (GMR) memory bits; Software package HSPICE; Semiconductor storage

Authors: He J.-H., Schilling P.J., Ma E.
Title: Synchrotron X-ray absorption studies of atomic-level alloying in immiscible mixtures
Affiliations: Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, LA, United States
Authors with affiliations: He, J.-H., Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, LA, United States; Schilling, P.J., Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, LA, United States; Ma, E., Louisiana State Univ, Baton Rouge, LA, United States
Abstract: An X-ray absorption beamline has been developed recently at the electron storage ring of the LSU Center for Advanced Microstructures and Devices. Using Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) and X-ray Absorption Near Edge Structure (XANES), we have studied the local atomic environments in immiscible mixtures processed by high-energy ball milling, a mechanical alloying technique involving heavy deformation. By examining the local coordination and bond distances, it is concluded that atomic-level alloying can indeed be induced between Cu and Fe through milling at room temperature, forming substitutional fcc and bcc solid solutions. In addition to single-phase regions, a two-phase region consisting of fcc/bcc solutions has been found after milling at both room temperature and liquid nitrogen temperature. In contrast to the Cu-Fe system, solid solution formation is not detectable in milled Ag-Fe and Cu-Ta mixtures. This work demonstrates the power of synchrotron EXAFS/XANES experiments in monitoring nonequilibrium alloying on the atomic level. At the same time, the results provide direct experimental evidence of the capability as well as limitations of high-energy ball milling to form alloys in positive-heat-of-mixing systems.
Index Keywords: Ball milling; Binary mixtures; Solid solutions; X ray analysis; Atomic-level alloying; Extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS); X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES); Mechanical alloying

Authors: Xiao T.D., Reisner D.E., Strutt P.R.
Title: High density active-site MnO2 nanofibers for energy storage and conversion applications
Affiliations: US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States
Authors with affiliations: Xiao, T.D., US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States; Reisner, D.E., US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States; Strutt, P.R., US Nanocorp, Inc, North Haven, United States
Abstract: This investigation involves the synthesis of MnO2 nanofibrous materials, via an aqueous chemical synthesis route. A critical step in the synthesis is the extended period of the refluxing of the reactive constituents, which enables the gradual transformation of the initial amorphous nanoparticles into a random-weave nanofibrous structure, in the form of a bird's nest superstructure. The bird's nest has a diameter of approximately 10 μm, which is an assemblage of many individual nanofibers with a diameter of about 15 nm, and a length up to 1 μm. Partial transformation of the nanostructured MnO2 realizes a novel bimodal morphology, which combines a high density of chemically active sites with an enhanced percolation rate. Characterization of these nanofibers include SEM, TEM, surface area, and chemical analysis. High resolution TEM observations reveals that the as-synthesized MnO2 nanofibers contain lattice defects, including molecular pores, meso- and micro-pores.
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Crystal defects; Crystal lattices; Morphology; Nanostructured materials; Percolation (solid state); Scanning electron microscopy; Synthesis (chemical); Transmission electron microscopy; Manganese oxides; Random weave nanofibrous structures; Manganese compounds

Authors: Emerson Ryan P., Bakis Charles E.
Title: Relaxation of press-fit interference pressure in composite flywheel assemblies
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Emerson, Ryan P., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States; Bakis, Charles E., Pennsylvania State Univ, University Park, United States
Abstract: Relaxation of pressure in interference-fitted filament wound composite rings was experimentally investigated. The ring materials, shapes, and pressures were selected to be representative of typical rings for flywheel energy storage systems, where press-fitting and rotation cause long-term loadings that can lead to time-dependent deformation and stress redistribution. Two initial pressures and three interference-fitted ring pair configurations were used; carbon/epoxy on glass/epoxy, carbon/epoxy on aluminum, and aluminum on glass/epoxy. For the composite-on-composite assemblies a 3-4% pressure drop was observed, and for the assemblies with aluminum a 4-5% pressure drop was observed. Approximately steady-state pressures were realized within 500 hours after assembly of the ring pairs. The steady-state pressure losses are percentage-wise independent of the initial pressures, suggesting that a linear-viscoelastic model may apply to these materials.
Index Keywords: Creep; Deformation; Energy storage; Flywheels; Loads (forces); Pressure drop; Relaxation processes; Stress concentration; Composite flywheel assemblies; Interference fitted filament wound composite ring; Linear viscoelastic model; Press fitting; Thick composite; Composite structures

Authors: Benini Luca, Bogliolo Alessandro, Cavallucci Stefano, Ricco Bruno
Title: Monitoring system activity for OS-directed dynamic power management
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Universita di Bologna, Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Benini, Luca, Universita di Bologna, Bologna, Italy; Bogliolo, Alessandro, Universita di Bologna, Bologna, Italy; Cavallucci, Stefano, Universita di Bologna, Bologna, Italy; Ricco, Bruno, Universita di Bologna, Bologna, Italy
Abstract: In this paper we describe a workload monitoring system that has been specifically designed for supporting dynamic power management in personal computers with tight power constraints (such as laptop or notebook computers). Our monitoring system is minimally intrusive, and has negligible impact on system activity. Moreover, it can be used both for on-line system monitoring and off-line data collection. We used our monitoring tool to collect data on the usage of system resources (disks, CPU, keyboard and mouse) for a laptop computer, under several workload conditions. Our analysis shows that resource usage is strongly resource and workload dependent, and that on-line usage monitoring capability is a critical issue of the implementation of effective power management policies.
Index Keywords: Computer keyboards; Computer operating systems; Computer selection and evaluation; Data acquisition; Energy management; Magnetic disk storage; Mice (computer peripherals); Online systems; Operating system-directed dynamic power management; Personal computers

Authors: Singh D., Wu T., Wendling M., Bendale P., Ware J., Ritter D., Zhang L.
Title: Mechanisms causing capacity loss on long term storage in NiMH system
Affiliations: Energizer Power Systems, Gainesville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, D., Energizer Power Systems, Gainesville, United States; Wu, T., Energizer Power Systems, Gainesville, United States; Wendling, M., Energizer Power Systems, Gainesville, United States; Bendale, P., Energizer Power Systems, Gainesville, United States; Ware, J., Energizer Power Systems, Gainesville, United States; Ritter, D., Energizer Power Systems, Gainesville, United States; Zhang, L., Energizer Power Systems, Gainesville, United States
Abstract: The different mechanisms that cause self discharge and capacity loss after storage and loaded storage with the NiMH system are discussed. Capacity loss after long term storage involves two main events. One is self discharge which causes the open circuit voltage (OCV) of the cell to drop. Self discharge is caused by decomposition of NiOOH, migration of metal ions and possible degradation of separator. The OCV drop causes a breakdown of the cobalt conductive network in the nickel positive electrode. The permanent breakdown in the conductive network results in low efficiency of the cell on consecutive and discharge cycles.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Cathodes; Electric breakdown; Electric energy storage; Nickel; Nickel metal hydride cells; Open circuit voltage (OCV); Secondary batteries

Authors: Samra Abdul H., Siddiquie Sajjad A.
Title: Optimum design of hybrid resonant converter for energy storage capacitors
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Caracas Conference on Devices, Circuits and Systems, ICCDCS
Affiliations: Florida Int Univ, Miami, United States
Authors with affiliations: Samra, Abdul H., Florida Int Univ, Miami, United States; Siddiquie, Sajjad A., Florida Int Univ, Miami, United States
Abstract: Resonant converter topologies may be used for applications in pulse power systems. And these are of three types: series loaded, parallel-loaded and series-parallel loaded. A circuit has been built that incorporates the third type, the concept of splitting the resonant circuit capacitance into a series component and a parallel component. The switching scheme presented for this design provides a discontinuous mode of operation with constant on-time constant frequency operation. The design, operation, and control of the series-parallel power converter along with the output test results proves that this topology offers an effective way of charging energy storage capacitors to voltage levels on the order of 3 kv.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Capacitor storage; Capacitors; Electric network synthesis; Electric network topology; Electric power systems; Switching; Energy storage capacitors; Hybrid resonant converter; Pulse power systems; Power converters

Authors: Kessling Wolfgang, Laevemann Eberhard, Peltzer Matthias
Title: Energy storage for solar desiccant cooling systems
Affiliations: ZAE Bayern, Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kessling, Wolfgang, ZAE Bayern, Munich, Germany; Laevemann, Eberhard, ZAE Bayern, Munich, Germany; Peltzer, Matthias, ZAE Bayern, Munich, Germany
Abstract: Liquid desiccant cooling systems offer several advantages compared to conventional desiccant systems in respect of solar cooling, e.g. lower regeneration temperature potential, higher COP potential, and energy storage potential. Conditions are outlined under which these potentials can be realized, efficient energy storage being the major objective. Solid and liquid desiccants are compared. A cooled liquid desiccant absorber for air dehumidification and efficient energy storage capacity (1000 MJ/m3), based on special exchanger surfaces, has been developed and built. Experimental results using LiCl-H2O solution as desiccant are reported.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Energy storage; Heat exchangers; Lithium compounds; Solar absorbers; Air dehumidification; Liquid desiccant cooling systems; Solar desiccant cooling systems; Solar energy

Authors: von Halle A.
Title: Final operations of the tokamak fusion test reactor (TFTR)
Affiliations: Princeton Plasma Physics Lab, Princeton, United States
Authors with affiliations: von Halle, A., Princeton Plasma Physics Lab, Princeton, United States
Abstract: The TFTR completed its final operating period in 1997 bringing to a close a highly successful phase of research in plasma science. Safe operation of the TFTR systems in D-T has been demonstrated, with over 950kCi of tritium processed within the constraints of a 50kCi site limit and a 20kCi machine limit. The Tritium Purification System 'closed the loop' on the TFTR fuel cycle during the final operating campaign, processing >50kCi of tritium at >98% purity back to the Tritium Storage and Delivery System U-Beds for further use on TFTR experiments.
Index Keywords: Deuterium; Fusion reactions; Magnetoplasma; Nuclear energy; Planning; Plasma confinement; Plasma density; Plasma heating; Tokamak devices; Tritium; Alpha heating; Fusion energy; Tokamak fusion test reactors; Experimental reactors

Authors: Coumeri Sari L., Thomas Donald E.
Title: Memory modeling for system synthesis
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States
Authors with affiliations: Coumeri, Sari L., Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States; Thomas, Donald E., Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States
Abstract: We present our methodology for developing models of on-chip SRAM memory organizations. The models were created to enable the quick evaluation of energy, area, and performance of different memory configurations considered during synthesis. The models are defined in terms of parameters, such as size and mode of operation, which are known at synthesis time. Our methodology does not require knowledge of the underlying memory circuitry and provides models with average percentage errors within 8%. We found that only 10 different memories from a large span of possible memory sizes are needed to obtain reasonably accurate models, with average errors within 15%. We further use these models to evaluate different low power memory organizations and have seen energy reductions of up to 88%. In this paper we present our modeling methodology, discuss the important aspects in developing the models, and show results of using the models in evaluating low power memory organizations.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Mathematical models; Microprocessor chips; Storage allocation (computer); Static random access memory (SRAM); Random access storage

Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States, IEEE and ACM/SIGDA; Téllez, G.E., Dept. of Elec. Eng. and Comp. Sci., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, United States; Sarrafzadeh, M., Dept. of Elec. Eng. and Comp. Sci., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States
Abstract: Sleep mode operation and exploiting it to minimize the average power consumption are of great importance in modern VLSI circuits. In general, sleep mode refers to the mode in which part(s) of the system are idle. In this paper, we study the problem of partitioning a circuit according to the activity patterns of its elements such that circuit elements with similar activity patterns are packed into the same partition. Then a partition can be placed in sleep mode during the time intervals all elements contained in that partition are idle. We formulate the partitioning problem to exploit sleep mode operation and show that the problem is NP-complete. We present polynomial time algorithms for practical classes of the problem. Applications of the problem to memory and module partitioning and clock gating are discussed. The experimental data confirm that a careful partitioning allows upto 40% more sleep time which could be exploited to minimize the average power consumption.
Author Keywords: NP-Completeness; Partitioning; Power minimization; Sleep mode
Index Keywords: Computational complexity; Data storage equipment; Electric network analysis; Electric network synthesis; Energy utilization; Problem solving; Memory partitioning; Sleep mode operation; VLSI circuits

Authors: Kakehashi H., Habu M., Ninomiya T., Shoyama M., Ogasawara H., Ohta Y.
Title: Analysis of an HID-lamp igniter using a two-stage magnetic-pulse-compression circuit
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Matsushita Electric Works, Ltd, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kakehashi, H., Matsushita Electric Works, Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Habu, M., Matsushita Electric Works, Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Ninomiya, T., Matsushita Electric Works, Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Shoyama, M., Matsushita Electric Works, Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Ogasawara, H., Matsushita Electric Works, Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Ohta, Y., Matsushita Electric Works, Ltd, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: This paper proposes a High-Intensity-Discharge (HID) lamp igniter using a two-stage magnetic-pulse-compression (MPC) circuit. The circuit operation is analyzed, and an optimal design procedure for selecting the saturable reactors and energy-storage capacitors is derived. Experimental verification is also given. This igniter can generate voltage pulses whose peak value and pulse width are 50 kV and 800 ns, respectively.
Index Keywords: High-intensity-discharge (HID) lamp igniters; Magnetic-pulse-compression (MPC) circuits; Capacitor storage; Electric network analysis; Saturable core reactors; Discharge lamps

Authors: Hsu Chin-Yuan, Wu Horng-Yuan, Ngo Khai D.T.
Title: Analysis and design of regenerative load system for power system test
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Natl Kaohsiung Inst of Technology, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Hsu, Chin-Yuan, Natl Kaohsiung Inst of Technology, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Wu, Horng-Yuan, Natl Kaohsiung Inst of Technology, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Ngo, Khai D.T., Natl Kaohsiung Inst of Technology, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
Abstract: This paper has presented a regenerative load system to replace the conventional passive load for long-term testing of power equipment and motor-generator set. This system has three merits: economic, safety and power quality improvement. The energy consumption can be less than 20% of the passive load and the utility source current can be shaped into pure sinusoidal waveform with power factor nearly to one. For reality, the utility source inductance Ls is taken into consideration. Through root-locus analysis and PSpice simulation, we conclude that for a stable system, the following conditions must be met: (1) addition of a damping circuit and (2) the current gain of the inverter must be kept below one. In addition, we have developed a simple control method to regulate the energy-storage capacitor voltage, using the energy-balance concept and memory circuit to calculate the required utility source current. The transient response is less than two cycles. Finally, PSpice simulation and experimental results are provided to verify the feasibility of this regenerative load system.
Index Keywords: Device under test (DUT); Energy balance; Regenerative load systems; Software package PSpice; Capacitor storage; Computer simulation; Electric inverters; Electric loads; Electric network analysis; Energy efficiency; Power control; Transients; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Ready W.J., Smith B.A., Turbini L.J., Stock S.R.
Title: Analysis of catastrophic field failures due to conductive anodic filament (CAF) formation
Affiliations: Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ready, W.J., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States; Smith, B.A., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States; Turbini, L.J., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States; Stock, S.R., Georgia Inst of Technology, Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: Under certain environmental conditions, printed wiring boards (PWB) respond to applied voltages by developing subsurface deposits of copper salts extending from anode to cathode along separated fiber/epoxy interfaces. The formation of these deposits, termed conductive anodic filaments (CAF) require high humidity (80%RH) and high voltage gradient (5 V/mil). The humidity exposure during the storage environment may cause the failure in the use environment. CAF formation is enhanced by the use of certain hot air solder leveling (HASL) fluids and/or water soluble flux constituents. In this work, two catastrophic field failures were analyzed. Both failures were related to boards produced in a manufacturing process, which included HASL. One CAF failure occurred between a component through-hole and power plane held at a potential difference of 40 V with a 0.005 inch nominal spacing. The other occurred on an inner layer of a multi-layer board (MLB) between a via and ground plane held at a potential difference of 320 V with 0.015 inch nominal spacing. The nature of the CAF was analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS). Ion chromatography (IC) was used to identify residue extracted from a failed board. The failure phenomena known as CAF poses serious long-term reliability concerns in electronic products exposed to adverse and hostile environments, especially those with closely spaced conductors.
Index Keywords: Chromatographic analysis; Conductive materials; Energy dispersive spectroscopy; Failure analysis; Printed circuit boards; Scanning electron microscopy; Catastrophic field failures; Conductive anodic filament (CAF); Electronics packaging

Authors: Simonson Carey J., Besant Robert W.
Title: Heat and moisture transfer in desiccant coated rotary energy exchangers: Part II - validation and sensitivity studies
Affiliations: Univ of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Simonson, Carey J., Univ of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada; Besant, Robert W., Univ of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada
Abstract: In Part II, results from the numerical model are compared with experimental data. The agreement between the measured and simulated effectiveness (sensible, latent, and total energy) is very close and within the experimental uncertainty. In addition, the effect of certain assumptions was investigated for sensitivity on the predicted performance of regenerative energy exchangers. The sensitivity results are calculated with an aluminum matrix wheel that is coated with a molecular sieve desiccant. Neglecting thermal and moisture storage in the air is shown to result in errors as large as 2.4% in the predicted effectiveness of a rotary energy exchanger at typical wheel speeds. Including the heat of sorption in the model affects the predicted effectiveness only slightly (<0.5%). However, the predicted effectiveness is greatly affected (up to 48%) by whether the heat of phase change is assumed to remain in the air or in the matrix. Controlling the energy rate of the energy exchanger by controlling wheel speed may be impractical because the sensitivity of each effectiveness to wheel speed differs with each operating condition. The model is also used to show the importance of the entry length and thermal conductivity on the predicted performance of rotary energy exchangers.
Index Keywords: Heat transfer; Mathematical models; Moisture; Molecular sieves; Phase transitions; Sensitivity analysis; Speed control; Thermal conductivity of gases; Desiccant coated rotary energy exchangers; Heat exchangers

Authors: Hong I., Kirovski D., Qu G., Potkonjak M., Srivastava M.B.
Title: Power optimization of variable voltage core-based systems
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, University of California, Los Angeles, CA  90095-1596, United States; Electrical Engineering Department, University of California, Los Angeles, CA  90095-1 596, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hong, I., Computer Science Department, University of California, Los Angeles, CA  90095-1596, United States; Kirovski, D., Computer Science Department, University of California, Los Angeles, CA  90095-1596, United States; Qu, G., Computer Science Department, University of California, Los Angeles, CA  90095-1596, United States; Potkonjak, M., Computer Science Department, University of California, Los Angeles, CA  90095-1596, United States; Srivastava, M.B., Electrical Engineering Department, University of California, Los Angeles, CA  90095-1 596, United States
Abstract: The growing class of portable systems, such as personal computing and communication devices, has resulted in a new set of system design requirements, mainly characterized by dominant importance of power minimization and design reuse. We develop the design methodology for the low power core-based real-time system-on-chip based on dynamically variable voltage hardware. The key challenge is to develop effective scheduling techniques that treat voltage as a variable to be determined, in addition to the conventional task scheduling and allocation. Our synthesis technique also addresses the selection of the processor core and the determination of the instruction and data cache size and configuration so as to fully exploit dynamically variable voltage hardware, which result In significantly lower power consumption for a set of target applications than existing techniques. The highlight of the proposed approach is the non-preemptive scheduling heuristic which results in solutions very close to optimal ones for many test cases. The effectiveness of the approach is demonstrated on a variety of modem industrial-strength multimedia and communication applications. © 1998 ACM.
Index Keywords: Interactive computer systems; Optimization; Personal computing; Real time systems; Scheduling; System-on-chip; Buffer storage; Computer hardware; Energy utilization; Heuristic methods; Microprocessor chips; Multimedia systems; Personal computing; Real time systems; Communication application; Communication device; Industrial strength; Lower-power consumption; Power Optimization; Scheduling techniques; Synthesis techniques; Target application; Integrated circuit design; Computer systems programming; Variable voltage core-based systems

Authors: von Daak Matthias, Hille Peter, Silber Dieter
Title: New concept for fast photovoltaic MOS-driver with protection
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference

Abstract: In this paper a new concept for photovoltaic MOS drivers is presented providing fast switching speed for power MOS devices. Control signal encoding allows the continuous transfer of optical energy, a storage capacitor provides active low impedance gate control and allows the implementation of additional features like protection, zero voltage or zero current switching. The principle of operation and experimental results are presented.

Authors: Henze Gregor P., Krarti Moncef, Brandemuehl Michael J.
Title: Simulation environment for the analysis of ice storage controls
Affiliations: Johnson Controls, Essen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Henze, Gregor P., Johnson Controls, Essen, Germany; Krarti, Moncef, Johnson Controls, Essen, Germany; Brandemuehl, Michael J., Johnson Controls, Essen, Germany
Abstract: This paper describes the development of a simulation environment for the evaluation of the performance of various controls of a set of common ice storage systems. The cooling plant used for this evaluation consisted of one chiller for icemaking and chilled-water modes, an ice storage, an air-handling unit, a condenser, and all required fans and pumps. The plant model allows the selection of one of three ice storage systems as well as one of three compressor types. Components are modeled using polynomial fits to manufacturers' data. Using dimensionless parameters, components can be scaled to arrive at a proper cooling plant design. The performance of a selected cooling plant configuration can be assessed for three conventional control strategies (chiller-priority, constant-proportion, and storage-priority control) and compared to optimal control that achieves the theoretical maximum of operating cost savings. Optimal control is found using a dynamic programming based global search in the domain of on-peak and off-peak demands. Mixed integer programming is used for validation using a linear plant model. A set of artificial rate structures with marked characteristics is applied to generate results that allow the discussion of fundamental features of cool storage control. The effect of non-cooling electrical loads on optimal control is illustrated.
Index Keywords: Compressors; Computer simulation; Condensers (liquefiers); Control system analysis; Energy efficiency; Fans; Ice; Integer programming; Machine design; Optimal control systems; Polynomials; Pumps; Abstract only; Ice storage systems; Mixed integer programming; Refrigerating machinery

Authors: Wixom M.R., Tarnowski D.J., Parker J.M., Lee J.Q., Chen P.-L., Song I., Thompson L.T.
Title: High surface area metal carbide and metal nitride electrodes
Affiliations: T/J Technologies, Inc, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wixom, M.R., T/J Technologies, Inc, Ann Arbor, United States; Tarnowski, D.J., T/J Technologies, Inc, Ann Arbor, United States; Parker, J.M., T/J Technologies, Inc, Ann Arbor, United States; Lee, J.Q., T/J Technologies, Inc, Ann Arbor, United States; Chen, P.-L., T/J Technologies, Inc, Ann Arbor, United States; Song, I., T/J Technologies, Inc, Ann Arbor, United States; Thompson, L.T., T/J Technologies, Inc, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: Processes for fabricating new high surface area ceramic electrode materials have been developed. These electrode materials have been applied in electrochemical capacitors and related energy storage and conversion devices. Several synthetic approaches have been developed for producing high surface area carbide or nitride active materials. The fabrication methods provide the capability to vary the composition and microstructure of the electrode material. A number of new candidate high surface area electrode materials have been synthesized. Compositional and microstructural information is presented. Electrodes have been evaluated by cyclic voltammetry, chronopotentiometry, and impedance spectroscopy in acidic and basic aqueous electrolyte systems. Single electrode and single cell performance data are presented. Intrinsic properties such as open circuit potential, electrochemical stability and specific capacitance are discussed with respect to electrode composition. The influence on performance of extrinsic factors such as electrode thickness, particle size, and pore structure is also discussed. The performance of these new materials is compared to carbon, with emphasis on advantages with respect to volumetric energy and power density.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Carbides; Ceramic materials; Composition effects; Crystal microstructure; Cyclic voltammetry; Electrodes; Electrolytes; Nitrides; Particle size analysis; Spectroscopic analysis; Synthesis (chemical); Electrochemical capacitors; High surface area ceramic electrodes; Impedance spectroscopy; Electrochemical electrodes

Authors: Ehrlich G.M., Gitzendanner R.L.
Title: Demonstration of mixed metal oxide cathode materials in prismatic Li-ion cells
Affiliations: Yardney Technical Products, Inc, Pawcatuck, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ehrlich, G.M., Yardney Technical Products, Inc, Pawcatuck, United States; Gitzendanner, R.L., Yardney Technical Products, Inc, Pawcatuck, United States
Abstract: Recent advances in mixed metal oxide (LiNi1-xCoxO2) cathode materials for lithium ion (Li-ion) batteries have resulted in a new generation of high capacity cathode materials. High capacity materials are particularly useful for applications where either volume or weight is limited, such as in space applications. These applications also benefit from cell chemistries with high energy efficiency as this permits reduced ancillary energy storage and dissipation apparatus. Mixed metal oxide materials have been evaluated and demonstrated in prismatic Li-ion cells. The capacity of the mixed metal oxide materials is exceptional, reversible capacity of 160 mAh/g is demonstrated although the cell voltage is lower than when LiCoO2 materials are used, 3.58 V vs. 3.74 V, at low (0.5 mA/cm2) discharge rates. The high capacity results in a significant improvement in specific energy, further, the sloping discharge curve characteristic of the mixed metal oxide materials facilitates determination of the state of charge based on cell voltage. The design of composite cathode materials using the mixed metal oxide materials has a significant influence on the cell impedance and the rate capability of the material. Results describing the rate capability of these materials is presented.
Index Keywords: Cathodes; Energy efficiency; Lithium compounds; Mixed metal oxide cathode materials; Lithium batteries

Authors: Iris Bahar R., Albera Gianluca, Manne Srilatha
Title: Power and performance tradeoffs using various caching strategies
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Design
Affiliations: Brown Univ, Providence, United States
Authors with affiliations: Iris Bahar, R., Brown Univ, Providence, United States; Albera, Gianluca, Brown Univ, Providence, United States; Manne, Srilatha, Brown Univ, Providence, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we propose several different data and instruction cache configurations and analyze their power as well as performance implications on the processor. Unlike most existing work in low power microprocessor design, we explore a high performance processor with the latest innovations for performance. Using a detailed, architectural-level simulator, we evaluate full system performance using several different power/performance sensitive cache configurations such as increasing cache size or associativity and including buffers along side L1 caches. We then use the information obtained from the simulator to calculate the energy consumption of the memory hierarchy of the system. As an alternative to simply increasing cache associativity or size to reduce lower-level memory energy consumption (which may have a detrimental effect on on-chip energy consumption), we show that, by using buffers, energy consumption of the memory subsystem may be reduced by as much as 13% for certain data cache configurations and by as much as 23% for certain instruction cache configurations without adversely effecting processor performance or on-chip energy consumption.
Index Keywords: Design; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Microprocessor chips; Performance; Simulation; Cache associativity; Cache size; Memory hierarchy; On chip energy consumption; Buffer storage

Authors: Coumeri Sari L., Thomas Donald E.
Title: Memory modeling for system synthesis
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Design
Affiliations: Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Coumeri, Sari L., Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, PA, United States; Thomas, Donald E., Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Abstract: We present our methodology for developing models of on-chip SRAM memory organizations. The models were created to enable the quick evaluation of energy, area, and performance of different memory configurations considered during synthesis. The models are defined in terms of parameters, such as size and mode of operation, which are known at synthesis time. Our methodology does not require knowledge of the underlying memory circuitry and provides models with average percentage errors within 8%. We found that only 10 different memories from a large span of possible memory sizes are needed to obtain reasonably accurate models, with average errors within 15%. We further use these models to evaluate different low power memory organizations and have seen energy reductions of up to 88%. In this paper we present our modeling methodology, discuss the important aspects in developing the models, and show results of using the models in evaluating low power memory organizations.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Mathematical models; Microprocessor chips; Regression analysis; Statistical methods; Energy reductions; Linear regression; System synthesis; Random access storage

Authors: Avery Stephen, Jabri Marwan
Title: Three-port adiabatic register file suitable for embedded applications
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Low Power Design
Affiliations: Univ of New South Wales
Authors with affiliations: Avery, Stephen, Univ of New South Wales; Jabri, Marwan, Univ of New South Wales
Abstract: Adiabatic logic promises extremely low power consumption for those applications where slower clock rates are acceptable. However, there have been very few adiabatic memory designs, and any circuit of even moderate complexity requires some form of RAM. This paper presents a register file implemented entirely with adiabatic logic, and fabricated using a 1.2 μm CMOS technology. Comparison with a conventional CMOS logic implementation, using both measured and simulated results, indicates significant power savings have been realised.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Computer simulation; Energy dissipation; Energy utilization; Field effect transistors; Logic gates; Random access storage; Energy recovery techniques; Three port adiabatic register file; Shift registers

Authors: Storey B.G., Allen T.R.
Title: Radiation damage of a glass-bonded zeolite waste form using ion irradiation
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab-West, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Storey, B.G., Argonne Natl Lab-West, Idaho Falls, United States; Allen, T.R., Argonne Natl Lab-West, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: Glass-bonded zeolite is being considered as a candidate ceramic waste form for storing radioactive isotopes separated from spent nuclear fuel in the electrorefining process. To determine the stability of glass-bonded zeolite under irradiation, transmission electron microscope samples were irradiated using high energy helium, lead, and krypton. The major crystalline phase of the waste form, which retains alkaline and alkaline earth fission products, loses its long range order under both helium and krypton irradiation. The dose at which the long range crystalline structure is lost is about 0.8 dpa for helium and 0.1 dpa for krypton. Because the damage from lead is localized in such a small region of the sample, damage could not be recognized even at a peak damage of 50 dpa. Because the crystalline phase loses its long range structure due to irradiation, the effect on retention capacity needs to be further evaluated.
Index Keywords: Crystal structure; Fission products; Helium; Ion bombardment; Krypton; Lead; Radiation damage; Radioactive waste storage; Transmission electron microscopy; Glass bonded zeolites; Zeolites

Affiliations: Weizmann Inst of Science, Rehovot, Israel

Abstract: The `reflective tower' optics proposed to heat molten salt in a combined ground receiver/storage tank. This concept eliminates the tubular receiver that is installed on the top of the tower and the heated piping to and from it to the storage tank. A plant similar in size to Solar Two was analyzed and evaluated. Detailed geometric parameters of the combined receiver/storage unit and the performance results of the system during a typical design clay are described.

This article reports a study on the new mechanism of glass excitation leading to modification of glass optical parameters that can be used for data recording.

Authors: Pabla Surjit S., Rane Milind V.
Title: Design and analysis of a solar energy based vaccine storage unit
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Technology, Mumbai, India
Authors with affiliations: Pabla, Surjit S., Indian Inst of Technology, Mumbai, India; Rane, Milind V., Indian Inst of Technology, Mumbai, India
Abstract: Pressure-Temperature-Concentration (P-T-X) diagrams for adsorbent/adsorbate pairs and thermal conductivity of the adsorbent with different adsorbate concentrations are important for design of adsorption refrigeration systems. Experimental investigations have been conducted to study adsorption of ammonia on activated carbons (ACs) of Indian origin and P-T-X diagrams have been generated using a computer program developed for the purpose. Thermal conductivity of activated carbons at different ammonia concentrations has also been studied experimentally. Results of these experimental investigations are presented in this paper. Design of a Solar Vaccine Storage Unit (SVSU) and results of computer simulation of variation of system performance with generation temperature, evaporator temperature, condenser temperature and module size are also presented. The simulation results show that it is possible to design and construct regenerative adsorption machines to achieve high COPs of over 1.0 without involving the complex hardware needed for affecting thermal wave. This translates to about 20 kg ice per day per m2 of solar collector. Economic analysis of SVSU shows that a unit of 165 litre storage capacity will cost around US $400, which is only about 25% of the price of SVSUs available in the market at present.
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Adsorption; Ammonia; Computer simulation; Computer software; Solar collectors; Solar energy; Thermal conductivity of solids; Pressure temperature concentration (P T X) diagrams; Solar adsorption refrigeration; Solar vaccine storage units (SVSU); Solar refrigeration
